questions.text: An 18-day-old child is brought to the OPD with complaints of recurrent vomiting. On evaluation, an olive-shaped mass was found on abdominal examination. A USG is advised and shows the following signs. Identify the condition associated.
questions.solution:
The given USG shows the cervix/ antral nipple sign and is seen in the case of Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS).

  • Firstborn male child > 3 weeks.
  • Non-bilious vomiting, palpable olive-like mass at the epigastrium.
  • The child has hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.
  • The common cause of gastric outlet obstruction (GOO), especially in first-born males between 2-6 weeks of age.

Ultrasound (USG) Findings:

  • Muscle Hypertrophy:
    • Thickening of the pyloric muscle is a hallmark feature (> 3 mm).
  • Pyloric Length:
    • Elongation of the pyloric channel is often observed. (>16 mm)
  • Double-Track or Railroad Track Sign:
    • Appearance of two parallel, echogenic (bright) lines on either side of the lumen.
    • Gives the characteristic "double-track" or "railroad track"appearance

Explanation of other options:

Intussusception (Option A) is a condition in which one segment of the intestine "telescopes" inside another, causing an intestinal obstruction (blockage). It will show a claw sign on barium studies and target sign on USG, whereas the given USG shows cervix sign, which is seen in the case of IHPS.

In the case of ileocecal tuberculosis (Option B), shows a gooseneck deformity. Gooseneck deformity occurs due to contracted, cicatrised, and pulled-up cecum as well as straightening of the terminal ileum, whereas the given USG shows a cervix sign, which is seen in the case of IHPS.

Hirschsprung disease (Option D) shows narrowing of the distal-most colon and proximal dilation of the colon, whereas the given USG shows a cervix sign, which is seen in the case of IHPS.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to psychiatry OPD with complaints of irritability, guilt of not being able to perform well in office and decreased interest in recreational activities since he left college 3 years back. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient describes a chronic low mood, anhedonia, irritability, low self-esteem, and functional impairment that has persisted for over 2 years, all hallmark features of Dysthymia (now called Persistent Depressive Disorder in DSM-5).
  • Major depression (Option A) requires more severe symptoms over a shorter duration (≥2 weeks) and is not chronic.
  • Adjustment disorder (Option B) involves mood changes triggered by a specific identifiable stressor, usually resolving within 6 months of the stressor. This case lacks a discrete trigger.
  • Personality disorder (Option C) involves lifelong patterns of behavior, but this presentation centers on mood disturbance, not fixed personality traits.

Key Takeaways:

  • Dysthymia = low-grade chronic depression ≥2 years.
  • Symptoms may be less severe but are long-lasting and disabling.
  • Must differentiate from major depression (acute/severe) and adjustment disorders (situational/short-term).

questions.text: A healthy individual is undergoing a respiratory physiology experiment. When the lungs are steadily inflated beyond normal tidal volumes, the respiratory cycle is altered, resulting in prolonged expiration. Which of the following reflexes best explains this response?
questions.solution:
• The Hering-Breuer inflation reflex is a protective pulmonary reflex that comes into play when the lungs are overinflated typically during deep or prolonged inspiration. This reflex is mediated by:
    • Slowly adapting stretch receptors (SARs) in the airway smooth muscle
    • These receptors send signals via the vagus nerve to the respiratory centers in the medulla
    • This leads to inhibition of further inspiration and prolongation of expiration

Explanation of other options:

Bezold-Jarisch reflex(Option A) A cardiovascular reflex triggered by ventricular stretch or chemical stimuli, causing bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea, not related to lung inflation.

Pulmonary chemoreflex(Option C) Elicited by chemical irritants in the lungs, it causes bronchoconstriction, apnea, and coughing, not prolonged expiration.

Hering-Breuer deflation reflex(Option D) Triggered by sudden lung deflation, it leads to increased inspiratory effort, the opposite of what's described.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: A term neonate born after prolonged labor develops lethargy and hypotonia within 6 hours of birth. The baby has a weak Moro reflex, poor suck, and experiences seizures on day 1. On examination, the pupils are constricted (miosis), and EEG shows low-voltage theta and delta waves. Based on these findings, the most appropriate Sarnat stage of Hypoxic Ischemic Encephalopathy is:
questions.solution:
• The clinical findings - lethargy, hypotonia, weak reflexes, miosis, seizures, and abnormal EEG - are hallmark features of Stage 2 HIE in the Sarnat staging system.
  • This stage is moderate HIE, and timely intervention (like therapeutic hypothermia in appropriate settings) may improve neurological outcomes.

Sarnat and Sarnat Staging:

This classification is based on:

  • Mental status
  • Muscle tone
  • Autonomic function (e.g., pupils, heart rate)
  • Seizure activity
  • EEG pattern

Knowing these stages is crucial because:

  • Stage 1 usually resolves without a neurological deficit.
  • Stage 2 has ~20-35% chance of adverse outcomes.
  • Stage 3 has poor prognosis, with high mortality and neurodevelopmental impairment.

Hypoxic Ischemic Encephalopathy (HIE):

It is a type of brain dysfunction that occurs when the brain does not receive enough oxygen (hypoxia) and/or blood flow (ischemia) for a period of time, particularly around the time of birth.

Causes of Perinatal Asphyxia Leading to HIE:

  • Uteroplacental insufficiency
  • Prolonged or obstructed labour
  • Umbilical cord compression/prolapse
  • Placental abruption
  • Maternal hypotension or cardiac arrest
  • Severe neonatal anaemia (e.g., fetomaternal hemorrhage)

Pathophysiology of HIE:

  1. Initial insult: Lack of oxygen/blood → energy failure → cellular dysfunction.
  2. Reperfusion phase: Restoration of blood leads to free radical damage, calcium influx, and apoptosis.
  3. Secondary energy failure: Occurs after 6-48 hours; critical window for therapeutic intervention (e.g., hypothermia).

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical signs (altered consciousness, seizures, abnormal tone)
  • APGAR score <3 for more than 5 minutes
  • Need for resuscitation >10 minutes
  • Multisystem organ involvement
  • MRI/EEG findings may help assess severity and prognosis

Treatment:

  • Therapeutic hypothermia:
    • Initiate within 6 hours of birth
    • Continue for 72 hours
    • Reduces cerebral metabolic demand and apoptosis
    • Improves neurodevelopmental outcomes if given early in moderate HIE
  • Supportive care:
    • Manage seizures (Phenobarbitone is first-line)
    • Maintain ventilation, perfusion, glucose, and electrolytes
    • Monitor organ function (renal, hepatic, cardiac)

Stage 1 (Mild) (Option A): Stage I HIE usually presents with hyperalertness, normal tone, brisk reflexes, and no seizures, with a normal EEG. The presence of lethargy, hypotonia, and seizures here clearly rules this out.

Stage 3 (Severe) (Option C): Stage III involves coma or stupor, absent reflexes, flaccid tone, and an isoelectric (flat) EEG. This neonate is lethargic but not comatose, and has low-voltage EEG, not a flat one.

No HIE - Normal findings (Option D): The neonate has multiple signs of neurological dysfunction (seizures, tone abnormalities, EEG changes), strongly indicating hypoxic encephalopathy, not a normal perinatal transition.

Reference:

  1. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10874515

choices.text: Tavernier manoeuvre is used for closed reduction
Lunate remains in position and the carpals dislocate dorsally
Lunate dislocates ventrally and carpals remain in position

questions.text: Which is incorrect about perilunate dislocation?
questions.solution:
• In Lunate dislocation the lunate dislocates out of the carpus while in Perilunate dislocation the lunate stays in its place while all other carpal bones dislocate out of the carpus.(Option C explained)
  • In other words, in lunate dislocation long axis of radius passes through the capitate and in perilunate dislocation long axis of radius passes through the lunate.
  • The most common nerve injured in perilunate dislocation as well as in fracture of lunate is the Median nerve. (Option B explained)
  • X-ray of perilunate dislocation shows discontinuity of Gilula's arc. In lateral view of lunate dis- location, lunate is seen palmarly rotated and no longer articulates with capitate (Spilled teapot sign).
  • Treatment- In reducible perilunate dislocation close reduction and percutaneous pinning is recommended. Close reduction is achieved by Tavernier manoeuvre. For irreducible peri- lunate dislocations open reduction and repair is required.(Option A explained)

questions.text: What is the most common cause of cystoid macular edema that demonstrates a fluorescein angiographic hyperfluorescent cystic ("petaloid") pattern?
questions.solution:
• Cystoid Macular Edema (CME) involves retinal thickening of the macula due to a disruption of the normal blood-retinal barrier, leading to leakage from perifoveal retinal capillaries and fluid accumulation primarily in the outer plexiform layer.
  • Of the listed causes, cataract surgery is the most common cause of clinical and angiographic CME that demonstrates a hyperfluorescent cystic ("petaloid") pattern on fluorescein angiography. This post-surgical inflammation is a well-known phenomenon.

Explanation of Other Options:

Retinitis pigmentosa (Option A): Retinitis pigmentosa is a rare cause of CME. While CME can occur, it's not the most common cause of the specific angiographic pattern described.

Niacin (Option B): CME can occur with niacin use, particularly at doses greater than 1.5g/day, causing blurry vision. However, niacin toxicity typically does not demonstrate retinal cystic hyperfluorescence on fluorescein angiography; importantly, leakage is not reported with niacin-induced CME.

Choroidal neovascularization (Option D): While choroidal neovascularization (CNV) may be associated with cystic retinal thickening seen on optical coherence tomography (OCT), it rarely demonstrates a hyperfluorescent cystic ("petaloid") pattern on fluorescein angiography. CNV typically shows different leakage patterns.

Key Takeaways:

  • Cystoid Macular Edema (CME) is characterized by fluid accumulation in the macula, primarily in the outer plexiform layer, due to a disrupted blood-retinal barrier.
  • Cataract surgery is the most common cause of CME that exhibits a fluorescein angiographic hyperfluorescent cystic ("petaloid") pattern.

choices.text: The patient may continue breastfeeding at her own risk
The patient should breastfeed her baby only if her INR is <2.5
The patient can breastfeed her baby after the 6-week course of warfarin is over
Warfarin is not a contraindication for lactation

questions.text: Sarita, a 30-year-old woman, develops a deep vein thrombosis in her left calf on the fourth postoperative day following a caesarean section done for foetal distress. The patient is started on heparin and is scheduled to begin a 6-week course of warfarin therapy. The patient is a devoted mother who wants to breastfeed her baby. What advice can be given to the patient?
questions.solution:
• Warfarin is not excreted in significant quantities into breast milk and is considered safe during lactation
  • Recommended in postpartum anticoagulation after initial heparin in cases like DVT
  • Supported by Williams Obstetrics and ACOG guidelines

Explanation of other options:

Patient may continue breastfeeding at her own risk (Option A): Misleading and incorrect; there is no risk with warfarin in lactation.

The patient should breastfeed her baby only if her INR is <2.5 (Option B): INR monitoring is for maternal anticoagulation control, not related to breastfeeding safety.

Patient can breastfeed baby after the 6 6-weekourse of warfarin is over (Option C): Unnecessary restriction; breastfeeding can and should continue during warfarin therapy.

Key Takeaways:

  • Warfarin is safe for breastfeeding mothers
  • INR level does not impact breastfeeding safety
  • No need to delay or avoid breastfeeding while on warfarin

choices.text: Delayed-type hypersensitivity skin test with PPD

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents with recurrent skin and soft tissue infections caused by Staphylococcus aureus and Serratia marcescens. His infections often form abscesses, but his serum immunoglobulin levels and T-cell counts are normal. To evaluate his neutrophil function, which of the following tests is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
• The NBT test is a classical assay used to evaluate the phagocytic function, specifically the oxidative (respiratory) burst in neutrophils and monocytes.
  • In this test, Nitroblue Tetrazolium (NBT) is reduced to formazan (a blue-black precipitate) by superoxide radicals generated during the oxidative burst.
  • A normal NBT test shows dark blue staining inside cells, indicating functional NADPH oxidase activity.
  • An abnormal NBT test lacks formazan formation, indicating a defect in ROS generation, as seen in Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD).
  • The second image diagrammatically shows how normal phagocytes reduce NBT to purple-blue formazan, while defective ones remain yellow, indicating formazan-negative cells.
  • Thus, NBT reduction test directly assesses phagocytic oxidative killing capacity, making it the correct choice.

NBT Test:

  • Detects NADPH oxidase activity in neutrophils.
  • Used for diagnosing CGD, a condition with recurrent bacterial and fungal infections due to impaired phagocyte killing.
  • Formazan positive = Normal ROS function.
  • Formazan negative = Abnormal ROS generation → defective phagocytes.
  • Alternative modern test: DHR (Dihydrorhodamine) flow cytometry - more sensitive and quantitative.

Proliferative response to mitogens (Option A):

  • Tests T-cell function, not phagocytic function.
  • Assessed by measuring lymphocyte proliferation in response to mitogens like phytohemagglutinin (PHA) or concanavalin A.

Serum immunoglobulin assay (Option C):

  • Measures humoral (B-cell) immunity, not neutrophil or phagocyte function.

Delayed-type hypersensitivity skin test with PPD (Option D):

  • Tests cell-mediated immunity (T-cell response) to Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Key Takeaways:

  • NBT reduction test evaluates the ability of neutrophils to undergo an oxidative burst, essential for killing microbes.
  • Blue-black formazan = functional phagocytes; no staining = defective (e.g., CGD).
  • A simple, rapid screening tool for innate immune defects affecting phagocyte function.

questions.text: Edmond Locard is most known for?
questions.solution:
Edmond Locard is most famously known for his Theory of Exchange, often referred to as Locard's Exchange Principle.

  • Edmond Locard, a pioneering French criminologist, is widely regarded as the father of modern forensic science.
  • Locard's Exchange Principle: The central tenet of forensic science, stating that "every contact leaves a trace." This highlights the inevitability of material transfer during any interaction.
  • Significance: This principle guides the collection and analysis of all forms of trace evidence (e.g., fibres, hair, soil, glass fragments) at a crime scene.
  • Poroscopy:Locard also developed poroscopy, a specialised technique for studying fingerprint pores for individual identification, though it is less widely recognised than his Exchange Principle.

Explanation of Other Options:

Study of fingerprints (Option A): Sir Edward Richard Henry is widely recognised for developing the first systematic classification system of fingerprints (Henry Classification System) used globally.

Stature estimation (Option C): The notable work in stature estimation from long bones is attributed to Rollet (1888), who published extensive tables for this purpose.

Forensic ballistics (Option D): The initial success in forensic ballistics is generally credited to Henry Goddard in 1835, who famously matched a bullet to a specific mould.

Key Takeaways:

  • Edmond Locard is predominantly recognized for his "Theory of Exchange" / "Locard's Exchange Principle."

questions.text: A patient of nasal trauma presents to an ENT specialist. X-ray nasal bone shows a nasal bone fracture. The fracture reduction is being planned. The surgeon uses the forceps shown in the given picture. What is the name of these forceps?
questions.solution:
WALSHAM'S FORCEPS

Used to reduce nasal bone fracture

ASCH'S FORCEPS

Used to reduce nseptal fracture

Luc's forceps (Option C): Used in Caldwell-Luc operation (to remove mucosa), submucosal resection (SMR) operation (to remove bone or cartilage), polypectomy (to grasp and avulse polyps) and to take a biopsy from the nose or throat

Freer's double-ended elevator (Option D): Used for elevation of mucoperichondrium or periosteum in SMR or septoplasty operation.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with an itchy rash on his thigh. He gave a history of using topical corticosteroids a few days back, which gave him temporary relief. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Tinea incognito is a type of dermatophyte infection modified by corticosteroid (systemic or topical) and other immunosuppressive agents.

Tinea incognito

  • Ringworm infection altered by systemic or topical corticosteroids, often prescribed for another condition or misdiagnosed as eczema, is called tinea incognito due to its disguised appearance.

Pathophysiology:

  • Corticosteroids suppress local inflammation and immune response, masking typical ringworm signs.
  • They also reduce cell-mediated immunity, allowing fungal growth to continue unchecked.

Clinical Features

  • Patients often report initial relief from itching and redness.
  • Symptoms recur after stopping steroids, and reapplication brings temporary relief, creating a treatment cycle.
  • Presentation:
    • The characteristic raised, scaly border disappears.
    • Appearance includes nondescript nodules, brownish discolouration, and minimal inflammation.
    • On the face, it may mimic perioral dermatitis (papules and pustules); on the eyelids, it can resemble a stye.
    • Chronic use may cause skin atrophy, telangiectasia, and striae in the groins or underarms.
    • Even mild steroids (like 1% hydrocortisone) can significantly alter the presentation.

Management

  • Oral antifungals (e.g., terbinafine, itraconazole) are recommended rather than topical agents alone.
  • Continue low-potency topical steroids (e.g., 1% hydrocortisone) temporarily to ease symptoms while antifungals take effect.
  • Advise patients about possible symptom rebound and the importance of steroid discontinuation.
  • Arrange follow-up to confirm steroids have stopped and the infection is fully resolved.

Tinea corporis (Option A), commonly referred to as ringworm, is a superficial fungal infection of the skin caused by dermatophytes from the Trichophyton, Epidermophyton, or Microsporum genera. It typically presents with itching and may become extensive or merge into larger patches, particularly in individuals with weakened immune systems.

Tinea cruris (Options B) or jock itch, is a fungal infection affecting the skin of the groin, pubic region, perineum, and perianal area, caused by dermatophyte fungi. Patients typically present with an itchy rash localised to the groin area.

questions.text: A newborn presents with poor feeding, lethargy, and a characteristic maple syrup odour to the urine. On examination, there is hypotonia and intermittent apnea. Urine analysis in this infant will show which aminoacid/s?
questions.solution:
The above-described clinical scenario in this infant is suggestive of Maple syrup urine disease. The basic biochemical defect is a deficiency of Branched Chain Ketoacid Dehydrogenase, resulting in the accumulation of branched-chain keto acids - Leucine, Isoleucine and Valine, which are then excreted in Urine.

Maple Syrup Urine Disease :

Biochemical defect

  • Deficiency of the enzyme Branched Chain Ketoacid Dehydrogenase.
  • Results in deficient decarboxylation of branched-chain keto acids - Valine, Leucine, Isoleucine.

Clinical features

  • Mental Retardation
  • Convulsion
  • Acidosis, Coma
  • Burnt Sugar [Maple Syrup] smell of urine (Due to excretion of branched-chain keto acid in urine)

Tests for MSUD

  • Di Nitro Phenyl Hydrazine Test (DNPH Test)
  • Rothera's Test (Positive)
  • Enzyme Analysis

Treatment

  • Restrict Branched Chain Amino Acid
  • Give high doses of Thiamine.

Explanation of Other Options:

Leucine, Lysine (Option A): Lysine is not a branched-chain amino acid.

Leucine only (Option C): Although leucine is elevated, isoleucine and valine are also involved.

Lysine only (Option D): Lysine is unrelated to MSUD.

Key Takeaways:

Maple Syrup Urine Disease is due to a deficiency in branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase, leading to the accumulation of leucine, isoleucine, and valine in blood and urine.

questions.text: As a researcher studying the circuitry of the cerebellum, which of the following cells is known to be the major output neuron of the cerebellar cortex?
questions.solution:
Purkinje cells are the major output neurons of the cerebellar cortex.

  • They receive inputs from various sources within the cerebellum and send their axons to different targets outside the cerebellum.
  • These cells play a crucial role in motor coordination and learning.
  • They are characterised by their distinctive morphology, with a large, flat dendritic tree that receives inputs from parallel fibres and a single axon that projects to the deep cerebellar nuclei.
  • Purkinje cells are critical for the integration and modulation of motor signals, making them the major output neurons of the cerebellar cortex.

Explanation of Other Options:

Dentate nucleus (Option B): A deep cerebellar nucleus that receives inhibitory input from Purkinje cells and gives excitatory output via the superior cerebellar peduncle.

Fastigial nucleus (Option C): Another deep cerebellar nucleus involved in posture and equilibrium; not part of the cortex.

Clarke's nucleus (Option D): Located in the spinal cord (T1-L2); source of the dorsal spinocerebellar tract, not part of cerebellar cortex or its output.

questions.text: Which of the following induction agents is associated with the Robinhood phenomenon?
questions.solution:
• The Robinhood phenomenon (reverse cerebral steal) occurs when vasoconstriction in normally perfused cerebral areas redirects blood flow to ischemic regions where vessels are already maximally dilated.
  • Thiopentone sodium decreases cerebral metabolic rate (CMRO2) and intracranial pressure (ICP).
  • It induces cerebral vasoconstriction, which favors redistribution of blood toward ischemic tissue, producing the reverse steal effect.

Explanation of other options:

Ketamine (Option A): Causes cerebral vasodilation and increases CBF and ICP, which can worsen cerebral ischemia.

Propofol (Option B): Causes global reduction in CBF and CMRO2, but is not specifically associated with the reverse steal phenomenon.

Etomidate (Option C): Minimally affects CBF and ICP, not associated with Robinhood phenomenon.

Key Takeaways:

  • Thiopentone causes cerebral vasoconstriction and may lead to reverse steal
  • Ketamine increases CBF and ICP
  • The Robinhood phenomenon benefits ischemic brain areas

questions.text: Which of the following is an ionic dimer?
questions.solution:
Ioxaglate is classified as an ionic dimer among the types of iodinated radiocontrast agents.

  • Iodinated radiocontrast agents are broadly categorized based on their ionic properties and molecular structure (monomer vs. dimer).
  • Ionic Dimers specifically include ioxaglate

Key Takeaway:

Iodinated radiocontrast agents are categorized by their ionic nature and molecular size. Ioxaglate is a key example of an ionic dimer, distinguishing it from ionic monomers (like Diatrizoate and Iothalamate) and non-ionic monomers (like Iohexol).

choices.text: It is associated with physical dependence only.
Can cause depersonalisation and derealisation at high doses
The active ingredient of cannabis is delta-9 tetrahydrocannabinol
Running amok and Magnan's phenomenon are characteristic of long-term use.

questions.text: A 22-year-old unemployed male is brought to the ED by friends after an alleged history of smoking cannabis "joints" at a party. He complains of tripling the size of his friend's face and the room becoming distorted and changing in colour and proportion. He is anxious, and examination showed bilateral conjunctival injection and increased HR. All of the following are true about such an intoxicated state except:
questions.solution:
The symptoms are suggestive of Cannabis intoxication, and Cannabis is associated only with psychological dependence and not physical dependence.

  • Cannabis is the most commonly illegally used drug in India and the world, known by street names - joint, marijuana, grass, pot, and weed.
  • The active ingredient of Cannabis is delta-9 tetrahydrocannabinol, which is responsible for its addictive nature. (Option C)
  • The cannabinoid receptor is found in highest concentrations in the basal ganglia, the hippocampus, and the cerebellum, with lower concentrations in the cerebral cortex.
  • The most common route of administration is by smoking.
  • Only psychological dependence is seen with cannabis use; physical withdrawal symptoms are not seen. (Option B)
  • When cannabis is smoked, the euphoric effects appear within minutes, peak in about 30 minutes and last 2 to 4 hours.

Cannabis intoxication:

  • Symptoms of cannabis intoxication include:
    • Voracious appetite
    • Dry mouth
    • Reddening of the conjunctiva
    • Euphoria
    • Synaesthesia (crossing of senses).
    • An unpleasant experience (like fear, extreme anxiety) is called a Bad Trip.
  • Cannabis intoxication commonly heightens users' sensitivities to external stimuli, reveals new details, makes colours seem brighter and richer, and subjectively slows the appreciation of time. Thus, in high doses, users may experience depersonalizationand derealization. (Option B)

Cannabis related disorders

  • Hemp insanity refers to cannabis induced psychosis associated with delusions and hallucinations.
  • Cannabis and LSD are known to cause the Flashback phenomenon due to their high fat solubility. It refers to the recurrence of cannabis use experience in the absence of current cannabis use.
  • Running amok: A sudden, uncontrolled, violent outburst seen with cannabis use, resulting in hurting or killing someone. (Option D)

Key Takeaways :

Cannabis and LSD :

  • No physical dependence
  • Flashback phenomenon
  • High fat solubility

choices.text: Flower spray endings of the muscle

questions.text: A 34-year-old man performs stretching exercises before a workout to prevent muscle injury. Which sensory receptor is primarily stimulated to protect the muscle from excessive tension?
questions.solution:
The Golgi tendon organ is stimulated by stretching the muscle.

Golgi Tendon Organ (GTO):

  • Located in the musculotendinous junction.
  • Responds to tension/stretch in the tendon (especially prolonged or forceful stretch).
  • Activation leads to inhibition of alpha motor neurons, causing muscle relaxation → Prevents tendon/muscle injury during overstretching

Explanation of Other Options:

Annulospiral endings (Option A): These detect sudden muscle stretch and trigger the stretch reflex, leading to muscle contraction, not relaxation, which is the opposite of what is needed during pre-exercise stretching.

Flower spray endings (Option B): These respond to sustained stretch and help maintain muscle tone, but do not play a primary role in preventing muscle damage via relaxation.

Key Takeaway:

The Golgi tendon organ is the key proprioceptor that prevents muscle injury during stretching by causing muscle relaxation in response to high tension.

choices.text: Suction the nose first, followed by the mouth
Routine suctioning of mouth and nose is recommended in all deliveries
Suction the mouth first, then the nose if needed

questions.text: A term neonate is delivered through meconium-stained amniotic fluid. Immediately after birth, the baby is vigorous with a good tone and strong cry. The healthcare team prepares for routine neonatal resuscitation under a radiant warmer. Which of the following is the most appropriate step regarding airway management in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Neonatal resuscitation is a critical skill aimed at stabilizing newborns with compromised respiration and circulation after birth. As per the 2020 AHA/AAP Neonatal Resuscitation Program (NRP) guidelines, suctioning should only be performed if there is an obstruction or excessive secretions.

In neonates born through meconium-stained liquor, the vigorous baby (crying, HR > 100 bpm, good tone)does NOT need deep (tracheal) suctioning. Instead, if necessary, gentle suctioning should be performed with a bulb syringe or suction catheter, and the correct order is:

Mouth first → then nose

("M before N" - to prevent aspiration if the baby gasps)

Routine suctioning of all neonates is no longer recommended, as it may delay initiation of ventilation and even cause bradycardia due to vagal stimulation.

Neonatal Resuscitation:

  • Definition: Life-saving steps to support breathing/circulation after birth.
  • Burden: Birth asphyxia causes ~19% of neonatal deaths in India.
  • Need:
    • 85% of newborns breathe spontaneously.
    • 10% need basic support (drying/stimulation).
    • 5% need PPV.
  • Consequences: Impaired lung fluid clearance, hypoxemia, poor pulmonary flow, multiorgan dysfunction.

Resuscitation Preparation:

  • Team readiness: Assign roles, check equipment.
  • Equipment includes:
    • Suction: Catheters, meconium aspirator
    • Airway: Bag/mask, oxygen
    • Intubation: ET tubes, laryngoscope
    • Drugs: Epinephrine, saline
    • Others: Warm linen, stethoscope, feeding tube
  • PPV Correction (MR SOPA): Mask, Reposition, Suction, Open mouth, Pressure ↑, Alt. airway
  • Drugs: Epinephrine (0.2 mL/kg IV), saline 10 mL/kg if hypovolemic

Post-Resuscitation Care:

  • Monitor vitals, temperature, glucose
  • Begin breastfeeding if stable
  • Avoid routine suctioning; it may cause bradycardia or delay ventilation.
  • Always prioritize PPV if breathing is inadequate.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8606598

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman presents after falling on her outstretched hand. She complains of pain, swelling, and deformity near the wrist. X-ray shows a dorsally displaced, angulated distal radius fracture with radial shortening. After closed reduction, she is placed in a dorsal slab. During follow-up, she develops wrist stiffness and persistent burning pain in her hand. Which of the following is not a known complication of her condition?
questions.solution:
Gunstock deformity is not a complication of Colles fracture; it is seen in supracondylar fractures of the humerus.

Colles fracture, a dorsally displaced distal radius fracture common in elderly women following FOOSH (fall on outstretched hand), has several complications:

  • Non-union is rare in Colles fracture but has been documented.
  • EPL (extensor pollicis longus) tendon rupture occurs late due to attrition over the displaced fracture.
  • Complex Regional Pain Syndrome (CRPS) is a known painful complication.

Explanation of Other Options:

Non-union (Option A): Rare but documented late complication of Colles fracture.

EPL tear (Option B): Known late complication due to attrition over displaced fragments.

CRPS (Option C):Sudeck's dystrophy, a chronic pain condition, is a late complication of wrist fractures.

questions.text: Attachment of the vitreous to the posterior surface of the lens is called
questions.solution:
The attachment of the vitreous to the posterior surface of the lens is specifically called Weigert's ligament. This ligament forms a circular adhesion, marking a firm connection point.

Explanation of Other Options:

Patellar fossa (Option A): The patellar fossa is the saucer-shaped depression on the anterior surface of the vitreous body where the lens rests. It is not the attachment itself.

Retrolental space of Berger (Option C): The retrolental space of Berger is the potential space between the lens and the vitreous within the confines of Weigert's ligament, not the attachment structure itself.

Ciliary zonules (Option D):Ciliary zonules, also known as the suspensory ligament of the lens, are fibrous strands that extend from the ciliary body to the lens equator. They are responsible for holding the lens in place and play a role in accommodation, but they do not describe the attachment of the vitreous to the posterior lens surface.

Key Takeaways:

  • Weigert's ligament is the specific anatomical term for the attachment of the vitreous to the posterior lens capsule.
  • The retrolental space of Berger is a potential space, not a ligament, located within this attachment.

Explanation:

The attachment of the vitreous to the posterior surface of the lens is called Weigert's ligament.

The potential space between the lens and vitreous is called retrolental space of Berger.

choices.text: Enhanced by estrogen and inhibited by progesterone

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the hormonal regulation of uterine muscle sensitivity during late pregnancy and labor?
questions.solution:
During late pregnancy and at the onset of labor, estrogen increases the uterus's responsiveness by:

  1. Upregulating oxytocin receptors on myometrial cells
  2. Increasing gap junctions, promoting synchronized contractions
  3. Stimulating synthesis of myometrial contractile proteins (e.g., actinomycin) via the cAMP pathway
  4. Making the uterine muscles more excitable and active, with frequent action potentials

In contrast, progesterone inhibits uterine sensitivity by:

  1. Decreasing frequency and intensity of uterine contractions
  2. Suppressing oxytocin receptor expression and myometrial excitability
  3. Maintaining uterine quiescence during pregnancy to prevent premature labor
  4. Although it slightly increases contraction amplitude, its overall effect is inhibitory

Explanation of other options:

Enhanced by progesterone (Option A): Incorrect, progesterone's role is primarily to suppress contractions, not enhance them

Enhanced by estrogen (Option B): Partially correct but incomplete, it does not acknowledge progesterone's opposing effect, which is essential for understanding overall uterine sensitivity

Inhibited by estrogen (Option C): Incorrect, estrogen has a stimulatory role, promoting contraction readiness and oxytocin sensitivity

Key Takeaways:

  • Estrogen enhances uterine contractility by increasing receptor expression, gap junctions, and excitability
  • Progesterone inhibits uterine sensitivity to maintain pregnancy
  • The estrogen: progesterone ratio shift near term is critical for labor initiation

choices.text: Resistance is due to plasmid-mediated β-lactamase production
Community-acquired MRSA is mediated by mecA subtype I and is less virulent
PCR can be used to detect the mecA gene directly
MRSA is resistant to all β-lactams, including 5th-generation cephalosporins

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with recurrent skin abscesses. Culture from his lesions grows methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Antibiotic susceptibility testing confirms resistance mediated by a chromosomal gene encoding an altered penicillin-binding protein. Which of the following statements regarding MRSA is correct?
questions.solution:
• The patient's MRSA strain has resistance mediated by the mecA gene, which is located on the chromosome.
  • mecA encodes PBP2a (penicillin-binding protein 2a), which has low affinity for β-lactams.
  • Since mecA is a genetic determinant of resistance, PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) can directly detect the mecA gene, making it a rapid and sensitive diagnostic tool.
  • This is particularly useful when compared to traditional disk diffusion testing, which is phenotypic and slower.

MRSA: Mechanism, Types, Detection & Treatment

Definition:

  • MRSA = S. aureus resistant to methicillin/oxacillin:
    • Methicillin MIC ≥8 µg/mL
    • Oxacillin MIC ≥4 µg/mL

Mechanism of Resistance:

  • Mediated by mecA gene (chromosomally encoded).
  • mecA produces PBP2a, which has reduced affinity for β-lactam antibiotics.

Penicillin-Binding Protein (PBP):

  • Present in bacterial cell walls.
  • Functions as a transpeptidase, essential for cross-linking peptidoglycan.
  • Target of β-lactams (binding & inhibition).

Detection of MRSA:

  • Disk diffusion test (Muller-Hinton agar) with methicillin, oxacillin, or cefoxitin discs.
  • PCR for direct detection of mecA gene - more sensitive and specific.

Treatment of MRSA:

  • First-line: Vancomycin (when resistant to other agents).
  • Alternatives: Linezolid, teicoplanin, streptogramins, clindamycin, TMP-SMX, doxycycline, minocycline.
  • Newer agents: Daptomycin, delafloxacin, oritavancin, dalbavancin.
  • 5th-generation cephalosporins (ceftaroline, ceftobiprole) - β-lactams that are effective against MRSA.

Resistance is due to plasmid-mediated β-lactamase production (Option A):

  • MRSA resistance is chromosomally mediated by mecA, not plasmid-borne β-lactamase. β-lactamases confer penicillin resistance, not MRSA-level resistance.

Community-acquired MRSA is mediated by mecA subtype I and is less virulent (Option B):

  • CA-MRSA is mediated by mecA subtype IV, produces PV toxin, is more virulent, and shows monodrug resistance. mecA subtype I is seen in HA-MRSA.

MRSA is resistant to all β-lactams, including 5th-generation cephalosporins (Option D):

  • While MRSA is resistant to most β-lactams, it remains susceptible to 5th-generation cephalosporins (ceftaroline& ceftobiprole) because they can bind PBP2a effectively.

Key Take Aways:

  • MRSA resistance: mecA → PBP2a → reduced β-lactam affinity.
  • CA-MRSA: mecA subtype IV, PV toxin, more virulent.
  • HA-MRSA: mecA subtypes I-III, multidrug resistance, less virulent.
  • Detection: Disk diffusion (phenotypic) & PCR (genotypic).
  • Treatment: Vancomycin, newer drugs, and 5th-gen cephalosporins.

choices.text: Generalised extension of the body is present
Occurs due to the coagulation of muscle protein

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about pugilistic attitude?
questions.solution:
Pugilistic attitude (also known as heat stiffening) is caused by coagulation of muscle proteins when a body is exposed to high temperatures (>65°C), such as in:

  • Burns,
  • High-voltage electrocution,
  • Falling into boiling liquids.

Due to the bulk and strength of flexor muscles, they contract more than extensors during thermal exposure, resulting in flexed posture resembling a boxer's pose.

It can occur both antemortem and postmortem, especially in charred or extensively burned bodies.

  • Heat stiffening must be differentiated from rigor mortis, cold stiffening, gas stiffening, and cadaveric spasm.
  • Unlike rigor mortis (due to ATP depletion), pugilistic attitude is protein denaturation-dependent and develops rapidly under intense heat.
  • This finding alone does not indicate whether burns occurred before or after death-additional signs (e.g., soot in airways, COHb) are needed.

Explanation of Other Options:

Only postmortem in nature (Option A): Pugilistic attitude can occur antemortem or postmortem, depending on timing of burn.

ATP depletion is the cause (Option B): ATP depletion leads to rigor mortis, not heat stiffening.

Generalised extension of the body is present (Option C): Flexion of limbs (not extension) is characteristic of pugilistic attitude.

Key Takeaway:

Pugilistic attitude is a flexed posture caused by heat-induced coagulation of muscle proteins, seen in both antemortem and postmortem burns.

choices.text: Ponticulus is the bony spicule between the oval and round windows
Subiculum is the bony spicule from the promontory to the pyramid
Donaldson's line is a surgical landmark for the Posterior cranial fossa
The Facial recess is the surgical landmark for posterior tympanostomy

questions.text: Which of the following is an appropriate statement?
questions.solution:
• The facial recess is the surgical landmark for posterior tympanostomy
  • Subiculum (Option B) separates the oval and round windows.
  • Ponticulus (Option A) runs from the promontory to the pyramid
  • Donaldson's line (Option C) is a surgical landmark for the endolymphatic sac
  • Trautmann's triangle is a surgical landmark for the posterior cranial fossa
  • McEvan's triangle (suprameatal triangle) is a surgical landmark for the mastoid antrum.

questions.text: Identify the disorder in which the following clinical picture is seen:
questions.solution:
Pityriasis rubra pilaris (PRP) is a rare chronic papulosquamous disorder characterised by follicular papules and sharply demarcated islands of sparing.

Definition:

PRP is an idiopathic inflammatory skin disorder affecting both children and adults. Shows a cephalocaudal spread with characteristic clinical features.

Clinical Features:

  • Initial presentation: Diffuse fine scaling on the scalp.
  • Progression: Papules coalesce into plaques that spread in a cephalocaudal manner.
  • Classic hallmark: Orange-red follicular hyperkeratotic papules with intervening normal skin - described as "islands of sparing".
  • May evolve into generalised erythroderma.
  • Palmoplantar keratoderma: Red-orange thickening of palms and soles - described as "sandal-like PPK".
  • Nail changes: Thickening, discolouration, and subungual hyperkeratosis may occur.
  • Juvenile classic PRP often resolves spontaneously.

Pathology & Investigations (Histology):

  • Epidermis: Alternating horizontal and vertical orthokeratosis and parakeratosis (checkerboard pattern).
  • Hair follicles: Follicular plugging and irregular acanthosis.
  • Dermis: Sparse superficial perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate.
  • These histopathological findings help distinguish PRP from psoriasis and eczema.

Explanation of other options:

Psoriasis (Option A): Characterised by silvery-white scales and symmetrical plaques; lacks follicular accentuation and islands of sparing.

Eczema (Option B): Typically vesicular in acute stages, with crusting and oozing, not follicular-based or progressing to erythroderma.

Lichen nitidus (Option C): Tiny, flat-topped, shiny papules; not associated with cephalocaudal spread, palmoplantar keratoderma, or islands of sparing.

Key Takeaway:

Pityriasis rubra pilaris is a chronic dermatosis present with orange-red follicular papules, islands of sparing, cephalocaudal progression, and waxy palmoplantar keratoderma.

questions.text: Vitamin A functions as a prosthetic group in cones of the eye as.
questions.solution:
Vitamin A functions as retinaldehyde, the prosthetic group of the rods and cones, as Rhodopsin in the rods and Iodopsin in the cones in the retina.

Vitamin A:

  • Each cone cell in the retina is specialised to detect one of three primary colours: blue, green, or red. This specialisation allows for colour vision.
  • Each cone cell contains a single type of opsin pigment that determines its sensitivity to a specific wavelength of light, corresponding to one of the primary colours.
  • Vitamin A deficiency is the most important preventable cause of blindness.
  • The earliest sign of deficiency is loss of sensitivity to green light, followed by impairment in adapting to dim light, night blindness and eventually inability to see in the dark.
  • In vitamin A deficiency, both time and ability to adapt in the dark are poor. Vitamin A is essential for the synthesis of rhodopsin in rod cells, which are responsible for vision in low-light conditions.
  • Prolonged deficiency leads to xerophthalmia, keratinisation of the cornea and eventually blindness.

Explanation of other options:

Rhodopsin(Option A): Vitamin A functions as a prosthetic group of the rods as Rhodopsin.

Conopsin(Option B): It is a photopigment, a light-sensitive protein and when bound to retinal, becomes Iodopsin.

questions.text: Which is a derivative of the dorsal mesogastrium?
questions.solution:
Among the options, only the greater omentum is a derivative of the dorsal mesogastrium.

  • During the development of the gut, the stomach is first seen as a fusiform dilatation of the foregut just distal to the oesophagus.
  • Its distal border is attached to the posterior abdominal wall by a fold of peritoneum called the dorsal mesogastrium. The ventral border is attached to the septum transversum by another fold of peritoneum called the ventral mesogastrium.
  • The organs spleen and pancreas develop in the dorsal mesogastrium, and the liver develops in the ventral mesogastrium.

During the development of the gut, there are two mesogastria attaching to the developing stomach: the dorsal mesogastriumand the ventral mesogastrium. Different organs begin to develop in each mesogastrium--the spleen and pancreas develop in the dorsal mesogastrium and the liver develops in the ventral mesogastrium. So, the structures involving the spleen and the posterior part of the developing stomach (which becomes the greater curvature) are derived from the dorsal mesogastrium. These include: the greater omentum (gastrophrenic ligament, gastrosplenic ligament, gastrocolic ligament) and splenorenal ligament. The structures involved with the liver and its attachment to the stomach wall form the ventral mesogastrium. These include the lesser omentum (hepatogastric ligament, hepatoduodenal ligament) and the ligaments of the liver (falciform ligament, coronary ligaments, right and left triangular ligaments). Of the answer choices, only the greater omentum is part of the dorsal mesogastrium.

choices.text: Maximum inspiratory flow may exceed 30L/min during spontaneous breathing
Nasal cannulae significantly improve oxygenation even if the patient breathes through the mouth
A Venturi mask uses the Bernoulli principle
A Hudson mask is a fixed performance device

questions.text: A patient on the high dependency unit has pneumonia and is hypoxia on room air. When deciding which method of oxygen administration is appropriate, which of the following statements is FALSE?
questions.solution:
The false statement is Hudson mask is a fixed performance device

  • A Hudson mask (also known as a simple face mask) is a variable performance device.
  • FiO2 delivered depends on:
    • Oxygen flow rate (typically 5-10 L/min)
    • Patient's tidal volume and respiratory rate
    • Degree of room air entrainment
  • FiO2 is not consistent, typically ranges between 35% and 60%, and is not reliable for patients needing precise oxygen levels.

Explanation of other options:

Maximum inspiratory flow may exceed 30 L/min during spontaneous breathing.(option A)

  • In spontaneously breathing patients - especially those in respiratory distress - peak inspiratory flow rates can exceed 30-40 L/min, and may go up to 60 L/min or more.
  • This is clinically significant when choosing an oxygen delivery device, as low-flow devices may not meet inspiratory demand, leading to entrainment of room air and variable FiO2.

Nasal cannulae significantly improve oxygenation even if the patient breathes through the mouth.(option B):

Even in mouth breathers, oxygen delivered via nasal cannula improves oxygenation due to:

  • Oxygen reservoir effect in the nasopharynx.
  • Positive nasopharyngeal oxygen concentration, which gets entrained during inspiration.

A Venturi mask uses the Bernoulli principle (Option C):

  • Venturi masks work via the Venturi effect, a manifestation of the Bernoulli principle.
  • High-velocity oxygen through a narrow jet creates a pressure drop, entraining room air at a fixed ratio, ensuring a precise FiO2, making them fixed-performance devices.

Key takeaway:

The Hudson mask is a variable performance device, not fixed, because FiO2 varies with patient factors (RR, tidal volume).

questions.text: Well-defined lesion in the lung with popcorn calcification on X-ray is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Popcorn calcification on X-ray is seen in pulmonary hamartoma.

Hamartoma

  • Popcorn calcification is seen in pulmonary hamartoma.
  • Popcorn calcificationis defined as a pattern of calcification in rings and arcs that resembles popped corn kernels.
  • The presence of fat in a well-circumscribed solitary pulmonary nodule that does not demonstrate significant growth is pathognomonic of a pulmonary hamartoma.

Chest x-ray showing pulmonary hamartoma:

Explanation of other options:

Hydatid cysts (Option B) result from infection by the Echinococcus species and can result in cyst formation anywhere in the body. Floating membrane Sign/water lily sign/Camalotte sign are commonly seen.

Lung abscess (Option C): Large pulmonary cavity with a small dependent air-fluid level within the cavity.

Lung cancer (Option D) can present with various radiological findings depending on the type and stage, but common features include a focal mass or nodule within the lung parenchyma, irregular margins, associated with bronchial obstruction, and may show invasion into adjacent structures.

choices.text: This condition represents intrusion of aspects of REM sleep into waking state
Deficiency of hypocretin/orexin is commonly found
Modafinil is an FDA approved agent for treatment of this condition

questions.text: A 27-year-old male presented with complaints of non-refreshing sleep and irresistible urge to fall asleep during daytime despite 8-9 hours of night sleep. These sleep attacks would even occur at inappropriate times like during work or even while having a conversation. He frequently has frightening hallucinations while falling asleep at night and also frequently experiences body paralysis in which he awakens unable to move even his eyelids for a few seconds. Which of the following is/are true regarding his condition?
questions.solution:
In the above-mentioned question, the person seems to be having narcolepsy with characteristic features like sleep attacks, sleep paralysis, and hypnagogic hallucinations.

  • Narcolepsy is a condition that represents the intrusion of aspects of REM sleep into the waking state.
  • Sleep attacks: The sleep attacks of narcolepsy represent episodes of irresistible sleepiness → 10 to 20 minutes of sleep → the patient feels refreshed.
  • They can occur at inappropriate times (e.g., while eating, talking or driving and during sex).
  • Hypnagogic and hypnopompic hallucinations: These are vivid perceptual experiences, either auditory or visual, occurring at sleep onset or on awakening.
  • Sleep paralysis: Most often occurring on awakening in the morning; during the episode → awake and conscious → unable to move a muscle.
  • Cataplexy: A sudden loss of muscle tone, such as jaw drop, head drop, weakness of the knees or paralysis of all skeletal muscles with collapse. Strong emotions usually act as the "trigger" for cataplexy.
  • Modafinil, an a1-adrenergic receptor agonist, has been approved by the FDA to reduce the number of sleep attacks and to improve psychomotor performance in narcolepsy.

choices.text: It is characterised by flexion of the upper extremities at the elbow and extensor hyperactivity in the lower extremities
This lesion interrupts all inputs from the rubrospinal tract

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a traumatic upper midbrain transection presents with extensor posturing. Which feature is most characteristic of this lesion?
questions.solution:
A complete transection at the upper midbrain level (around the level of the superior colliculus) results in decerebrate rigidity.

Decerebrate Rigidity:

  • Cause: Lesions at the midbrain level (especially around the superior colliculus) interrupt descending cortical and rubrospinal inputs.
  • Mechanism: Loss of inhibitory (flexor-promoting) signals from the corticospinal and rubrospinal tracts leads to unopposed activity of the vestibulospinal and reticulospinal tracts.
  • Effect: This results in hyperactivity of extensor muscles in all four limbs, producing decerebrate rigidity.

Explanation of Other Options:

Option B: It is characterised by flexion of the upper extremities at the elbow and extensor hyperactivity in the lower extremities

Incorrect because it describes decorticate rigidity, which occurs with lesions above or at the midbrain level (preserving rubrospinal input, which promotes upper limb flexion), whereas a complete upper midbrain transection causes decerebrate rigidity with extensor hyperactivity in all limbs.

Option C: This lesion interrupts all inputs from the rubrospinal tract

This lesion interrupts all inputs from the rubrospinal tract. This is true, as the transection disrupts rubrospinal fibres, contributing to the loss of flexor tone, but the primary clinical feature is decerebrate rigidity.

choices.text: Culture on chocolate agar supplemented with hemin
Culture on a bilayer human blood agar

questions.text: A 44-year-old female complains of lower abdominal pain and vaginal discharge. On examination, there is cervicitis along with a mucopurulent cervical discharge. The Gram smear of the discharge shows the presence of abundant pus cells, but no bacteria. The best approach to isolate the possible causative agent would be:
questions.solution:
Culture on McCoy cells would be the best approach to isolate the possible causative agent, as

  • Patient is complaining of abdominal pain and vaginal discharge.
  • On examination, cervicitis and mucopurulent discharge are seen, which indicates she is having PID.
  • The presence of pus cells in the absence of an organism indicates chlamydial infection, the most common STD nowadays.
  • It is an intracellular organism that grows only on McCoy or HeLa cell cultures.
  • It cannot be grown on other media and hence, often goes unnoticed, later leading to infertility.
  • Culture in McCoy cells is 100% specific for chlamydia, but is inexpensive, technically difficult and takes 3-7 days to obtain the result.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male agricultural worker from Bihar presents with chronic, painless, non-pitting swelling of the lower limbs (elephantiasis), low-grade fever, and recurrent episodes of lymphangitis. A nocturnal peripheral blood smear stained with Giemsa reveals sheathed microfilariae with graceful curves and absence of nuclei at the tail tip. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
• Wuchereria bancrofti is the most common cause of lymphatic filariasis, especially in India.
  • Key morphologic feature: sheathed microfilariae with no nuclei at the tail tip.
  • Clinical presentation: elephantiasis, lymphangitis, fever.
  • Vector: Culex quinquefasciatus (night-biting mosquito).
  • Microfilariae exhibit nocturnal periodicity - detected best in night-time peripheral smear.
  • Adults lodge in lymphatic channels → chronic lymphatic obstruction.


Key Takeaways:

  • Wuchereria bancrofti is the major cause of lymphatic filariasis in India.
  • Diagnosis relies on morphologic features + nocturnal smear.
  • Tail nuclei pattern and sheath presence help differentiate filarial species.
  • WHO strategies include DEC + Albendazole mass drug administration to control transmission.

choices.text: Half the substrate concentration is required for Vmax

questions.text: Km is the substrate concentration at which:
questions.solution:
The Michaelis-Menten equation mathematically describes the relationship between the initial reaction velocity (vi) and substrate concentration ([S]). The Michaelis constant (Km) is specifically defined as the substrate concentration at which the initial reaction velocity (vi) is exactly half the maximal velocity (Vmax/2) that can be achieved by the enzyme at a given concentration. This value is an inverse measure of the enzyme's affinity for its substrate; a lower Kmindicates a higher affinity.

Explanation of Other Options:

Half the substrate concentration is required for Vmax (Option A): This statement is incorrect. Km relates to the velocity, not directly to the substrate concentration needed for the entire Vmax. Vmax is achieved at very high substrate concentrations, effectively saturating the enzyme.

Vmax is achieved (Option B): This is incorrect. Vmax is approached as substrate concentration becomes very high (saturating), not specifically at Km. At Km, the velocity is half Vmax.

Quarter the Vmax is achieved (Option =C): This is incorrect. The definition of Km explicitly states that it is the substrate concentration at which half the Vmax is achieved.

Key Takeaway:

The Michaelis constant (Km) is a fundamental parameter in enzyme kinetics, precisely defined as the substrate concentration at which the enzyme reaction rate is half its maximal velocity (Vmax/2), and it inversely reflects the enzyme's affinity for its substrate.

Explanation:

The Michaelis-Menten equation illustrates in mathematical terms the relationship between initial reaction velocity vi and substrate concentration [S].

The Michaelis constant Km is the substrate concentration at which vi is half the maximal velocity (Vmax/2) attainable at a particular concentration of the enzyme.

questions.text: Which of the following bones forms the marked foramen ?
questions.solution:
The marked foramen is foramen lacerum which is formed by temporal , sphenoid and occipital bones.


  • The foramen lacerum (Latin: lacerated piercing) is a triangular hole in the base of skull. It is located between 3 bones:
    • Sphenoid bone(forming the anterior border)
    • Apex of petrous part of temporal bone (forming the posterolateral border)
    • Basilar part of occipital bone (forming the posteromedial border)
  • It is the junction point of 3 sutures of the skull:
    • Petroclival (petro occipital) suture
    • Sphenopetrosal suture
    • Spheno Occipital suture

questions.text: A Puff of smoke appearance on cerebral angiography is seen in?
questions.solution:
• Moya Moyà disease is an idiopathic, non-inflammatory, non-atherosclerotic progressive vasculo-occlusive disease involving the circle of Willis, typically the supraclinoid internal carotid arteries, resulting in small abnormal net-like vessels giving a characteristic 'puff of smoke' appearance on MRA.
  • Moyamoya disease is a chronic, progressive cerebrovascular disorder characterised by the stenosis or occlusion of arteries at the base of the brain, particularly the internal carotid arteries and their major branches.
  • In response to this occlusion, a network of tiny blood vessels forms to compensate for the reduced blood flow.
  • These collateral vessels appear as a 'puff of smoke' (resembling the Japanese word 'moyamoya') on angiographic imaging, which is diagnostic of this condition.

Explanation of other options:

ACA aneurysm (Option A): An aneurysm in the anterior cerebral artery does not create the puff of smoke appearance.


Cavernous sinus thrombosis (Option B): This condition involves clot formation within the cavernous sinus and would not produce the characteristic collateral vessel network seen in Moyamoya disease.


Vein of Galen malformation (Option D): This is a type of arteriovenous malformation involving the vein of Galen and typically shows a different pattern of abnormal vascular connections.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with shortness of breath and weakness. A 12-lead electrocardiogram shows a rate of 42 beats per minute with complete dissociation of P waves from QRS complexes. What is the most likely jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform that will be seen?
questions.solution:
• In the above case, there is complete dissociation of P waves from QRS complex that suggests AV dissociation and Heart block.
  • Cannon A waves are caused by atrial contraction against a closed tricuspid valve, such as in complete heart block.
  • JVP- Pressure of the venous column of blood in the Right Internal Jugular Vein.

Different waves in JVP:

  • A wave produced by right atrial contraction.
  • The C wave is produced during the ventricular systole.
  • X wave represents the fall in right atrial pressure after a wave peak.
  • The wave represents venous return to the right column.
  • Y descent represents the opening of the tricuspid valve.
  • Elevated JVP (>4 cm above the sternal angle) with normal waveforms may reflect right heart failure and fluid overload.
  • Elevated JVP with absent waveforms may be caused by superior vena cava obstruction.
  • Elevated JVP with deep x and y descents may be seen with constrictive pericarditis.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Absent JVP(Option A): may be present in patients who are intravascularly depleted

Absent a waves(Option B): may be seen in atrial fibrillation

Large v waves(Option C) are a feature of tricuspid regurgitation

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with a history of systemic sclerosis presents with exertional dyspnea, fatigue, and chest discomfort. On physical examination, she has accentuated P2 and a tricuspid regurgitant murmur. Echocardiography reveals an elevated right ventricular systolic pressure and a dilated right ventricle. The radiograph and pulmonary angiogram are givenbelow. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The given images show prominence of the central pulmonary artery with peripheral hypovascularity, depicting pulmonary hypertension.
  • In the angiogram, the classical prune tree appearancecan also be seen.
  • All these radiological findings are consistent with the given presentation of the patient suffering from PAH.

The plain radiograph findings in Pulmonary artery hypertension include:

  • Elevated cardiac apex due to right ventricular hypertrophy
  • Enlarged right atrium
  • Prominent pulmonary outflow tract
  • Enlarged pulmonary arteries
  • Pruning of peripheral pulmonary vessels

Explanation of other options:

Sarcoidosis (Option B) shows the bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, not the prune tree appearance.

Pneumothorax (Option C) will show absence of bronchovascular markings and deep sulcus sign, not the prune tree appearance.


Pulmonary thromboembolism (Option D) will show its typical signs, Palla's sign and westermark sign and Hampton's hump not the prune tree appearance.

questions.text: A 34-year-old mother of two children has been suffering from amenorrhea for the last 12 months. She has a history of failure of lactation following second delivery but remained asymptomatic thereafter. Skull X-ray shows empty sella diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Empty Sella:

  • Congenital incompleteness of the sellar diaphragm.
  • Secondary to surgery/radiotherapy or infarction of pituitary tumor.
  • Secondary to infarction and necrosis of pituitary gland.

Now from the given causes:

  • either pituitary tumor or Sheehan's syndrome can cause an empty sella on X-ray.
  • Pituitary tumours (micro/macroadenoma) are prolactin secreting tumors and hence, cause galactorrhea (not lactational failure) with amenorrhea and are ruled out.
  • So, the obvious answer by exclusion is Sheehan's Syndrome.

Sheehan's syndrome:

  • It is the syndrome which results from ischemic necrosis of most of the anterior pituitary due to spasm in its arterioles occurring at the time of severe hemorrhage or shock, complicating childbirth.

choices.text: Hypnozoites are seen in the liver

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with fever, chills, and rigors for 2 days. Peripheral smear shows ring forms and banana-shaped gametocytes. The infected RBCs are of normal size and contain Maurer's clefts. Which of the following statements is true about the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
• Ring forms and banana-shaped gametocytes are characteristic.
  • Normal-sized RBCs with Maurer's clefts confirm the species.
  • It causes malignant tertian malaria with fever spikes every 48 hours.
  • No hypnozoite stage, so no relapse occurs.

P. falciparum infects RBCs of all ages and is associated with severe complications, including cerebral malaria, renal failure, and blackwater fever.

questions.text: A patient presents with scapular winging visible at rest, without active arm movement. Physical examination shows the medial border of the scapula is displaced laterally and inferiorly (as shown in the image), but there is no prominence during forward arm flexion. Which nerve is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Scapular winging visible at rest, with no prominence during forward arm flexion, is caused by the dorsal scapular nerve injury.

Dorsal Scapular Nerve (C5)

  • The dorsal scapular nerve arises from the C5 root of the brachial plexus and innervates the rhomboid major, rhomboid minor, and levator scapulae muscles.
  • These muscles function primarily to retract (adduct) and elevate the scapula.
  • When this nerve is injured, the rhomboids become weak or paralysed, resulting in the medial border of the scapula drifting laterally.
  • This causes winging of the scapula at rest, without the need for active movement.
  • The patient may experience difficulty retracting the scapula.

Explanation for other options:

Long Thoracic Nerve (C5-C7) (Option A):

  • The long thoracic nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, which holds the scapula tightly against the thoracic wall during upper limb movements, particularly flexion and overhead reaching.
  • Injury to this nerve causes the classic form of scapular winging, characterised by the medial border of the scapula protruding posteriorly when the patient attempts to push against resistance.

Spinal Accessory Nerve (Cranial Nerve XI) (Option C):

  • The spinal accessory nerve supplies the trapezius muscle, which plays a crucial role in elevating the shoulder and rotating the scapula during arm abduction above 90 degrees.
  • Damage to this nerve results in shoulder drooping, difficulty elevating the arm, and, in some cases, mild winging of the scapula.
  • The winging tends to be secondary and is more noticeable during shoulder movement, not typically at rest.

Axillary Nerve (C5-C6) (Option D):

  • The axillary nerve innervates the deltoid and teres minor muscles, both of which are involved in shoulder abduction and external rotation, respectively.
  • Injury to this nerve impairs abduction beyond the first 15 degrees (initiated by the supraspinatus), but it does not affect scapular position or stability.

questions.text: The photosensitive material used in X-ray films consists of:
questions.solution:
The photosensitive material used in X-ray films primarily consists of silver bromide.

  • X-ray films are coated with a layer of silver halide crystals, predominantly silver bromide.
  • When X-rays pass through the body, they expose these silver bromide crystals in proportion to the amount of X-rays reaching the film.
  • After exposure, the film undergoes chemical development processes where the exposed silver bromide crystals are reduced to metallic silver, which forms the blackening effect seen in the final X-ray image.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Lithium Fluoride (Option A) & Calcium sulphate (Option D): These materials are used in Thermoluminescent Dosimeters (TLD badges), which measure radiation exposure, but they are not used in X-ray films.
  • Zinc sulphide (Option C): Zinc sulphide is not used in X-ray films as the primary photosensitive material, unlike silver bromide, which is.

Key Takeaway:

The core photosensitive component of traditional X-ray films is silver bromide, which undergoes chemical changes upon X-ray exposure to form the radiographic image.

questions.text: Identify the tumour shown in the X-ray image?
questions.solution:
• GCT The X-ray depicts the diagnostic Soap bubble appearance of a Giant cell tumour, which is one of the commonest tumours to be seen in the distal end of the radius.
  • However, the commonest sites for the GCT per se are: Distal femur, Proximal tibia, Distal radius.

Giant cell tumour:

  • AGE (YR): 20-40 Slight female predominance
  • SITE: Distal femur>Proximal tibia>Distal radius
  • PRESENTATION: Pain, Pathologic fracture(10%-30%), Eggshell cracking sound on tapping the lesion is heard

IMAGING:

  • Eccentrically located in the epiphysis
  • Purely radiolucent(no matrix formation), Soap bubble appearance
  • Usually, no rim of reactive bone
  • Abuts subchondral bone
  • May exhibit cortical destruction with soft tissue extension
  • Metaphyseal in skeletally immature patients

HISTOLOGY:

  • Multinucleated giant cells in a sea of mononuclear cells
  • Nuclei of mononuclear cells are identical to nuclei of giant cells

TREATMENT:

  • Extended curettage, Resection if residual bone stock is inadequate
  • Consider radiation for spinal/sacral tumours, Resection of pulmonary metastases

Explanation of other options:

Aneurysmal bone cyst (Option A): Lytic expansile lesion in metaphysis with fluid-fluid levels on imaging, not typically epiphyseal.

Osteosarcoma (Option B): Malignant metaphyseal tumour with sunburst periosteal reaction, Codman triangle-not soap-bubble.

Simple bone cyst (Option D): Central metaphyseal lesion in children, usually the humerus or femur, with the fallen fragment sign, not eccentric or epiphyseal.

Key Takeaway:

A soap-bubble appearance in the epiphysis of the distal radius in a young adult points toward a giant cell tumour.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl presents with fever, sore throat, malaise and vesicles on the hands, feet, and painful oral ulcers. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
• Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common viral illness usually affecting infants and children under 10 years.
  • HFMD involves the hands, feet, and mouth. Vesicles are surrounded by a thin halo of erythema, eventually rupturing and forming superficial ulcers with a grey-yellow base and erythematous rim.
  • Cause: MC - coxsackievirus A16 and enterovirus71 in most cases, many other strains of coxsackievirus.
  • Spread - oral ingestion of the shed virus from the gastrointestinal or upper respiratory tract of infected hosts or via vesicle fluid or oral secretions.
  • Treatment is mostly supportive and symptomatic. In severe cases, if neurological complications occur, intravenous immunoglobulin is advisable.

Explanation of other options:

  • Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV-1)(Option A) can cause herpetic gingivostomatitis, which affects the mouth only, no rash on hands/feet.
  • Parvovirus B19 infection(Option B): Causes erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), not HFMD. Presents with a "slapped cheek" rash and lacy exanthem on the trunk and limbs.
  • Epstein-Barr virus infection(Option D): Causes infectious mononucleosis, with pharyngitis, lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly, but no vesicular rash on hands/feet.

questions.text: Tay-Sachs disease is due to the accumulation of:
questions.solution:
• Tay-Sachs disease is caused by a deficiency of the Hexosaminidase A
  • This leads to the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside in neuronal cells.
  • Clinical features include mental retardation, blindness, and muscular weakness.

Explanation of other options:

GM1 ganglioside (Option B): Accumulates in GM1 gangliosidosis, not Tay-Sachs disease.

Glucocerebroside (Option C): Accumulates in Gaucher's disease due to beta-glucocerebrosidase deficiency.

Galactocerebroside (Option D): Accumulates in Krabbe's disease due to galactocerebrosidase deficiency.

questions.text: A 16-year-old student is studying the physiology of vision. He learns that the retina contains several types of neurons that contribute to visual processing. Which of the following retinal cells is primarily responsible for enhancing contrast in the visual image?All of the following cells are found in the retina. Which of the following does enhance contrast?
questions.solution:
Ganglion cells are the final output neurons of the retina. They receive input from bipolar and amacrine cells and transmit visual signals to the brain via their axons, which form the optic nerve.

Importantly, some types of ganglion cells are involved in enhancing visual contrast through center-surround receptive fields:

  • These receptive fields have a central area and a surrounding area that respond oppositely to light.
  • This lateral inhibition mechanism helps the retina detect edges and contrast, allowing the brain to distinguish objects more clearly in various lighting conditions.

Thus, ganglion cells play a direct role in contrast enhancement and spatial resolution.

  • In the layer of retina, we find horizontal cells, bipolar cells, amacrine cells and ganglion cells apart from photoreceptor cells.
  • All the above cells except ganglion cells expand their processes on lateral sides providing lateral inhibition. Lateral inhibition helps in enhancing the contrast in vision.

Ganglionic cells are of three types

X cells - for Fine details of visual image transmission

Y cells - Respond to rapid changes in visual image

W cells - Sensitive for detecting directional movements in the field of vision

Explanation of other options:

Horizontal cells (Option A):

These cells modulate the signals between photoreceptors and bipolar cells and are involved in lateral inhibition, but their main role is in adjusting sensitivity to light and maintaining visual stability in varying illumination. They contribute indirectly to contrast but are not the primary cells responsible for contrast enhancement.

Bipolar cells (Option B):

These act as interneurons connecting photoreceptors to ganglion cells. They relay signals but are not directly involved in processing contrast or creating center-surround receptive fields.

Amacrine cells (Option D):

These cells operate at the level of bipolar to ganglion cell synapses, modulating signal timing and playing roles in motion detection and temporal sensitivity, but they do not primarily enhance spatial contrast

KEY TAKE AWAY

Following image shows a mechanism of lateral inhibition that occurs at horizontal cell, amacrine cell and bipolar cell level.

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant is brought to the clinic for a routine check-up. The mother reports that the child is able to sit without support, creep on all fours, and pull himself up to stand using furniture, but has not yet started to walk independently. Which of the following developmental abilities is most appropriate for his age?
questions.solution:
Developmental Milestone: Gross Motor Skill (10 Months)

  • At 10 months, the typical gross motor milestones include:
    • Sitting without support
    • Creeping (abdomen off ground)
    • Pulling to stand using furniture
    • Walking independently is expected only between 13-15 months, so its absence at 10 months is normal.

Core Concepts of Development:

  • Development begins in utero and continues to maturity.
  • Milestone sequence is constant; timing may vary.
  • Development follows three main principles:
    • Cephalocaudal: Head-to-toe (e.g., head control → trunk → legs).
    • Proximal to distal: Midline to periphery (e.g., arm → hand → fingers).
    • Neurological maturation: Myelination and CNS maturity are prerequisites for skill acquisition.
  • >80% brain development occurs in the first 3 years.

Domains of Development & Key Milestones:





Factors Influencing Development

A. Biological & Genetic

  • Genetics: Inherited disorders (e.g., Down, Turner syndrome).
  • Maternal health: Poor nutrition, infections (rubella), drug exposure.
  • Perinatal: Prematurity, SGA, birth asphyxia, jaundice.
  • Nutrition: Deficiencies (e.g., iodine, vitamin A/D).
  • Infections: Chronic (e.g., HIV, malaria, meningitis).
  • Toxins: Lead, mercury, arsenic exposure.
  • Brain insults: TBI, encephalitis.
  • Sensory deficits: Vision/hearing impairments.

B. Psychosocial & Environmental

  • Parenting quality: Responsiveness, warmth.
  • Socioeconomic status: Poverty affects nutrition, stimulation.
  • Emotional environment: Insecurity, stress impacts growth hormones.
  • Abuse: Psychological trauma.
  • Institutional care: Risk for attachment, emotional issues.

Assessment & Delays:

  • Developmental surveillance: Regular monitoring during health visits.
  • Developmental screening: Brief, standardised tools to detect delays.

Developmental Quotient (DQ):

  • DQ = (Developmental Age / Chronological Age) × 100
  • DQ < 70 → warrants full evaluation



Early Intervention:

  • Goal: Maximise potential in children with delays.
  • Services: Special education, speech therapy, occupational/physical therapy.
  • Importance: Early detection and treatment lead to better outcomes.

questions.text:
A chronic hypertensive patient shows the following finding on retinoscopic examination (arrow):

What is the grade of hypertensive retinopathy in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given fundus image shows hard exudates arranged in a macular star pattern

Grade 3 Hypertensive Retinopathy is characterised by:

  • All Grade 2 features (focal narrowing, AV nipping, copper wiring)
  • Retinal haemorrhages (dot, blot, flame-shaped).
  • Exudates: Chronic retinal oedema can lead to hard exudates arranged in a macular star pattern (as seen in the image).
  • Cotton-wool spots (soft exudates).

Explanation of Incorrect Options:


Grade 1 (Option A):

  • Grade 1 only has mild generalised arteriolar narrowing without haemorrhages, exudates, or macular star.

Grade 2 (Option B):

  • Grade 2 includes focal narrowing, AV nipping, and copper wiring, but does not have haemorrhages or exudates.

Grade 4 (Option C):

  • Grade 4 is characterised by optic disc swelling (papilledema) in addition to Grade 3 changes, seen in malignant hypertension.

questions.text: Primary amenorrhea with absent uterus, normal breasts and scanty pubic hair is seen in:
questions.solution: • The patient is presenting with primary amenorrhea along with well developed breast and scanty pubic hair and axillary hair -leave no doubt regarding Testicular feminisation syndrome as the diagnosis, which c/k/a AIS (Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome)

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with tinea corporis. A KOH mount and subsequent culture reveal thin-walled, pencil-shaped macroconidia and numerous small, unicellular microconidia. Which of the following is the most likely dermatophyte responsible?
questions.solution:
• Thin-walled, pencil-shaped macroconidia
  • Numerous small unicellular microconidia

These features are classic for Trichophyton, a dermatophyte that commonly causes tinea corporis (ringworm of the body). Trichophyton commonly causes tinea corporis, tinea capitis, onychomycosis, etc.

Dermatophytes:

Dermatophytes are fungi that infect keratinised tissues (skin, hair, nails). They are classified into three major genera based on microscopic morphology:


These fungi form two types of asexual spores which help in identification:

1.Macroconidia

  • Larger spores
  • Multicellular
  • Shape and wall thickness vary by genus

2. Microconidia

  • Smaller spores
  • Often unicellular
  • Number and arrangement help differentiate
