Candida albicans (Option D): Candida is a yeast, not a dermatophyte. It forms pseudohyphae, germ tubes, and chlamydospores, not macro/microconidia like dermatophytes.

Key Takeaways:

Dermatophytes Identification:

  • Trichophyton: Infects skin, hair, nails. Macroconidia: few, thin pencil-shaped. Microconidia: numerous.
  • Microsporum: Infects skin and hair. Macroconidia: large, spindle-shaped. Microconidia: scanty.
  • Epidermophyton: Infects skin and nails. Macroconidia: pear-shaped clusters. Microconidia: absent.

questions.text: A patient was stabbed 23 times. One such stab wound was present in the left supraclavicular fossa, piercing his left lung. Which of the following provides the vertebral attachment to the fascia present here?
questions.solution:
• The suprapleural membrane (Sibson's fascia) reinforces the apex of the lung and covers the cupola of the pleura
  • This fascia extends from the transverse process of C7 vertebra to the inner border of the first rib, providing structural support (Option C is correct)
  • C5 and C6 are too superior and do not serve as the direct attachment site for the suprapleural membrane (Options A and B ruled out)
  • C8 is part of the brachial plexus roots but does not serve as the anchoring vertebral level for this fascia (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Suprapleural membrane (Sibson's fascia) is anchored to C7 transverse process
  • It provides apical pleura protection and may be pierced in penetrating trauma to the supraclavicular fossa.

questions.text: Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome is associated with all of the following infections except:
questions.solution:
Syphilis is not associated with Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.

Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome (FHCS) is perihepatitis associated with pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

  • It most commonly occurs as a complication of PID caused by Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. (Options B & C ruled out)
  • It presents with right upper quadrant pain due to inflammation of the liver capsule (not the parenchyma), often with "violin string" adhesions between the liver capsule and anterior abdominal wall.
  • Genital tuberculosis may rarely cause similar perihepatic adhesions. (Option D ruled out)
  • Diagnosis: Laparoscopy (gold standard) shows violin-string adhesions.

choices.text: Decrease the risk of venous thromboembolism
Increase the risk of breakthrough bleeding
Are not used for emergency contraception

questions.text: Third-generation oral contraceptive pills containing norgestimate and gestodene, along with estrogens:
questions.solution:
Third-generation oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) contain newer progestins like norgestimate, gestodene, and desogestrel, combined with ethinyl estradiol (an estrogen). These formulations were developed to improve metabolic profiles and reduce androgenic side effects compared to earlier generations.

Third-generation progestins have minimal androgenic activity.

They have a better effect on lipid metabolism:

  • Increase HDL (good cholesterol)
  • Lower LDL (bad cholesterol)
  • Minimal impact on triglycerides.

Hence, they are considered more lipid-friendly compared to second-generation progestins (like levonorgestrel).

Explanation of incorrect options:

Decrease the risk of thromboembolism (Option B):

Third-generation OCPs do not decrease the risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE). They have been associated with a higher risk of VTE compared to second-generation pills (e.g., those containing levonorgestrel). This is due to their stronger estrogenic effects on hepatic coagulation factors, leading to increased clotting risk.

Increase the risk of breakthrough bleeding (Option C):

Third-generation pills typically offer better cycle control and are less androgenic, which tends to reduce rather than increase the incidence of breakthrough bleeding. Breakthrough bleeding is more common with low-dose or irregular use of OCPs, not specifically due to third-generation progestins.

Are not used for emergency contraception (Option D):

While they are not the first choice, some combined oral contraceptives-including those with third-generation progestins-can be used for emergency contraception using the Yuzpe method (multiple pills taken at specific intervals). However, dedicated emergency contraception pills like levonorgestrel-only or ulipristal are preferred.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with known gallstones presents with acute severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, accompanied by vomiting. Laboratory tests confirm acute pancreatitis. Which on admission finding is a component of the updated Ranson criteria for gallstone-induced acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
• The Ranson criteria are a set of clinical and biochemical parameters used to predict severity and mortality risk in acute pancreatitis.
  • They include parameters at admission and at 48 hours.
  • For gallstone-induced pancreatitis, the admission criteria include AST >250 IU/L, which reflects hepatocellular injury and biliary obstruction, common in this etiology.

Ranson Criteria

A score ≥3 indicates severe pancreatitis.

Why Ranson Criteria fit this condition-

  • Condition: Acute gallstone-induced pancreatitis.
  • Gallstones obstruct the ampulla → bile reflux into the pancreatic duct → premature activation of enzymes → local and systemic inflammation.
  • Biliary obstruction also injures hepatocytes, raising AST and bilirubin.
  • Ranson criteria quantify both initial injury and ongoing systemic effects to estimate prognosis and guide care.

Age >55 years (Option A): This threshold applies to non-gallstone (alcohol-related) pancreatitis. In gallstone-induced pancreatitis, the correct age cutoff is >70 years, making this incorrect.

Serum calcium >8 mg/dL (Option C): High calcium is normal. In pancreatitis, low calcium (<8 mg/dL) at 48 hours (due to fat necrosis and saponification) predicts severity. A value >8 mg/dL is not part of the criteria.

Blood glucose >200 mg/dL (Option D): The correct admission threshold for gallstone-induced pancreatitis is >220 mg/dL. A value >200 mg/dL applies to non-gallstone pancreatitis, so this is incorrect.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child with medulloblastoma is being considered for a specialised form of radiotherapy that minimises radiation to surrounding healthy brain tissue. The oncologist explains that this technique relies on the Bragg peak phenomenon. Which type of radiation exhibits the Bragg peak, delivering maximal energy deposition at a specific depth within tissues?
questions.solution:
Protons exhibit a Bragg peak.

  • The proton is a heavy and charged particle that gradually loses its speed as it interacts with human tissue. It is easily controlled and delivers its maximum dose at a precise depth and can go as far as 32 cm.
  • The absorbed dose increases very gradually with greater depth and lower speed, suddenly rising to a peak when the proton is ultimately stopped. This is known as the Bragg Peak.
  • The behaviour of the proton can be precisely determined, and the beam directed to the Bragg peak occurs exactly within the tumour site. Immediately after this burst of energy, the proton completely stops to irradiate and the particles come to rest.
  • Proton therapy, therefore, allows for targeting tumours inside the body, precisely localising the radiation dosage and sparing the patient's healthy cells, offering a much less invasive alternative to treat cancer.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia consistently uses the term "cyana-pi" without being able to define or elaborate on its meaning. Additionally, when referring to a "wristwatch," he frequently uses the phrase "time vessel." Based on these speech patterns, what two specific features of formal thought disorder are best exemplified by this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
• The patient's use of "cyana-pi" exemplifies a neologism, which is a newly coined, non-existent, and often meaningless word invented by the individual.
  • The inability to explain it further reinforces this. His description of a "wristwatch" as a "time vessel" is a classic example of a metonym, where an unusual, symbolic, or indirectly associated term is used to refer to a common object or concept instead of its direct name.
  • Both neologisms and metonyms are recognized forms of formal thought disorder frequently observed in schizophrenia, particularly in its paranoid presentation.

Explanation of Other Options:

Neologism and Circumstantiality disorder (Option A): While "cyana-pi" fits neologism, circumstantiality involves excessive and unnecessary detail in speech before eventually returning to the main point. The patient's inability to "reach a conclusion" for "cyana-pi" doesn't align with the characteristic "returning to the point" of circumstantiality.

Tangentiality and Circumstantiality (Option B): Tangentiality describes speech that repeatedly veers off-topic and never returns to the original point, which could partially explain the inability to explain "cyana-pi." However, there is no indication of circumstantiality (roundabout but eventually relevant responses), and the core features of "cyana-pi" and "time vessel" are specifically neologism and metonymy.

Incoherence and Flight of ideas (Option D): Incoherence (also known as "word salad") implies a complete lack of logical or understandable connections between thoughts, making speech virtually incomprehensible. Flight of ideas involves rapidly shifting from one topic to another with superficial associations, typically seen in manic episodes. The patient's speech, while distorted in word choice, is not described as completely unintelligible or rapidly shifting between unrelated topics in the manner of incoherence or flight of ideas. The examples provided suggest structured but altered word usage.

Key Takeaways:

  • Formal thought disorder (FTD) is a hallmark symptom of schizophrenia, manifesting as disorganised thinking patterns reflected in speech.
  • Neologisms are newly invented words without meaning to others.
  • Metonyms involve using indirect or symbolic substitutions for common words or concepts.

choices.text: Café au lait macules measuring 3 mm

questions.text: A 9-year-old child presents with multiple hyperpigmented macules over the trunk and freckling in the axillary region. Ophthalmological examination reveals Lisch nodules on slit lamp examination. Which of the following additional findings would best support a diagnosis of Neurofibromatosis Type 1?
questions.solution:
This is a major diagnostic criterion for Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1). It is a classical osseous abnormality seen in NF1 and helps confirm the diagnosis when present alongside other features such as:

  • ≥6 café-au-lait macules (>5 mm in prepubertal children or >15 mm post-puberty) (Option C ruled out)
  • Axillary/inguinal freckling
  • Lisch nodules (iris hamartomas) (Option D ruled out)
  • Neurofibromas
  • Family history

Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1):

  • Common inherited neurocutaneous disorder
  • Autosomal dominant inheritance
  • 100% penetrance: All individuals with mutation express the disorder
  • Mutation: NF1 gene (chromosome 17)

Other Clinical Features:

  • Eye: Optic glioma, Lisch nodules
  • Bone: Sphenoid wing dysplasia, cortical thinning of long bones
  • Genetics: Autosomal dominant with variable expressivity

Management:

  • Observation: Most cases are benign
  • Surgery: For symptomatic or malignant neurofibromas

Bilateral vestibular schwannomas (Option A) is pathognomonic for Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (NF2), not NF1.

choices.text: Anticipated prolonged operative time due to complex injuries
Extensive abdominal trauma involving multiple organs
Serum lactate trending down and currently <2 mmol/L

questions.text: A middle-aged male presents following high-speed blunt trauma and is found to have multiple intra-abdominal injuries with significant hemorrhage. During evaluation, he is noted to be acidotic, hypothermic, and coagulopathic. He has already undergone substantial blood transfusion. In considering the next surgical step, which of the following parameters would argue against initiating a damage control surgical strategy?
questions.solution:
• Damage Control Surgery (DCS) is employed in trauma patients with critical injuries who are at risk of death if subjected to prolonged definitive surgery.
  • A key determinant is the physiological reserve of the patient - markers of inadequate perfusion such as lactate >5 mmol/L signal the need for abbreviated surgery.
  • Conversely, a serum lactate <2 mmol/L suggests adequate tissue perfusion and does not warrant DCS.

Stages and Phases of Damage Control Surgery

Indications for Damage Control Surgery

Anatomical factors

  • Uncontrollable hemorrhage despite efforts
  • Extensive injury to critical organs (e.g., liver, pancreas)
  • Combined injuries involving vessels, solid and hollow organs (e.g., aorta, vena cava)
  • Venous injuries in inaccessible regions (e.g., retrohepatic vena cava)
  • Anticipated excessively long operation due to injury complexity
  • Requirement to prioritize non-operative management of other major injuries (e.g., pelvis)

Physiological factors (reflecting exhausted reserve)

  • Hypothermia: temperature <34°C
  • Acidosis: pH <7.2
  • Hyperlactatemia: lactate >5 mmol/L (normal <2.5)
  • Coagulopathy: PT >16 sec, PTT >60 sec
  • Massive transfusion requirements (~15 units)
  • Persistent hypotension: systolic BP <90 mmHg for >60 min

Environmental factors

  • Prolonged operative time (>60 minutes)
  • Inability to safely close the abdomen at initial operation
  • Need for planned relook to reassess intra-abdominal injuries

Persistent inability to control hemorrhage (Option A): This is a clear anatomical indication for DCS because it reflects an immediate threat to life that cannot be controlled with standard surgery.

Anticipated prolonged operative time due to complex injuries (Option B): This is an anatomical/environmental indication, as prolonged operations in unstable patients increase mortality risk.

Extensive abdominal trauma involving multiple organs (Option C): This is an anatomical indication, especially when multiple critical organs are injured and cannot all be definitively repaired in one sitting.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with a history of severe COPD and reduced exercise tolerance is posted for a short, elective transurethral procedure under general anesthesia. He has a baseline SpO2 of 91% on room air and mild CO2 retention on ABG. To minimize postoperative respiratory depression and ensure rapid recovery with early discharge, which inhalational agent, owing to its lowest blood-gas partition coefficient, would be the most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Xenon possesses the lowest blood-gas partition coefficient (~0.115) among all inhaled anesthetics, resulting in extremely rapid onset and offset. This makes it ideal for patients with limited pulmonary reserve, like those with COPD, where minimizing anesthetic-induced respiratory depression and ensuring quick emergence are crucial for safety and discharge.

Explanation of other options:

Methoxyflurane (Option A): Extremely high solubility (~12); slow recovery and nephrotoxic-obsolete.

Desflurane (Option B): Fast acting with low solubility (~0.42) but slower than xenon; also an airway irritant.

Nitrous oxide (Option C): Faster than most agents (~0.47), but still slower than xenon.

Key Takeaways:

Xenon provides the fastest recovery due to its lowest solubility; ideal for COPD and short-duration surgeries.

questions.text: At the end of the third week, somites begin to develop along the notochord and neural tube. What do they end up forming?
questions.solution:
• Paraxial mesoderm that forms along the notochord and neural tube divides and forms paired cuboidal bodies called somites starting in week three.
  • They develop in a caudal direction from day 20-30 and give rise to most of the axial skeleton (skull base, vertebral column, ribs, and sternum), all skeletal musculature, and the dermis of the skin.
  • They are critical in the segmentation and development of the embryo.
  • Somites differentiate into three major components:

Explanation of Other Options:

Brain (Option B): Develops from the anterior neural tube, not somites.

Spinal cord (Option C): Arises from the neural tube, not somites.

Sympathetic chain ganglia (Option D): Derive from neural crest cells, not from somites.

choices.text: Glucokinase, Pyruvate Kinase, Glyceraldehyde 3 Phosphate Dehydrogenase
Hexokinase, Phospho Glycerate Kinase, Pyruvate Kinase

questions.text: Irreversible steps of Glycolysis are catalysed by:
questions.solution:
Only three steps in glycolysis are physiologically irreversible, and they serve as key regulatory points.

Irreversible Steps & Their Enzymes:

  • Hexokinase (or Glucokinase in the liver):
    • Converts Glucose → Glucose-6-phosphate
    • ATP-dependent phosphorylation (irreversible)
  • Phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1):
    • Converts Fructose-6-phosphate → Fructose-1,6-bisphosphate
    • The major rate-limiting enzyme of glycolysis
    • Highly regulated (by ATP, AMP, citrate)
  • Pyruvate Kinase:
    • Converts Phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP) → Pyruvate
    • Final ATP-yielding step in glycolysis
    • Irreversible under cellular conditions

Explanation of other options

Glucokinase, Pyruvate Kinase, Glyceraldehyde 3 Phosphate Dehydrogenase (Option A): Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase is a reversible enzyme.

Hexokinase, Phospho Glycerate Kinase, Pyruvate Kinase(Option C): Phosphoglycerate kinase catalyzes a reversible step.

Pyruvate Kinase, Fructose 1, 6 Bisphosphatase, Phosphofructokinase (Option D): Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase is a gluconeogenic enzyme, not part of glycolysis.

questions.text: The bithermal caloric test is done to check the function of
questions.solution:
Fitzgerald Bithermal Caloric Test: This is a Test for the lateral Semicircular Canal (aka Horizontal SCC)

Steps-

  • Patient is lying supine with the head lifted 30° (This brings lateral SCC in a vertical plane).
  • EAC is irrigated with Warm (44°C) and Cold (30°C) water.
  • This will produce nystagmus (Note the latency, duration, (direction) in all normal people.
  • With cold water stimulation, the eyes move towards the opposite side.
  • With warm water stimulation, the eyes move towards the side.

questions.text: Not a symptom of inorganic chronic lead poisoning is:
questions.solution:
Diarrhoea is not a symptom of inorganic chronic lead poisoning.

Signs & symptoms of chronic lead poisoning:

(Mnemonic: ABCDEFGHI)

  1. Anaemia/Anorexia/Arthralgia/Abortion/Atrophy of optic nerve
  2. Basophilic stippling/Burton's line
  3. Colic/Constipation/Cerebral edema
  4. Drop (wrist, foot)
  5. Encephalopathy/Emaciation/Erectile dysfunction
  6. Facial pallor/Foul smell of breath/Fanconi syndrome
  7. Gonadal dysfunction/Gout-like picture (Saturnine gout)
  8. Hypertension/Headache/Hallucination
  9. Infertility/Insomnia/Irritability
  • Pain areas: In the abdomen or joints
  • Gastrointestinal: Constipation,nausea, or vomiting
  • Developmental: Learning disability or slow growth
  • Whole body: Fatigue or loss of appetite
  • Behavioural: Hyperactivity or irritability
  • Also common: Baby colic, headache, insomnia, or memory loss

Explanation of other options:

Constipation (Option A): Classical symptom due to autonomic nervous dysfunction.

Insomnia (Option B): Common neuropsychiatric manifestation.

Anorexia (Option D): Frequently reported in chronic exposure.

Key Takeaway:

Constipation, not diarrhoea, is a hallmark gastrointestinal symptom in chronic lead poisoning.

questions.text: A 42-year-old renal transplant recipient presents with fever, malaise, and rising serum creatinine. Urinalysis shows haematuria and viral PCR is positive. Renal biopsy reveals enlarged cells with large basophilic intra-nuclear inclusions and small cytoplasmic granules. What is the most characteristic histological finding in this condition?
questions.solution:
• The patient is immunocompromised (post-transplant), which makes them more prone to opportunistic viral infections.
  • They have kidney involvement and the virus is confirmed by PCR.
  • Biopsy shows large, basophilic (blue-staining) inclusions inside the nucleus, which is a classic feature of Cytomegalovirus (CMV).
  • Owl's eye inclusions - large, round, blue intra-nuclear bodies with a clear halo around them. This finding is characteristic and diagnostic of CMV infection.

Cytomegalovirus (CMV):

  • DNA virus from the Herpesviridae family
  • Common in immunocompromised patients (HIV, transplant)
  • Causes:
    • CMV retinitis, esophagitis, colitis, pneumonitis, nephritis
    • Congenital CMV - sensorineural deafness, periventricular calcifications
  • Histology hallmark: Owl's eye inclusions
    • Basophilic, intra-nuclear, surrounded by halo
    • Seen in epithelial cells of affected organs

questions.text: Medication used in the treatment of idiopathic central precocious puberty is:
questions.solution:
GnRH analogues are the treatment of choice for idiopathic central precocious puberty. They act by desensitizing the pituitary gland through continuous stimulation, leading to suppression of LH and FSH release, thereby halting premature puberty progression.

Mechanism of Action:

  • Continuous (non-pulsatile) administration of GnRH analogues leads to downregulation of GnRH receptors in the pituitary
  • Results in suppressed gonadotropin release (LH, FSH)
  • This ultimately halts gonadal steroid production and delays further pubertal development

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Exogenous gonadotropins (Option A):

Used in inducing ovulation or spermatogenesis, not in treating precocious puberty. These would worsen the condition.

Ethinyl estradiol (Option B):

Exogenous estrogen would advance puberty, not suppress it. Not indicated in central precocious puberty.

Progesterone (Option D):

Sometimes used to regulate menstrual cycles, but ineffective in suppressing the HPG axis or halting puberty progression.

questions.text: What surgeon is credited for designing the prosthesis seen in the figure?
questions.solution:
• The Austin-Moore prosthesis was a large, uncemented femoral stem that didn't use polyethylene. The Austin-Moore prosthesis had fenestrations for self-locking which later became the impetus for biological fixation.
  • These implants were originally used to treat hip fractures and certain cases of degenerative arthritis.
  • The prosthesis has a head with a small neck and a stem. It is available in head sizes ranging from 35 to 59 mm (odd numbers).
  • There is a small hole at the top of the stem for the hook of the extractor, used while removing the prosthesis. The stem has two fenestrations in its middle, through which the bone supposedly grows and helps in fixation of the prosthesis.
  • This prosthesis can thus be used only without cement because the use of cement would make its removal, if required, difficult.

Explanation of Other Options:

John Charnley (Option A)

  • John Charnley introduced the idea of replacing the eroded acetabulum with a Teflon component. Pioneer of the modern total hip replacement (THR)
  • Developed the low-friction arthroplasty using polished metal stem and polyethylene cup, with polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) fixation.

San Baw (Option B)

  • Known primarily for the development of forefoot arthroplasty using ivory composite prostheses in Burma/Myanmar.
  • His work focused on toe joint replacements, not hip implants.

Sir Harry Platt (Option C)

  • A renowned British orthopedic surgeon (early 20th century), known for cerebral palsy & bone infection treatment, as well as establishing orthopedic services.

questions.text: A 3-day-old male neonate presents with poor feeding, vomiting, lethargy, and rapidly progressing encephalopathy. Plasma ammonia is markedly elevated. Arterial blood gas is normal. Urinary orotic acid is significantly increased. Which of the following is the most likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency is the most common urea cycle disorder and is X-linked.

Characterised by:

  • Hyperammonemia in the neonatal period
  • Normal pH and bicarbonate (unlike organic acidemias)
  • ↑ Urinary orotic acid due to carbamoyl phosphate spillover into pyrimidine synthesis pathway

 Urea Cycle:

  • Purpose: Detoxifies ammonia by converting it into urea (excreted in urine).
  • Location: Liver mitochondria and cytosol.
  • Key Enzymes (in order):
    1. CPS1 - Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I
    2. OTC - Ornithine transcarbamylase
    3. ASS - Argininosuccinate synthetase
    4. ASL - Argininosuccinate lyase
    5. ARG1 - Arginase 1
  • Activator: NAG (N-acetylglutamate) activates CPS1; synthesised by NAGS enzyme

Genetics:

Clinical Manifestations by Age:

Neonates:

  • Poor feeding, vomiting, lethargy, seizures, coma
  • Increased intracranial pressure
  • Possible prenatal signs: IUGR, microcephaly (e.g., cblC defect)

Infants & Children:

  • Vomiting, ataxia, altered behaviour, seizures
  • Episodes may mimic encephalitis or psychiatric illness

Late-Onset Forms:

  • May present in adolescence/adulthood
  • Episodic headache, confusion, psychosis, lethargy

Neurologic & Other Sequelae:

  • Intellectual disability, movement disorders (dystonia, CP mimic)
  • Seizures (20-30%), optic atrophy, retinal issues
  • Skin lesions (acrodermatitis-like) due to protein restriction
  • Hepatomegaly, failure to thrive

Enzyme-Specific Findings:

Related Disorders Causing Hyperammonemia:

Diagnostic Approach:

Initial Screening:

  • Any neonate with:
    • Sepsis-like features
    • Unexplained encephalopathy
    • Recurrent vomiting

Key Lab Investigations:

Treatment Overview:

Acute Management:

Long-Term Management:

  • Protein-restricted diet (RDA-based)
  • Regular monitoring - Growth, amino acids, development
  • Avoid triggers - Infections, fasting, valproate
  • Ammonia-lowering drugs - Long-term use of benzoate/phenylbutyrate
  • Liver transplantation - Curative in severe cases

Key Differentiating Biochemical Features:

questions.text: Which structure does NOT lie in the coronary sulcus?
questions.solution:
• The coronary sulcus (also called the atrioventricular groove) separates the atria from the ventricles and contains key vessels that run around the heart horizontally
  • The following structures lie in the coronary sulcus:
    • Circumflex artery - branch of the left coronary artery that runs in the left part of the coronary sulcus (Option A ruled out)
    • Coronary sinus - the main venous drainage of the heart, lies in the posterior coronary sulcus (Option B ruled out)
    • Right coronary artery (RCA) - courses in the right part of the coronary sulcus (Option C ruled out)
  • The right marginal artery, however, branches off from the RCA and descends along the right margin of the heart, not in the coronary sulcus (Correct)

Key Takeaways:

  • Coronary sulcus houses major horizontal vessels like the RCA, circumflex artery, and coronary sinus
  • Right marginal artery travels along the inferior border of the heart, outside the sulcus
  • Recognizing the pathways of coronary vessels helps in both imaging and surgery

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman with a mechanical heart valve was anticoagulated with warfarin during her pregnancy. Her newborn was delivered at 34 weeks. Which of the following is the most likely to be present in the newborn?
questions.solution:
Maternal use of warfarin during pregnancy can cause Fetal Warfarin Syndrome (Warfarin embryopathy) due to its ability to cross the placenta and inhibit vitamin K-dependent coagulation factors.

Key features of fetal warfarin syndrome:

  • Craniofacial anomalies:
    • Nasal hypoplasia (flat, underdeveloped nasal bridge - hallmark feature)
    • Depressed midface
  • Skeletal defects:
    • Stippled epiphyses (chondrodysplasia punctata)
    • Limb shortening (micromelia, brachydactyly)
  • Neurological defects (hydrocephalus, developmental delay)
  • Fetal/neonatal bleeding due to anticoagulation

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Hyperplastic gums (Option A): Hyperplastic gums are seen with phenytoin (fetal hydantoin syndrome)

Macromelia (Option C): Macromelia (isolated enlargement of an entire extremity) is not a feature of fetal warfarin syndrome; on the contrary, micromelia or limb shortening is.

Syndactyly (Option D): Syndactyly (fused digits) is not a classic finding of warfarin exposure.

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3624665/

questions.text: A 36-year-old previously healthy male working in a government laboratory who is researching bioterrorism agents, suddenly presents with abrupt-onset fever, malaise, dyspnoea, and chest tightness. His condition rapidly deteriorates over 24 hours. Chest X-ray shows a widened mediastinum with clear lung fields, and blood cultures reveal large Gram-positive bacilli arranged in long chains. Which of the following pathogens is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
• The clinical scenario suggests inhalational anthrax, a life-threatening form of anthrax resulting from inhalation of aerosolised spores.
  • The widened mediastinum on imaging (due to hemorrhagic mediastinitis) with clear lung fields is a classic radiologic finding.
  • Gram-positive rods in long chains on blood culture strongly point to Bacillus anthracis, the causative organism.
  • As the patient is working with bioterrorism agents, this organism’s relevance as a CDC Category A bioterrorism pathogen strengthens the diagnosis.

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4921253

questions.text: As per NMC rules, if any request is made for medical records, the documents shall be issued within the period of
questions.solution:
As per the NMC Registered Medical Practitioner (Professional Conduct) Regulations, 2023:

  • Every self-employed RMP must maintain medical records of inpatients for 3 years from the last date of contact.
  • If a request for medical records is made by the patient, an authorized attendant, or a legal authority, it must be:
    • Acknowledged promptly
    • Supplied within 5 working days

This applies to records managed by individual RMPs or by institutions.

Explanation of Other Options:

48 hours (Option B): Too short; may be mandated for emergency medico-legal requests but not standard record release.

24 hours (Option C): Unfeasible for routine release, especially in institutional setups.

7 days (Option D): Exceeds the NMC's prescribed limit; not compliant with current regulations.

Key Takeaway:

As per NMC 2023 regulations, requested medical records must be supplied within 5 working days, reinforcing patient rights and documentation standards.

Reference: National Medical Commission Registered Medical Practitioner (Professional Conduct) Regulations, 2023

questions.text: A 23-year-old young man who is a member of a music band has played saxophone for the last 10 years. The band has been doing many popular concerts. He has developed a neck swelling on the left side of the larynx. An X-ray of the neck is shown in the picture. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a typical case of laryngocele.

Etiology

  • A laryngocele is an air-filled dilation of the laryngeal saccule, which communicates with the laryngeal lumen.
  • Predisposing factors:
    • Increased intralaryngeal pressure (e.g., playing wind instruments: trumpet, saxophone, etc.)
    • Chronic cough or straining
    • May be congenital or acquired

Pathophysiology

  • The saccule is a mucosal outpouching from the ventricle of the larynx, situated between the true vocal cords (TVC) and false vocal cords (FVC).
  • When the saccule becomes abnormally dilated and air-filled, it forms a laryngocele.
  • The laryngocele may:
    • Remain internal (confined within the larynx)
    • Extend externally through the thyrohyoid membrane to present as a neck swelling (external laryngocele)
    • Or be mixed (both internal and external components)

Clinical Features

  • Bryce's Sign: Compression of the swelling produces a hissing sound of air leakage
  • Intermittent swelling that may enlarge during:
    • Valsalva maneuver
    • Coughing
    • Blowing
  • May cause hoarseness, dysphagia, or airway obstruction in internal or large mixed types

Investigations

  • X-ray soft tissue neck (lateral view) during Valsalva manoeuvre:
    • Shows an air-filled, thin-walled swelling lateral to the larynx
  • CT scan:
    • More accurate in defining the extent (internal vs external vs mixed)
  • Laryngoscopy:
    • May show bulging of the ventricular fold or false cord

Management

  • Symptomatic or large laryngocele:
    • Surgical excision (via endoscopic or external approach, depending on type)
    • Microlaryngoscopic resection for internal laryngocele
    • External approach for large or external laryngoceles
  • Avoidance of triggers (e.g., blowing instruments, chronic straining)

Explanation for other options:

Thyroglossal cyst (Option B) is a midline swelling formed due to non-obliteration of the thyroglossal tract.

A branchial cyst (Option C) is formed due to non-obliteration of the second branchial cleft. It presents as lateral neck swelling in childhood or early adulthood with an increase in size following an episode of upper respiratory infection.

Ranula (Option D) is a mucus extravasation cyst of sublingual glands, which presents as a bluish translucent swelling in the floor of the mouth.

questions.text: Which of the following iron preparations cannot be used intramuscularly?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ferric carboxymaltose is a stable, non-dextran intravenous (IV) complex of ferric hydroxide and carbohydrate polymer.

It is designed specifically for intravenous use only due to its high molecular weight and poor intramuscular absorption.

  • Mechanism: When given IV, it releases iron slowly for uptake by reticuloendothelial macrophages, allowing large single doses (up to 1000 mg over 15 minutes) without anaphylaxis risk.
  • IM administration is contraindicated because:
    • It causes severe local pain and tissue necrosis.
    • The large molecular complex is not absorbed effectively from muscle tissue.
    • Risk of skin staining and abscess formation if injected intramuscularly.
  • Clinical use: Preferred for rapid iron repletion in CKD, IBD, postpartum anemia, or intolerance to oral iron.

Hence, ferric carboxymaltose is IV-only; it must not be used intramuscularly.

Explanation of Other Options:

Iron Dextran (Option A): Can be given both IM and IV. IM route requires Z-track technique to prevent staining; test dose needed due to risk of anaphylaxis from dextran component.

Iron Sorbitol (Option B): Commonly used IM preparation (2 mL = 100 mg Fe). Usually given deep IM in the gluteal region. Less anaphylactic risk than dextran, but causes local pain and discoloration.

Key Takeaways:

• Transitional Cell Carcinoma of Ureter(TCC) typically shows a "goblet sign", where the mass causes a dilated ureter proximal to the tumour, giving a goblet-shaped contour.
  • B. Ureterocele presents with a "cobra or adder head appearance" due to the ballooning of the distal ureter into the bladder.
  • C. Retrocaval ureter shows a "fish hook sign" on imaging, due to medial deviation and kinking of the ureter behind the IVC.
  • D. Retroperitoneal fibrosis causes "maiden waist deformity" by causing bilateral medial deviation and tapering of the ureters.

questions.text: In which type of fracture neck of femur according to Garden's classification is the trabeculae of femoral neck, femoral head and acetabulum in alignment?
questions.solution:
• In Garden type II all 3 trabeculae are collinear.
  • This preserved alignment indicates minimal disruption of the intracapsular blood supply, allowing stable fixation with a low risk of avascular necrosis.
  • The Garden classification is used to classify intracapsular proximal femur fractures (neck of femur fractures)

questions.text: A 24-year-old female reports to the casualty with a history of amenorrhoea for two and a half months and abdominal pain and bleeding per vaginum for one day. On examination, vital parameters and other systems are normal. On speculum examination, bleeding is found to come from Os. On bimanual examination, the uterus is 10 weeks in size, soft, and Os admits one finger. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical scenario given the most probable diagnosis would be Inevitable Abortion

Inevitable Abortion

Inevitable abortion is a type of spontaneous miscarriage where pregnancy loss is unavoidable. It typically occurs before 20 weeks of gestation.

Key Features:

  • Vaginal bleeding and cramping
  • The cervix is dilated
  • Membranes may rupture, and tissue may bulge into the vagina
  • Products of conception have not yet been fully expelled

Diagnosis:

  • Based on the clinical exam showing cervical dilation and active bleeding
  • Ultrasound may show a nonviable or low-lying gestational sac

Management Options:

  • Expectant: Allow natural passage (if stable)
  • Medical: Misoprostol to assist expulsion
  • Surgical: Dilation and curettage (D&C) if bleeding is heavy or incomplete

Complications:

  • Hemorrhage
  • Infection
  • Retained products of conception

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with fever, headache, and photophobia. On examination, he has neck stiffness and purpura over the trunk. Lumbar puncture reveals cloudy CSF with increased neutrophils. Gram stain of CSF shows Gram-negative diplococci within polymorphonuclear leukocytes. The organism ferments both glucose and maltose. Which of the following features helps differentiate this pathogen from its close relative causing sexually transmitted infections?
questions.solution:
• The patient has classical signs of acute bacterial meningitis, and CSF findings point to Neisseria meningitidis, which appears as Gram-negative diplococci inside polymorphs and ferments both glucose and maltose.
  • The key differentiating feature between Neisseria meningitidis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae is that meningococci possess a polysaccharide capsule, while gonococci are non-capsulated.
  • The capsule is a major virulence factor of meningococci and forms the basis for serogroup classification and vaccine development.

Meningococci vs Gonococci:

Similarities (Both are Neisseria species):

  • Gram-negative diplococci, intracellular in polymorphs (Option C ruled out)
  • Oxidase-positive, catalase-positive (Option B ruled out)
  • Require enriched media like chocolate agar or Thayer-Martin medium (Option D ruled out)
  • Delicate organisms, die quickly outside host
  • Produce IgA1 protease, helping mucosal evasion

questions.text: CRISPR-Cas9 has revolutionised genomic DNA studies. Which of the following is true for CRISPR-Cas9?
questions.solution:
CRISPR-Cas9 (clustered regularly interspersed short palindromic repeats - associated gene 9)

  • CRISPR is a gene editing and regulatory technique. (Option A)
  • Found in prokaryotes (bacteria and archaea), derived from bacteriophage DNA.
  • Acts as an antiviral defense system, helping prokaryotes detect and destroy DNA from similar bacteriophages.
  • Provides adaptive immunity to prevent reinfection by specific phages.
  • Complements restriction endonucleases and methylases.
  • RNA-based targeting guides the Cas9 nuclease to complementary DNA for editing.

CAS9: CRISPR-associated protein 9

  • An endonuclease enzyme. (Option C)
  • It uses CRISPR sequences as a guide (as guide RNA). (Option B)
  • Then recognises specific DNA strands that are complementary to the CRISPR sequence & cleaves them.

CRISPR CAS9

  • Both together are used to edit genes within organisms.
  • Within bacteria, this CRISPR-RNA-Cas9 complex then degrades and inactivates the targeted DNA.

Applications of CRISPR in Eukaryotes:

  • CRISPR has been adapted for use in eukaryotic cells, including humans, functioning as an RNA-guided site-specific nuclease.
  • It has broad applications in:
    • Medicine - used experimentally for genetic disorders (e.g., sickle cell disease) and viral infections like HIV.
    • Basic research - enables gene deletion, editing, visualization, and transcription modulation.
    • Agriculture & food industry - applied for genetic improvements.
  • CRISPR is a highly specific and efficient tool for DNA manipulation and genetic analysis in mammalian cells.
  • A variant, C2c2, can site-specifically cleave RNA, offering the potential to alter mRNA levels in human cells.

choices.text: Removal of placenta followed by repositioning of uterus
Attempt to reposition uterus with placenta in situ

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida patient delivered vaginally after a spontaneous labor. After delivery placenta did not deliver spontaneously so the obstetrician attempted controlled cord traction. During the procedure the obstetrician noticed a pear shaped mass protruding outside with a broad base pointing downwards and placenta attached to it. The next best step in management of such patient:
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes acute uterine inversion, a rare but life-threatening obstetric emergency that typically presents immediately after delivery, often during or after controlled cord traction when the placenta is still attached.

In acute uterine inversion, the first priority is immediate manual repositioning of the uterus (e.g., Johnson maneuver), even before removing the placenta, because:

  • Attempting to remove the placenta first may worsen hemorrhage and shock.
  • Repositioning the uterus restores uterine tone and reduces ongoing bleeding.

Clinical Features:

Symptoms:

  • Sudden onset of lower abdominal or pelvic pain
  • Heavy vaginal bleeding
  • Dizziness or collapse due to hypovolemic shock

Signs:

  • Absent uterine fundus on abdominal palpation
  • Smooth, red-blue mass protruding through the vagina (often with placenta attached)
  • Fundal dimple or depression in lower abdomen

Management:

  1. Immediate Resuscitation:
    • Secure airway, breathing, and circulation (ABC)
    • High-flow oxygen
    • Large bore IV access, start fluid resuscitation
    • Crossmatch and prepare blood products
  2. Manual Repositioning (Johnson Maneuver):
    • Use the palm and fingers to push the uterine fundus upward through the vagina toward the umbilicus
    • Maintain steady pressure until the uterus reverts to its normal position
    • Do not remove the placenta before repositioning
  3. If Manual Reposition Fails:
    • Administer tocolytics to relax uterus (e.g., nitroglycerin, terbutaline)
    • Attempt repositioning again
    • Once successful, administer uterotonics (oxytocin, misoprostol) to promote contraction and prevent recurrence

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Transvaginal ultrasound (Option A):

Useful for diagnosis in subacute or chronic inversion, but not appropriate when the diagnosis is clinically obviousand urgent intervention is needed.

Hysterectomy (Option B):

Considered only when manual and surgical repositioning fails or there's irreversible uterine damage or necrosis. It is not the next step.

Removal of placenta followed by repositioning (Option C):

Contraindicated initially. Removing the placenta first can cause catastrophic hemorrhage. Always attempt repositioning first.

questions.text: Identify the type of scotoma
questions.solution:
• A Bjerrum (arcuate) scotoma is an arc-shaped visual field defect that begins at the blind spot and curves around the fixation point following the retinal nerve fiber layer.
  • It typically occurs in early glaucoma and respects the horizontal meridian.
  • This region corresponds to the Bjerrum's area-10°-20° from fixation, where glaucomatous damage is most commonly observed.
  • Arcuate scotomas are among the earliest and most classic glaucomatous defects and are used to identify progression over time.

Progression of Visual Field Defects in POAG

  1. Isopter contraction - Early diffuse generalized constriction of the central and peripheral fields.
  2. Baring of blind spot - Early non-specific sign due to inward curve of the outer boundary of the 30° field.
  3. Paracentral scotoma - Common early localized defect near fixation.
  4. Seidel scotoma - A sickle-shaped extension of the blind spot into arcuate regions.
  5. Nasal step of Roenne - Defect respecting horizontal midline due to selective damage of arcuate fibers.
  6. Arcuate (Bjerrum) scotoma - Classic mid-stage defect that arches from the blind spot toward the nasal field.
  7. Ring scotoma - Late stage, due to merging of superior and inferior arcuate scotomas.
  8. Tubular and temporal island - Seen in end-stage glaucoma; central and temporal islands may be all that remain.

Explanation of other options:

Paracentral scotoma (Option A): This is a small localized visual field defect that lies just adjacent to the fixation point, usually within 10°. It can occur in early glaucoma but does not extend from the blind spot or form an arc. It is usually more localized and not shaped like a bow or arc.

Ring scotoma (Option B): A ring scotoma is a complete or incomplete ring-shaped area of visual loss that surrounds the central field. Commonly seen in retinal dystrophies such as retinitis pigmentosa or in cases involving panretinal degeneration. In contrast to arcuate scotoma, it is not linked to nerve fiber layer loss or glaucoma and typically affects both nasal and temporal fields symmetrically.

Seidel scotoma (Option D): It is a comet-shaped extension of the blind spot. It is often seen in early glaucoma and represents a nasal step defect extending from the blind spot. Unlike arcuate scotomas, Seidel scotomas are smaller and more focal, often a precursor to arcuate defects.

This area is called as bjerrum's area and this scotoma is arc shaped arcuate scotoma

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with a history of lifting weights presents the next day with back pain, right-sided radiculopathy, loss of bladder function, loss of sensation of the feet, and weakness of the extensor hallucis longus. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Presents with asymmetric radiculopathy, saddle anesthesia, loss of bladder control, and lower motor neuron signs
  • Typically due to massive central disc herniation, especially in the context of physical strain (e.g., heavy lifting)
  • Involves compression of the lumbosacral nerve roots, not the spinal cord itself

Explanation of other options:

Lumbar canal stenosis (Option A): Typically presents with chronic neurogenic claudication and bilateral symptoms. Does not usually cause acute bladder dysfunction or focal radiculopathy.

Fracture of lumbar vertebrae (Option B): Requires significant trauma. Neurological symptoms occur only if there is cord or nerve root compression, which is not indicated directly in this case.

Conus medullaris syndrome (Option C): Also causes bladder dysfunction, but is characterized by symmetric symptoms, early bladder involvement, and less radicular pain. This case shows asymmetric radiculopathy with delayed bladder signs, favoring cauda equina syndrome.

Key Takeaways:

  • Cauda equina syndrome = asymmetric nerve root symptoms, bladder dysfunction, saddle anesthesia
  • Conus medullaris = symmetric symptoms, early bladder signs, less radicular pain
  • It must be diagnosed early via MRI and treated with emergency decompression.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought for evaluation due to delayed developmental milestones. On examination, the child has severe intellectual disability, frequent inappropriate laughter, ataxic gait, and minimal speech development. MRI is unremarkable. Genetic testing reveals a microdeletion in the maternal chromosome 15q11-q13 region. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Angelman syndrome is characterised by:
    • Loss of maternal UBE3A gene function (15q11-q13)
    • Features: Severe intellectual disability, ataxia, absent or minimal speech, frequent laughter/smiling, seizures
    • MRI is often normal in early stages
    • Most common genetic cause: Maternal deletion (~70%)

Genomic Imprinting:

  • Definition: Selective expression of a gene depending on its parental origin.
  • Mechanism: One allele (either maternal or paternal) is epigenetically silenced.
  • Clinical Relevance: Can lead to disease when the active (non-imprinted) allele is missing or mutated.
  • Key Example: Chromosome 15q11-q13 disorders show parent-specific expression effects.

Key Disorders Involving Genomic Imprinting:

Angelman Syndrome (AS):

  • Genetic Cause: Loss of function of maternal UBE3A gene (15q11-q13).
  • Mechanisms:
    • Maternal deletion (~70% of cases)
    • Mutation in maternal UBE3A
    • Paternal uniparental disomy (UPD)
    • Imprinting defect affecting maternal allele
  • Imprinting Note: Paternal UBE3A is silenced (imprinted) in neurons.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Severe intellectual disability
    • No or minimal speech
    • Ataxia (gait and coordination issues)
    • Seizures
    • Happy personality with frequent laughter and excitability

Prader-Willi Syndrome (PWS):

  • Genetic Cause: Loss of function of paternal genes in the same 15q11-q13 region.
  • Mechanisms:
    • Paternal deletion
    • Maternal UPD
    • Imprinting defect affecting paternal gene expression
  • Imprinting Note: Maternal copies of these genes are imprinted (silenced).
  • Clinical Features:
    • Severe hypotonia and feeding difficulty in infancy
    • Progresses to hyperphagia and obesity in childhood
    • Intellectual disability, behavioural issues
    • Hypogonadism, short stature, small hands/feet

Rett syndrome (Option A): It affects girls (X-linked dominant MECP2 mutation), with normal early development followed by regression, hand-wringing, and seizures.

Fragile X syndrome (Option D): It presents with macroorchidism, long face, large ears, and X-linked inheritance, often with autism features - not frequent laughter or ataxia.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK585708

choices.text: DHT-receptor complex is less stable than testosterone-receptor complex
5alpha reductase type 1 is found in genital skin
DHT-receptor complex is necessary for wolffian duct growth
DHT is responsible for most of the secondary sexual characteristics in males

questions.text: The Following is true related to Dihydrotestosterone (DHT)
questions.solution:
Dihydrotestosterone (DHT) is a potent androgen derived from testosterone through the action of the enzyme 5α-reductase. It is responsible for most male secondary sexual characteristics, such as facial and body hair growth, deepening of the voice, development of the prostate, and male-pattern baldness. DHT has a stronger affinity for androgen receptors than testosterone and forms a more stable DHT-receptor complex, making it biologically more potent in target tissues.

While testosterone is essential for internal genitalia (like the Wolffian duct derivatives), DHT is crucial for the development of external genitalia (penis, scrotum, prostate) and secondary sexual traits. Abnormalities in DHT production or action (e.g., 5α-reductase deficiency) can lead to underdeveloped male genitalia despite normal testosterone levels.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

DHT-receptor complex is less stable than testosterone-receptor complex (Option A): Incorrect. The DHT-receptor complex is more stable and has a higher affinity for androgen receptors than testosterone.

5α-reductase type 1 is found in genital skin (Option B): Incorrect. Type 2 is the main isoform in genital skin and prostate; type 1 is primarily found in the liver and non-genital skin.

DHT-receptor complex is necessary for Wolffian duct growth (Option C): Incorrect. Testosterone, not DHT, is responsible for Wolffian duct development (epididymis, vas deferens, seminal vesicles).

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman undergoes screening mammography. Imaging reveals a well-circumscribed, oval, non-calcified lesion with smooth margins. The radiologist assesses it as unlikely to be malignant but not definitively benign, recommending short-interval follow-up mammograms every 6 months for 2 years.
According to the Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS), which of the following categories correctly applies?
questions.solution:
• The Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) is a structured reporting tool used in mammography, ultrasound, and MRI to classify breast findings based on their likelihood of malignancy and to guide clinical management.
  • A probably benign finding corresponds to BI-RADS 3:
  • Estimated risk of malignancy: >0% but ≤2%
  • Management: 6-month follow-up mammograms for 2 years to confirm stability.
  • Such findings are not definitively benign but have a very low chance of cancer and do not initially warrant biopsy.

BI-RADS 1- Negative (Option A): This applies when there is no abnormal finding at all, requiring only routine screening. Incorrect because a lesion was detected.

BI-RADS 2- Benign finding (Option B): This is used when the lesion is definitively benign (e.g., a simple cyst or fat necrosis), requiring only routine screening. Incorrect here as the lesion is not definitively benign.

BI-RADS 4- Suspicious abnormality (Option D): This applies when the finding has a higher probability of malignancy (>2% to <95%), where biopsy is recommended. Not correct here because the risk is ≤2%, and immediate biopsy is not warranted.

questions.text: Identify the type of cartilage shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
The above image shows an elastic cartilage.

The elastic cartilage, like the hyaline cartilage, contains individual or small groups of chondrocytes that are surrounded by type II collagen fibrils. However, it differs from hyaline cartilage in that much of the interterritorial matrix consists of fine yellow elastic fibers containing elastin protein.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male has a problem of infertility and chronic respiratory infection. He was probably diagnosed with Kartagener syndrome after many biochemical investigations. A mutation in the genes affecting the synthesis of which of the following proteins, which are involved in the movement of cilia and flagella, has been detected in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Kartagener syndrome is a form of primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD).
  • It is caused by a genetic defect in dynein arms, leading to immotile cilia and flagella.
  • This results in:
    • Male infertility (due to immotile sperm)
    • Recurrent respiratory infections (due to impaired mucociliary clearance)
    • Situs inversus (in ~50% of cases)
  • Dynein, a microtubule-associated motor protein, provides ATP-powered movement along the minus end of microtubules. In axonemal cilia and flagella, dynein arms generate sliding forces required for motility.

Explanation of other options:

Kinesin (Option (A): Moves cargo toward the plus end of microtubules (anterograde axonal transport), not involved in cilia movement.

Dynamin (Option B): GTPase involved in endocytosis, not in ciliary or flagellar movement

Myosin (Option D): Motor protein for actin filaments, relevant to muscle contraction, not microtubule-based cilia

questions.text: When placenta invades myometrium but doesn't penetrate serosa such type of adherent placenta is called:
questions.solution:
Adherent placenta, also known as morbidly adherent placenta, refers to abnormal attachment of the placenta to the uterine wall due to defective decidua basalis. When the placenta invades into the myometrium but does not penetrate the uterine serosa, it is classified as placenta increta. This condition is more severe than placenta accreta and can result in massive postpartum hemorrhage, often requiring hysterectomy at the time of delivery.

Clinical Features:

  • Antepartum hemorrhage: May occur in late pregnancy, though not always present.
  • Failure of placental separation after delivery.
  • Severe postpartum hemorrhage (PPH): Typically occurs when attempts are made to remove the placenta manually.
  • Shock: May be out of proportion to visible blood loss.
  • No plane of cleavage between placenta and uterus during manual removal.
  • History of risk factors:
    • Previous cesarean section
    • Placenta previa
    • Prior uterine surgeries (e.g., curettage, myomectomy)

Investigation Findings:

Antenatal Diagnosis:

  • Ultrasound (preferably transvaginal):
    • Loss of clear zone between placenta and myometrium
    • Thinning of the myometrium over the placenta
    • Turbulent lacunar blood flow within the placenta on color Doppler
    • Placental bulge or extension into uterine wall
  • MRI (if ultrasound is inconclusive):
    • Better defines the depth and topography of invasion
    • Especially useful in posterior placenta and to differentiate increta from percreta

Management:

Antenatal Period:

  • Planned delivery at tertiary care center with availability of blood products, ICU, and surgical expertise
  • Timing: Elective cesarean hysterectomy at 34-36 weeks in stable cases, after corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity
  • Avoid manual removal of placenta during delivery

Intraoperative Management:

  • Cesarean hysterectomy (preferred): Uterus with placenta in situ is removed to prevent massive hemorrhage
  • Conservative management (selected cases only):
    • Placenta left in situ
    • Uterotonics, methotrexate may be considered (controversial)
    • Close follow-up with imaging and monitoring for infection, bleeding, or sepsis

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Placenta accreta (Option A): This is the least severe form of morbidly adherent placenta. In this condition, the placental villi attach directly to the superficial myometrium without actual invasion into it.

Placenta percreta (Option C): This is the most severe form, where the placenta penetrates through the myometrium and uterine serosa, and may even invade adjacent organs such as the bladder.

Subamniotic abruption (Option D): This is a type of placental abruption, not an adherent placenta. It involves bleeding between the amniotic membrane and the fetal surface of the placenta and is unrelated to abnormal placental invasion.

questions.text: A patient was admitted to the medicine department for some reason. The nurse was keeping a chart for intake and output of water from the body. Apart from the urine output, what average amount of insensible water loss should be taken into consideration in an average environment?
questions.solution:
• Continuous evaporation of water through the respiratory tract (breathing air) and through skin (independent of sweating) adds up to the insensible water loss from the body. This loss is termed insensible water loss because we are not consciously aware of it.
  • Usually, insensible water loss through the respiratory tract normally averages about 300 to 400 ml/day.
  • Insensible water loss through skin, independent of sweating, is approximately 300 to 400 ml/day.
  • Total insensible loss of water through the body is around 700 to 800 ml per day.

choices.text: Age of the patient influences the risk of malignant transformation.
Size of the lesion is an important prognostic factor and affects staging.
Grade of dysplasia predicts malignant potential.
Posterior aspect of the tongue is considered a low-risk site for malignant transformation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male smoker presents with an ulcerative lesion on the lateral border of the tongue. Biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma of the oral cavity. Examination reveals a 4 cm single ipsilateral lymph node fixed to skin with adjacent structure infiltration (clinically ENE-positive). Regarding factors that affect prognosis or malignant transformation, which among the following statements is NOT correct?
questions.solution:
• The posterior aspect of the tongue (base of tongue) is actually considered a high-risk site for malignant transformation.
  • This area has rich lymphatic drainage and tumors in this location tend to present late, with a higher chance of nodal and distant metastases.
  • Hence, the statement claiming it is a low-risk site is incorrect, making it the correct answer for this question.

Oral Cavity Cancer: Risk Factors and Prognostic Indicators


Age of the patient influences the risk of malignant transformation. (Option A): Older age correlates with a higher risk of developing oral cavity cancers due to cumulative exposure to carcinogens and reduced DNA repair mechanisms. Hence, this is correct.

Size of the lesion is an important prognostic factor and affects staging. (Option B): Larger lesions are associated with higher T stages and worse outcomes, as per TNM criteria. Hence, this is correct.

Grade of dysplasia predicts malignant potential. (Option C): High-grade dysplasia (severe dysplasia or carcinoma in situ) is more likely to transform into invasive cancer. Hence, this is correct.

Reference:https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6528815/

questions.text: All of the following are sources of phosphate taking part in energy capture, except:
questions.solution:
Beta oxidation of fatty acids is not the source of phosphate in ATP production

  • Produces NADH and FADH2, which enter the ETC to generate ATP indirectly
  • No direct Pi transfer to ADP occurs in this pathway
  • ATP generation is oxidative and downstream, not direct
  • ATP acts as the energy currency of the cell
  • The high group transfer potential of ATP enables it to act as a donor of high-energy phosphate to form many compounds.
  • Likewise, with the necessary enzymes, ADP can accept phosphate groups to form ATP from some compounds.
  • In effect, an ATP/ADP cycle connects those processes that generate high-energy phosphate to those processes that utilize high-energy phosphate, continuously consuming and regenerating ATP.
  • There are three major sources in which phosphate takes part in energy conservation or energy capture

Explanation of Other Options:

Oxidative phosphorylation (Option A): Oxidative phosphorylation is the greatest quantitative source of high-energy phosphate in aerobic organisms. ATP is generated in the mitochondrial matrix as O2 is reduced to H2O by electrons passing down the respiratory chain.

Glycolysis (Option B): Glycolysis. A net formation of two high-energy phosphates results from the formation of lactate from one molecule of glucose, generated in two reactions catalyzed by phosphoglycerate kinase and pyruvate kinase, respectively.

TCA Cycle (Option C): The citric acid cycle. One high-energy phosphate is generated directly in the cycle at the succinate thiokinase step.

choices.text: Homogeneous vaginal discharge with pH 5.0 to 6.0
Positive clue cells in 100% of cases
It is due to Gardnerella vaginalis

questions.text: Regarding bacterial vaginosis, all are true except:
questions.solution:
Clue cells are diagnostic, but about 40% patients may not have clue cells.


Explanation for other options:

Homogeneous discharge with pH 5-6 (Option A): Bacterial vaginosis (BV) typically presents with thin, grayish-white discharge and a raised pH (>4.5) due to reduced lactobacilli.

Positive KOH with fishy odor (Option B): The whiff test is positive in BV, producing a fishy odor due to the release of amines when 10% KOH is added to the vaginal discharge.

Caused by Gardnerella vaginalis (Option D): BV is primarily due to the overgrowth of Gardnerella vaginalis and anaerobic bacteria, replacing the normal lactobacilli flora.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man from a non-western country presents with recurrent episodes of cholangitis. Imaging reveals soft, friable, laminated stones located in the common bile duct. Which type of stones is most likely responsible for his primary choledocholithiasis?
questions.solution:
• Brown pigment stones are typically found in the bile ducts (choledocholithiasis) rather than the gallbladder.
  • They are associated with chronic biliary infections (e.g., bacterial or parasitic) which lead to the deconjugation of bilirubin and the formation of soft, friable, brown-colored stones.
  • In the given scenario, the stones are soft, laminated, located in the ducts, consistent with brown pigment stones.
  • Brown pigment stones are formed in the presence of infection which hydrolyzes conjugated bilirubin.
  • Their location in bile ducts and soft, friable nature differentiates them from cholesterol or black pigment stones.

Cholesterol stones (Option A): Typically occur in the gallbladder, seen in Western countries, hard and crystalline, not usually associated with infection or ducts.

Black pigment stones (Option B): Occur in the gallbladder in non-western countries, associated with hemolysis or ileal disease, hard, brittle, and radio-opaque, not commonly found in ducts.

Mixed stones (Option D): These have overlapping features but are not specifically associated with ductal location or infection. Not the best answer here.

questions.text: A football player, while playing, sustained a lateral blow to the knee joint. On examination, the unhappy triad of O'Donoghue was suspected. The trait involves injury to all of the following except:
questions.solution:
The unhappy triad of O'Donoghue involves a combined injury of the medial collateral ligament, the medial meniscus and the anterior cruciate ligament.

  • The unhappy triad was described by American orthopaedic surgeon D H O'Donoghue in 1950.
  • He described the simultaneous occurrence of a tear of the ACL, MCL and medial meniscus when a lateral force is applied to the knee while the foot is fixed to the ground.

questions.text: A phase in cardiac cycle during which atrioventricular valves and semilunar valves both are closed. And the pressure in the aorta is minimum and in the ventricle is suddenly rising. This phase begins with the end of which wave of atrial pressure.
questions.solution:
• The above explanation is about isovolumetric contraction phase of ventricular systole in cardiac cycle.
  • In this phase both atrioventricular (AV) and semilunar valves are closed and ventricular pressure is suddenly rising.
  • This phase begins just after atrial systole ends. a wave in atrial pressure demarks atrial systole. So at the end of a wave the AV valve closes and the ventricular systole (isometric contraction) begins.

questions.text: A male with a history of recurrent respiratory infections since childhood presents for evaluation of infertility. Which of the following is most likely true about his condition?
questions.solution:
• This clinical presentation is classic for Kartagener syndrome, a subtype of Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia (PCD). The hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis is intact and hence FSH and LH levels are normal. It is an Autosomal recessive disease.
  • Classic triad:
    • Bronchiectasis
    • Recurrent sinusitis
    • Situs inversus
  • Due to dynein arm defect → affects ciliary motility → leads to impaired mucociliary clearance and infertility

choices.text: Left anterior descending artery- Left main coronary artery disease
Left posterior descending artery- Poor LV function with viable myocardium
Circumflex artery- Ongoing ischemia with NSTEMI unresponsive to medical therapy
Right marginal branch- Survivors of sudden cardiac death with ischemia-mediated VT

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with severe coronary artery disease and left main coronary artery stenosis is scheduled for coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery. He also has disabling angina despite maximal medical therapy. Which of the following is the most commonly bypassed artery during CABG in such patients, and which clinical indication correctly justifies CABG in this case?
questions.solution:
• The left anterior descending (LAD) artery is the most commonly bypassed artery during CABG. It supplies a large portion of the left ventricle and is most frequently involved in critical stenoses.
  • One of the class I indications for CABG, as per the ACC/AHA guidelines is left main coronary artery disease, which is present in this patient.
  • Disabling angina despite optimal medical therapy also supports the decision for CABG.

2. Indications for CABG (ACC/AHA guidelines):

Class I Indications:

  • Left main coronary artery disease
  • Three-vessel disease with or without proximal LAD involvement
  • Two-vessel disease with proximal LAD involvement
  • Survivors of sudden cardiac death with presumed ischemia-mediated VT

Other indications:

  • Disabling angina refractory to medical therapy
  • Ongoing ischemia with NSTEMI unresponsive to medical therapy
  • Poor LV function with viable myocardium amenable to revascularization

Left posterior descending artery- Poor LV function with viable myocardium (Option B): Left posterior descending is less commonly bypassed, and while poor LV function with viable myocardium is an indication for CABG, it is not the most common scenario. Therefore, incorrect.

Circumflex artery- Ongoing ischemia with NSTEMI unresponsive to medical therapy (Option C): The circumflex artery is not the most commonly bypassed, and although ongoing ischemia is a valid indication, it does not match the most common artery. Therefore, incorrect.

Right marginal branch- Survivors of sudden cardiac death with ischemia-mediated VT (Option D): Right marginal branch is rarely bypassed, and while sudden cardiac death with ischemia-mediated VT is an indication, it does not involve the most commonly bypassed artery. Therefore, incorrect.

choices.text: Lymphatic from the clitoris drains to the ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph nodes
Traverse the labia from medial to lateral
Drain directly into deep femoral glands

questions.text: Which of the following about the lymphatics of the vulva is true?
questions.solution:
Special features of vulval lymphatics are as follows:

  • Superficial lymph nodes are the primary lymph nodes that act as sentinel glands of the vulva. Deep inguinal nodes are secondarily involved. It is unusual to find pelvic glands without metastasis in inguinal nodes. Hence, they traverse the labia from the medial to the lateral side.
  • Lymphatic drainage from the clitoris, anterior labia minora, and perineum is bilateral. Metastases to contralateral lymph nodes in the absence of ipsilateral nodal involvement are very rare for a lateral vulval tumour less than 2cm. (Option A ruled out)
  • Vulvar lymphatics cross at the mons pubis and the posterior fourchette but do not cross the labiocrural folds. (Option D ruled out)
  • The lymphatics of the vulva and distal third of the vagina typically drain into the superficial inguinal node group. From here, lymph travels through the deep femoral lymphatics and the node of Cloquet to the pelvic nodal groups. (Option C ruled out)

choices.text: Fibres from this area project to the premotor cortex.
Lesions of this area produce defects in motor performance.
Some neurons from this area are involved in hand-eye coordination

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with a stroke in the posterior parietal lobe has difficulty with purposeful movements. Which is true about this lesion?
questions.solution:
• Lesions in the posterior parietal cortex often result in ideomotor or ideational apraxia, impairing the ability to perform learned, purposeful movement sequences (e.g., using utensils), despite having intact motor strength.
  • The posterior parietal lobe, specifically the somatosensory association cortex, plays a key role in motor control and coordination.
    • Projection to premotor cortex: Fibres from the posterior parietal cortex project to the premotor area, aiding in movement planning. (Option A)
    • Motor performance defects: Lesions in this region cause deficits in executing purposeful, learned movements (apraxia) even without motor weakness. (Option B)
    • Hand-eye coordination: Some neurons here are involved in coordinating visual information with motor actions, critical for hand-eye coordination and object manipulation. (Option C)

choices.text: Laparoscopic tubal ligation with silastic bands

questions.text: Sterilization procedure with maximum chances of reversal is:
questions.solution:
Laparoscopic tubal ligation with clips offers the highest chance of successful reversal among all sterilization techniques.

  • Clips (e.g., Filshie clips or Hulka clips) are applied across a small segment of the fallopian tube, causing minimal tissue damage.
  • Because less of the tube is destroyed or removed, the anatomical and functional integrity of the tube is more easily restored during reversal surgery (tuboplasty).
  • Reversal success rates can reach up to 75-80%, depending on the remaining healthy tubal length and patient factors.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Pomeroy's tubal ligation (Option A):

  • A widely used method involving ligation and excision of a loop of the fallopian tube.
  • While technically reversible, it removes a larger segment of the tube, making reversal more complex and success rates lower.

Irwing's technique (Option B):

  • A method involving partial salpingectomy (removal of part of the fallopian tube), which is not easily reversibledue to significant tissue loss.

Laparoscopic tubal ligation with silastic bands (Option C):

  • Involves placing a silastic ring around a loop of the fallopian tube, which leads to necrosis of a larger tubal segment.
  • Reversibility is less favorable than with clips due to more extensive tissue damage.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe retrosternal chest pain radiating to the back, upper abdominal rigidity, and shortness of breath for 1 day. He reports a history of repeated forceful vomiting after heavy alcohol consumption prior to symptom onset. Imaging reveals mediastinal air and pleural effusion. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The clinical presentation is classic for Boerhaave's syndrome, which refers to a spontaneous, transmural perforation of the esophagus triggered by forceful vomiting.
  • The association with alcohol intake, sudden retrosternal and upper abdominal pain, shortness of breath, and findings of mediastinal air strongly support this diagnosis.

In this case, the patient developed symptoms after forceful vomiting, consistent with a spontaneous tear of the esophagus (Boerhaave's), supported by findings of mediastinal air and pleural effusion.

Perforated peptic ulcer (Option A): Typically presents with generalized peritonitis and free air under the diaphragm, not mediastinal air or retrosternal pain after vomiting. Therefore, incorrect.

Myocardial infarction (Option B): Causes chest pain but not precipitated by vomiting, and there is no mediastinal air or upper abdominal rigidity. Therefore, incorrect.

Acute pancreatitis (Option D): Presents with epigastric pain radiating to the back, elevated pancreatic enzymes, but not mediastinal air or vomiting-induced esophageal rupture. Therefore, incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following structure expands upto 15 to 20 times during labor
questions.solution:
• Isthmus is located between the body of the uterus and cervix (between anatomical and histological OS). It is 0.5 cm in the non pregnant uterus. It expands greatly during pregnancy and labour, large enough to accomodate the fetal head.
  • The uterus which in nonpregnant state weighs about 60 g, with a cavity of 5-10 mL and measures about 7.5 cm in length, at term, weighs 900-1,000 g and measures 35 cm in length.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man diagnosed with gastric carcinoma is found to have a tumor that invades the muscularis propria, with two regional lymph nodes positive for metastasis, and no distant metastasis. Based on the TNM staging principles adapted from gastric carcinoma staging (shown in the table below), what is the correct stage?
questions.solution:
• According to the TNM classification:
    • T2: Tumor invades muscularis propria.
    • N1: Metastasis in 1-2 regional lymph nodes.
    • M0: No distant metastasis.
  • In this case, the tumor invades muscularis propria (T2), two regional lymph nodes are positive (N1), and no distant metastases (M0).
  • Therefore, the correct stage is T2N1M0.

T3N2M0 (Option A): Here T3 means tumor has gone beyond muscularis propria into subserosal tissue- not applicable here (only muscularis propria). N2 implies 3-6 nodes, but only 2 nodes are involved. Therefore, incorrect.

T2N2M0 (Option C): T2 is correct, but N2 implies 3-6 nodes- here only 2 nodes are involved. Therefore, incorrect.

T3N1M0 (Option D): T3 is incorrect because there is no penetration beyond muscularis propria. Therefore, incorrect.

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient with ischemic heart disease undergoes a successful cardiac rehabilitation program. Public health researchers are evaluating the cost-effectiveness of this intervention for widespread adoption. Which of the following metrics provides the most comprehensive measure of cost-effectiveness by accounting for both quality and quantity of life?
questions.solution:
• QALY is a composite metric used in economic evaluations to quantify health benefits.
  • It incorporates:
    • Duration of survival
    • Quality of life during that time, rated from 0 (death) to 1 (perfect health).
  • Particularly valuable in cost-effectiveness analyses of medical interventions.
  • Allows comparison across different diseases and interventions by assigning a common unit: cost per QALY gained.

Cost per life year saved (Option A):

  • Considers only longevity, not the quality of life during those years.
  • Fails to account for morbidity, which may significantly affect outcomes.
  • Less comprehensive than QALY.

Disability-adjusted life years (DALYs) averted (Option B):

  • DALY measures burden of disease, not benefit of intervention.
  • Used in epidemiological surveillance, not directly in cost-effectiveness.

Number needed to treat (NNT) (Option D):

  • Indicates how many patients need to be treated to prevent one adverse outcome.
  • Does not incorporate cost or duration/quality of life.

References:

  1. WHO Guide for Standardization of Economic Evaluations
  2. Global Burden of Disease Study- Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man presents with recurrent episodes of palpitations and dizziness. During one episode of tachycardia, he develops an irregularly irregular rhythm with a rapid ventricular rate. His resting ECG shows:

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
The patient is experiencing pre-excited atrial fibrillation (AF with WPW), characterised by an irregularly irregular rhythm and rapid ventricular response due to conduction via the accessory pathway. This is a medical emergency and requires immediate electrical cardioversion to prevent ventricular fibrillation and sudden death.

Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome is a pre-excitation disorder where an abnormal accessory pathway (bundle of Kent) bypasses the AV node, leading to premature ventricular activation and potential tachyarrhythmias.

Pathophysiology:

  • Accessory Pathway: Abnormal fast-conducting fibres (resembling Purkinje fibres) connect atria & ventricles.
  • Types of Conduction:
    • Concealed Pathway (50%): Retrograde conduction only → Normal ECG.
    • Manifest Pathway: Antegrade conduction → Abnormal ECG:
      • Short PR interval
      • Delta wave (slurred initial QRS)
      • Widened QRS complex
