  • Re-entry Tachycardia: Due to AV node & accessory pathway having different conduction speeds → leads to AV re-entrant tachycardia (AVRT).

Clinical Features:

  • Typical Tachycardia: Orthodromic AVRT → Narrow-complex tachycardia, often mimicking AVNRT.
  • Pre-excited Atrial Fibrillation:
    • Bypasses AV node's rate-limiting effect
    • Causes rapid ventricular rates, possibly leading to syncope or sudden death
  • Sudden Arrhythmic Death: Known complication.
  • Resting ECG findings:
    • Short PR interval
    • Delta wave
    • Broad QRS complex

Investigations:

Management:

Acute Tachycardia:

  • Carotid sinus massage or IV adenosine: First-line in stable patients (Option A ruled out)
  • DC cardioversion: Required for unstable pre-excited AF

Long-term Strategy:

questions.text: What is the most common location of Brodie's abscess?
questions.solution:
Brodie's abscess is a localised form of subacute or chronic osteomyelitis, usually seen in children and adolescents with unfused epiphyseal plates.

  • It typically affects the metaphyseal region of long bones.
  • Tibia, particularly the proximal or distal metaphysis, is the most common site.
  • Presents with mild pain and tenderness, often without systemic features.
  • Imaging may show a well-circumscribed lucency with sclerotic margins.

Explanation of other options:

Distal end of ulna (Option A): Rarely involved in Brodie abscess.

Femoral metaphysis (Option B): Commonly involved, but less frequently than the tibia.

Distal end radius (Option D): Not a classical site for Brodie abscess.

Key Takeaway:

The tibial metaphysis is the most common site of Brodie abscess, a localised intraosseous abscess seen in subacute osteomyelitis.

  • Brodie abscess is an intraosseous abscess related to a focus of subacute or chronic pyogenic osteomyelitis.
  • Typically, these present in children with unfused epiphyseal plates, more frequently in boys. It has a predilection for ends(metaphysis) of tubular bones, proximal/distal tibial metaphysis is the most common location.

questions.text: Which of the following complement components is involved in both the classical and alternative complement pathways?
questions.solution:
The component C3 is the central convergence point of all three complement pathways - classical, lectin, and alternative.

  • In classical and lectin pathways, C3 is cleaved by the C3 convertase C4b2b.
  • In the alternative pathway, C3 undergoes spontaneous hydrolysis, and upon pathogen recognition, the alternative C3 convertase (C3bBb) is formed.
  • Thus, C3 activation is common and essential to both classical and alternative pathways, making it the correct answer.

C2 (Option B) is only involved in the classical and lectin pathways. It is not used in the alternative pathway.

C1 (Option C) is the initiator of the classical pathway only, by recognising antigen-antibody complexes. It is not used in the alternative pathway.

C4 (Option D) is cleaved in the classical and lectin pathways, but does not participate in the alternative pathway.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man underwent neurosurgical resection of an oligodendroglioma and was started on antiepileptic prophylaxis. At a 3-month follow-up, he reports increased irritability, mood swings, and aggressive behaviour over minor issues. Which of the following antiepileptic drugs is most likely responsible for these psychiatric symptoms?
questions.solution:
Levetiracetam is a second-generation antiepileptic drug that binds to synaptic vesicle protein 2A (SV2A), modulating neurotransmitter release. It is favoured for its minimal drug interactions, lack of hepatic metabolism, and favourable pharmacokinetics.

However, one notable and rare adverse effect of levetiracetam is the occurrence of behavioural disturbances, particularly in adults and children with epilepsy. These include:

  • Irritability
  • Aggression
  • Hostility
  • Mood swings
  • Anxiety
  • Depression (rare)

These psychiatric adverse effects may occur even in patients without a prior psychiatric history and are idiosyncratic.

Levetiracetam:

  • Mechanism of Action:
    • Binds to synaptic vesicle protein 2A (SV2A).
    • Modulates neurotransmitter release → ↓ neuronal hyperexcitability.
    • Does not affect sodium channels or GABA receptors directly.
  • Indications:
    • Effective in partial-onset, myoclonic, and generalised tonic-clonic seizures.
    • Used both as monotherapy and adjunctive therapy.
  • Pharmacokinetics:
    • High oral bioavailability (>95%)
    • Minimal protein binding
    • No hepatic metabolism → minimal drug-drug interactions
    • Renally excreted → dose adjustment needed in renal impairment.
  • Adverse Effects:
    • Generally well tolerated.
    • Common: Somnolence, dizziness, fatigue.
    • Behavioural effects (rare): Irritability, aggression, mood instability → especially in patients with prior psychiatric issues or brain injury.
      • These behavioural side effects are idiosyncratic and not dose-related.
      • Mechanism likely due to altered synaptic neurotransmitter balance via SV2A modulation.

Lamotrigine (Option A):

  • Though rash (including Stevens-Johnson syndrome) and insomnia are common adverse effects, aggression or irritability is not characteristic.
  • It actually has a mood-stabilising effect, often used in bipolar disorder.

Topiramate (Option C):

  • May cause cognitive dulling, word-finding difficulty, weight loss, paresthesia - but behavioural aggression is not a typical side effect.
  • Can cause mood changes, but not classically associated with frank aggression.

Pregabalin (Option D):

  • More likely to cause drowsiness, dizziness, and weight gain.
  • Rarely causes mood elevation, but aggression is not a reported adverse effect.

choices.text: DPT + OPV + MR + JE + Vitamin A

questions.text: An 18-month-old child is brought to the immunization clinic for the first time with no prior vaccinations. According to the National Immunization Schedule (NIS) of India, which of the following combinations of vaccines can be administered at this visit?
questions.solution:
For an 18-month-old previously unimmunized child, the following vaccines are allowed under catch-up:

  • DPT booster-1: due between 16-24 months
  • OPV booster: permitted up to 5 years
  • MR 1st and/or 2nd dose: up to 5 years
  • JE-1 and JE-2: permissible in endemic areas, via campaign-based catch-up
  • Vitamin A (1st or 2nd dose): given between 9 months and 5 years

However, BCG and Pentavalent are not administered after 12 months, so these cannot be included.

  • PCV and JE are given only in designated states/districts.
  • Catch-up for IPV, though allowed in campaigns, is not listed in the MoHFW NIS.
  • MR catch-up: Measles component allowed up to 5 years.

OPV and BCG only (Option A): Incorrect. BCG is contraindicated beyond 1 year. Also, MR, DPT, and Vitamin A are missing.

Pentavalent only (Option B): Incorrect. Pentavalent is not given after 1 year. Also omits critical vaccines like MR, DPT, OPV booster, and Vitamin A.

DPT, OPV and Measles (Option C): Partially correct but incomplete. Measles has been replaced by MR in the NIS. Also misses JE and Vitamin A, which are crucial at this age.

Reference: https://nhm.gov.in/New_Updates_2018/NHM_Components/Immunization/report/National_%20Immunization_Schedule.pdf

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of painless hematuria and occasional urinary tract infections. On examination, she is afebrile, and her bladder is not distended. Intravenous urography (IVU) shows a rounded filling defect at the vesicoureteric junction surrounded by a thin radiolucent halo of contrast, giving a "cobra head" appearance. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient has recurrent urinary symptoms and IVU shows the classic cobra head sign, which is due to a cystic dilatation of the intramural portion of the ureter, seen in ureterocele.
  • Ureterocele can present clinically with recurrent UTIs, hematuria, or can be asymptomatic and detected incidentally.

In this case, the image matches the cobra head sign, confirming a diagnosis of ureterocele.

Vesico-ureteric reflux (Option B): On imaging, shows retrograde filling of ureters and renal pelvis, without the cystic distal ureter dilatation and cobra head appearance. Therefore, incorrect.

Medullary sponge kidney (Option C): Shows bouquet of flowers / paintbrush appearance in the renal medulla, not at the bladder-ureter junction. Therefore, incorrect.

Ureteric duplication (Option D): Shows drooping lily sign- displaced lower pole collecting system and impaired upper pole drainage- which is not seen here. Therefore, incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of homologous genital structures is incorrect?
questions.solution:
• The epoophoron is derived from mesonephric tubules.The appendix of testis, is a remnant of the Müllerian (paramesonephric) duct, not the mesonephric tubules.

Explanation of other options:

  • Granulosa cells - Seminiferous tubules(Option A):Granulosa cells in females are functionally analogous to Sertoli cells and seminiferous tubules in males.
  • Gartner duct - Vas deferens(Option B):Gartner's duct is a remnant of the mesonephric (Wolffian) duct in femalesIn males, the Wolffian duct develops into the vas deferens, epididymis, and seminal vesicles.
  • Paraurethral glands - Prostate glands(Option D): Skene's glands (paraurethral glands) are the female homologues of the prostate gland.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department after collapsing during a village cricket match. He was struck on the head by a cricket ball while batting but initially regained consciousness. Over the next 30 minutes, he became progressively drowsy and then unresponsive. On examination, his BP is 180/110 mmHg, pulse is 58/min, and GCS is 6. He has been intubated and ventilated. Fundoscopy reveals papilloedema. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment to reduce his raised intracranial pressure?
questions.solution:
• Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic that reduces intracranial pressure by drawing water out of the brain parenchyma into the intravascular compartment. It is one of the first-line emergency interventions in raised ICP.
  • This clinical scenario describes Cushing's triad (hypertension + bradycardia + decreased GCS), which is pathognomonic for raised intracranial pressure (ICP).
  • The temporal progression after head trauma and worsening sensorium indicates likely cerebral oedema or expanding haemorrhage, raising intracranial tension.

RAISED INTRACRANIAL TENSION (ICT):

Definition:

  • Raised ICT (Intracranial Hypertension) is defined as an abnormally increased pressure within the cranial vault.
  • Normal ICP range: 5-15 mmHg
  • Raised ICT: >20-25 mmHg → warrants treatment

Causes:

  • Intracranial haemorrhage
  • Brain tumours
  • Head injury/Trauma
  • Meningitis
  • Brain abscess
  • Hydrocephalus
  • Cerebral oedema

Investigations:

  • Neuroimaging (before LP):
    • CT Brain / MRI Brain with gadolinium → to rule out mass lesions (ICSOL)
  • Papilloedema: Critical sign of raised ICP
  • Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in suspected raised ICT → due to risk of brain herniation (coning)

IV alteplase (Option A): This is a thrombolytic agent used for acute ischaemic stroke, not for trauma-induced raised ICT. It may worsen bleeding in this patient.

IV furosemide (Option B): It is not the first choice for reducing cerebral oedema. Osmotic diuretics like mannitol are more effective and act faster in this setting.

IV heparin (Option C): Anticoagulation is contraindicated in patients with possible intracranial haemorrhage or trauma, as it increases the risk of further bleeding.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man presents with fatigue and reddish-brown urine noticed early in the morning. On examination, he has scleral icterus.

Investigations reveal:
1. Haemoglobin: 8.2 g/dL
2. Platelets: 92 x 10⁹/L
3. WBC count: 3.8 x 10⁹/L
4. Total bilirubin: 5.8 mg/dL (Direct: 0.3 mg/dL)
5. Urinalysis: 1 RBC/hpf, positive for haemoglobin
6. Direct Coombs test: Negative
7. Flow cytometry: Shows absence of CD55 and CD59 on RBCs

Which of the following complications is most likely to cause death in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient has Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH):

  • Classical features: fatigue, Coombs-negative hemolytic anaemia, pancytopenia, hemoglobinuria
  • Confirmed by absence of CD55 and CD59 on flow cytometry.
  • Mutation in the PIGA gene → defective GPI anchors → loss of CD55 (decay accelerating factor) and CD59 (MAC inhibitor) on blood cells.
  • Leads to uncontrolled complement activation (especially via the alternative pathway) → intravascular hemolysis and thrombosis.
  • Thrombosis is the leading cause of death in PNH.
  • Common sites: hepatic veins (→ Budd-Chiari syndrome), cerebral veins, portal vein, mesenteric vessels.
  • Hypercoagulable state is driven by complement-coagulation cross-activation (especially C5a-mediated upregulation of tissue factor and inhibition of fibrinolysis).

Sepsis (Option A): While patients with PNH may have cytopenias, the primary cause of mortality is thrombosis, not overwhelming infection.

Myocardial infarction (Option C): Though possible due to thrombosis, coronary artery thrombosis is rare in PNH compared to venous thrombosis in unusual sites like hepatic or cerebral veins.

Intra-abdominal haemorrhage (Option D): PNH patients may have thrombocytopenia, but they do not typically experience fatal bleeding. Haemorrhage is not a major contributor to mortality.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man with known systolic heart failure presents with worsening shortness of breath at rest for the past 3 days. On examination, he appears dyspnoeic with bilateral basal crepitations. He is admitted for acute decompensated heart failure and started on a drug that is a recombinant derivative of a hormone acting via guanylate cyclase-mediated cGMP elevation. The drug reduces pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, promotes natriuresis, and is known to cause dose-dependent hypotension as a side effect. Which of the following hormones is this drug most likely derived from?
questions.solution:
Nesiritide is a recombinant form of B-type (brain) natriuretic peptide (BNP), which is released from ventricles in response to volume overload and wall stretch.

  • Mechanism: Acts on natriuretic peptide receptor A (NPR-A) → ↑ cGMP via guanylate cyclase → vasodilation, natriuresis, and diuresis
  • Clinical use: Acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF)
  • Hemodynamics: ↓ Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP), ↓ systemic vascular resistance, ↑ stroke volume
  • Adverse effect: Hypotension (due to potent vasodilation)

Prostacyclin (Option A) analogues (like epoprostenol) are vasodilators used in pulmonary arterial hypertension, not ADHF. They act via cAMP, not cGMP.

Aldosterone (Option B) is a mineralocorticoid, promoting sodium and water retention - the opposite of what nesiritide does. Drugs like spironolactone block aldosterone in heart failure.

Antidiuretic hormone (Option C): ADH (vasopressin) promotes water reabsorption via V2 receptors in the kidneys, increasing preload - again, opposite to the natriuretic effect of BNP. Vasopressin analogues are not used to treat ADHF.

choices.text: Advanced Epidemiological Triangle with Time Dimension

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to a community clinic with high-grade fever and jaundice following consumption of food at a roadside shop. The community physician is investigating the possible cause of this outbreak using classical epidemiological methods. Which of the following models best explains the interplay between the agent (HAV), the contaminated water source, and the patient's susceptibility due to low immunity?
questions.solution:
• The classical epidemiological triad is used primarily for infectious disease causation.
  • It includes three essential components:
    • Agent: Hepatitis A virus (HAV)
    • Host: Patient's immunity, age, nutritional status
    • Environment: Contaminated water, sanitation, crowding
  • It provides a framework for identifying points of intervention in controlling disease outbreaks.

Models of Disease Causation

Used in:

  • Infectious disease outbreaks (e.g., foodborne hepatitis, malaria, cholera)
  • Focuses on interaction among 3 components
  • Broader applicability beyond infections (e.g., NCDs, accidents)
  • Descriptive epidemiology
  • Focuses on "Who, Where, When"
  • Not a causation model- used to describe patterns
  • Linear, used in infection control protocols

Time-Place-Person (Option B): Describes disease distribution, not causation. Used in descriptive epidemiology, not outbreak modeling.

Chain of Infection (Option C): While correct for infectious control pathways, it is not the standard framework for analyzing interplay among host, agent, and environment in epidemiological analysis.

Advanced Triangle (Option D): More applicable for non-communicable diseases, behavioral and ecological models (e.g., obesity, diabetes, accidents). The clinical case here fits infectious disease best explained by the classic triad.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman is undergoing a total thyroidectomy for papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. During the surgery, the surgeon ligates the inferior thyroid artery close to the gland to preserve the parathyroid glands' blood supply. This artery arises from which of the following vessels?
questions.solution:
• The inferior thyroid artery arises from the thyrocervical trunk, which itself is a branch of the first part of the subclavian artery.
  • In thyroid surgery, preserving its branches is critical because it also supplies the parathyroid glands.
  • The three main arteries supplying the thyroid are:
    • Superior thyroid artery (from external carotid)
    • Inferior thyroid artery (from thyrocervical trunk)
    • Arteria thyroidea ima (if present, from brachiocephalic trunk or aortic arch).

Blood Supply of the Thyroid

  • The inferior thyroid artery is particularly important because it supplies both the thyroid and the parathyroid glands.

These vessels are also relevant during thyroidectomy to avoid excessive bleeding.

External carotid artery (Option A): Gives rise to the superior thyroid artery, not the inferior thyroid artery. Therefore, incorrect.

Internal carotid artery (Option B): Does not give branches to the thyroid gland at all. Therefore, incorrect.

Aorta (Option C): When present, the arteria thyroidea ima arises directly from the brachiocephalic trunk or sometimes from the arch of the aorta, and supplies the thyroid gland. However, the inferior thyroid artery does not originate from the aorta. Therefore, incorrect.

questions.text: In extra amniotic 2nd trimester medico legal termination of pregnancy, which of the following is used?
questions.solution:
In the context of a second-trimester medico-legal termination of pregnancy, particularly via extra-amniotic instillation, the substances used can include:

  • Ethacridine lactate(A) is one such substance used for extra-amniotic termination in the second trimester. It is an antiseptic that has been used for this purpose in certain regions and protocols.
  • Mifepristone(B) is more commonly used for first-trimester medical abortion rather than second-trimester extra-amniotic procedures.
  • Hypertonic saline(C) was historically used for second-trimester terminations but is less commonly used today due to safety concerns.
  • Glucose(D) is not used for this purpose.

Second Trimester (13-20 Weeks)

  • ProstaglandinsPGE1(Misoprostol), 15 methyl PGF2a (Carboprost), PGE2(Dinoprostone) and their analogues (used-intravaginally, intramuscularly or intra-amniotic ally)
  • Dilation and evacuation(13-15 weeks)
  • Extra-amniotic-Ethacridine lactate, Prostaglandins (PGE2,PGF2a)
  • Oxytocin infusionhigh dose used along with either of the above two methods
  • Intrauterine instillation of hyperosmotic solutions, Intra-amniotic hypertonic urea (40%), saline (20%)-seldom used nowadays

Hysterotomy (abdominal) - less commonly done

Methods of Medical Termination of Pregnancy First Trimester (Up to 12 Weeks)

MEDICAL

  • Mifepristone
  • Mifepristone and Misoprostol (PGE1)
  • Methotrexate and Misoprostol
  • Tamoxifen and Misoprostol

Surgical

  • Menstrual regulation
  • Vacuum Aspiration (MVA/EVA)
  • Suction evacuation and/or curettage
  • Dilatation and evacuation:
  • Rapid method
  • Slow method

questions.text: A 38-year-old HIV-positive male presents with nonproductive cough, fever, and progressive dyspnoea for the past week. Chest examination is normal, and he reports close contact with a family member recently treated for pulmonary tuberculosis. His CD4 count is 260 cells/mm³. What would be the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
In HIV-positive patients presenting with nonspecific respiratory symptoms and a history of TB exposure, but no overt findings on chest auscultation, screening tests for latent TB become highly relevant, especially:

  • Interferon Gamma Release Assay (IGRA):
    • High specificity, especially in BCG-vaccinated individuals
    • Not affected by prior BCG
    • Recommended in immunocompromised patients
    • Can detect latent TB infection
  • Tuberculin Skin Test (TST):
    • Lower sensitivity in HIV-positive (especially CD4 < 200), but still useful
    • Cutoff ≥5mm considered positive in HIV
    • Economical and accessible in resource-limited settings

Multiple guidelines (e.g., WHO, CDC, NACO) support using either IGRA or TST, and in many cases both, to maximise sensitivity in immunocompromised hosts when evaluating for latent TB infection.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with jaundice and right upper quadrant discomfort. Laboratory investigations reveal markedly elevated serum AST, ALT, and total bilirubin. A liver biopsy shows extensive hepatocellular necrosis. Which of the following histopathological findings most strongly correlates with this condition?
questions.solution:
• The condition suggests liver cellular injury as the cellular enzymes are elevated.
  • Cell membrane rupture fulfills the criteria for irreversible cell injury, correlating with the clinical picture of jaundice, elevated liver enzymes, and necrosis.
  • AST and ALT are cytoplasmic and mitochondrial enzymes found in hepatocytes.

Clumping of nuclear chromatin (Option A): This is a feature of reversible cell injury, due to decreased ATP and acidosis. It shows early nuclear response to stress, but is not enough to cause enzyme leakage or hepatocellular necrosis, hence not the primary correlation with elevated AST/ALT.

Bleb formation(Option B): This is also seen in reversible injury. The plasma membrane shows blebs (outpouching), but it is still intact. So, enzymes do not leak out in significant quantities. Therefore, this does not correlate with elevated liver enzymes in jaundice.

Swelling of the endoplasmic reticulum(Option C): Also, a sign of reversible injury. It reflects early cellular stress, but the cell is still viable. No rupture of organelles or plasma membrane has occurred, so it does not explain the enzyme elevation.

choices.text: Altered structure of enzymes involved in bacterial DNA winding-unwinding
Altered structure of enzymes involved in bacterial RNA synthesis
Altered structure of bacterial ribosomal proteins

questions.text: A 32-year-old man living with HIV presents with pulmonary tuberculosis and is started on a first-line 4-drug antitubercular therapy. Three weeks later, he returns to the clinic reporting reddish-orange discolouration of his urine and red staining of his contact lenses. A drug susceptibility test reveals resistance to several anti-TB agents. Which of the following mechanisms best explains resistance to the drug responsible for his current symptoms?
questions.solution:
The patient is experiencing rifampicin-induced body fluid discolouration, a classic side effect, along with confirmed rifampicin resistance.

Mechanism of Rifampicin Resistance:

  • Rifampicin binds to the β-subunit of bacterial RNA polymerase, encoded by the rpoB gene.
  • Mutations in the rpoB gene alter the drug-binding site, preventing rifampicin from inhibiting RNA synthesis.
  • This is the most common mechanism of primary rifampicin resistance in Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Drug Resistance Mechanisms in TB:

Mechanism of Resistance (Chromosomal Mutation):

  • M. tuberculosis develops resistance via point mutations, not horizontal gene transfer.
  • For rifampicin, the resistance occurs through mutations in the rpoB gene, altering the RNA polymerase β-subunit.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child undergoes a vision screening examination conducted as part of a school health service. The child has no complaints, but is found to have uncorrected refractive error and is prescribed corrective glasses. Which level of prevention does this screening activity fall under?
questions.solution:
• The child was asymptomatic and diagnosed with an early-stage condition (refractive error) during screening.
  • The objective of the intervention is early detection and prompt treatment to prevent progression or complications.
  • This directly aligns with the definition of secondary prevention.

Screening is a core component of secondary prevention, especially when applied to detect early disease in asymptomatic individuals.

Primordial (Option A): Incorrect. This involves preventing the emergence of risk factors by addressing underlying socioeconomic and environmental determinants. It does not include screening.

Primary (Option B): Incorrect. Primary prevention includes health promotion and specific protection (e.g., immunization, use of safety devices). It does not involve diagnosis or screening.

Tertiary (Option D): Incorrect. Tertiary prevention is aimed at minimizing long-term impairments and restoring function in patients with established disease or disability.

choices.text: One affected patient is a second-degree relative of the other two
Two or more successive generations are affected
Cancer in one or more affected relatives is diagnosed before the age of 50 years
Pathological diagnosis of cancer is verified

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with a strong family history of colorectal and endometrial cancer. Her mother, maternal uncle, and grandmother were diagnosed with cancers of the colon, endometrium, and small intestine, respectively. She is suspected to have Lynch syndrome based on Amsterdam II criteria. Which of the following statements is NOT a part of the Amsterdam II diagnostic criteria for Lynch syndrome?
questions.solution:
• The Amsterdam II criteria (also called the 3-2-1-0 rule) are used to diagnose hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)/Lynch syndrome.
  • The criteria require that at least one of the affected individuals must be a first-degree relative of the other two, not a second-degree relative. Hence, Option A is incorrect and therefore the correct choice in this question.

Features of Colorectal Cancer in HNPCC:

  • Typically occurs at a younger age (mean ~44 years).
  • More common in the proximal (right-sided) colon (about 70%).
  • Tumors often have mucinous or poorly differentiated (including signet ring cell) histology.
  • Increased frequency of synchronous (simultaneous) and metachronous (subsequent) cancers.
  • Despite these aggressive features, patients tend to have a better surgical outcome compared to sporadic cases.

Types:

  • Lynch I syndrome: Early-onset colorectal cancer, usually in the proximal colon, with a strong family history.
  • Lynch II syndrome: Colorectal cancer plus increased risk of extracolonic malignancies including endometrial, ovarian, gastric, small intestine, pancreatic, ureter, and renal pelvic cancers.

These criteria ensure the diagnosis of HNPCC is distinguished from other familial colorectal cancer syndromes.

Two or more successive generations are affected (Option B): This is a mandatory part of the criteria to demonstrate vertical transmission. Therefore, correct.

Cancer in one or more affected relatives is diagnosed before the age of 50 years (Option C): Included in the criteria to emphasize early onset of disease. Therefore, correct.

Pathological diagnosis of cancer is verified (Option D): Verification of tumor diagnosis by pathology is required to confirm the disease. Therefore, correct.

questions.text: Pain during the early (first) stage of labor is primarily transmitted through which of the following dermatomal levels?
questions.solution:
• Pain in the first stage of laboris primarily visceral in origin, caused by uterine contractions and cervical dilation
  • These pain signals are transmitted via sympathetic fibersto the spinal cord segments T10 to L1, which correspond to the lower abdominal and lumbar regions
  • This is why early labor pain is referred to these dermatomes

Explanation of other options:

S1 - S3 (Option B): Somatic pain from perineal stretching in the second stage of labor is transmitted through the pudendal nerve, which originates from S2-S4, not S1-S3

L4 - L5 (Option C): These dermatomes are not involved in visceral afferents for uterine pain and play no significant role in labor pain transmission

L2 - L3 (Option D): These levels do not correspond to the main afferent pathways of the uterus or cervix during labor, thus, not involved in early labor pain

Key Takeaways:

  • T10-L1spinal segments transmit early labor visceral pain
  • Somatic pain in second stageinvolves S2-S4, via the pudendal nerve
  • Accurate knowledge of dermatomes is essential for targeted labor analgesia

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with known chronic liver disease and ascites presents to the Emergency Department with diffuse abdominal pain and tenderness for the past 2 days. He has no history of recent procedures or peritoneal dialysis. On examination, he is febrile and drowsy. Diagnostic paracentesis reveals 600 polymorphonuclear cells/mm³ in ascitic fluid. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) is defined by:

  • Ascitic fluid PMN count ≥250 cells/mm³, with or without culture positivity.
  • Occurs in cirrhotic patients without a secondary intra-abdominal source of infection.
  • 600 PMNs/mm³ is well above the diagnostic threshold.


Tubercular ascites (Option A) is typically associated with lymphocytic predominance, not PMNs. Also, the presentation is more chronic, with low-grade fever, weight loss, and abdominal distension.

Malignant ascites (Option B): It usually presents with high protein, lymphocytic fluid, and low PMN counts. Tumour cells may be seen on cytology, but PMNs >600 are uncommon.

Chylous ascites (Option D): This fluid appears milky, rich in triglycerides (>110 mg/dL), and again has lymphocyte predominance, not neutrophilic.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presented with a 1 cm painless mass in the right breast, lower quadrant. Physical examination revealed a hard, non-tender and mobile lump. Ultrasound performed suggests neoplastic aetiology. Tru-Cut biopsy from the lesion was taken, and the histopathological examination was performed. Based on the above findings, what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Lobular carcinoma is defined by dyscohesive tumour cells infiltrating the stroma in single-file or targetoid patterns, reflecting loss of E-cadherin-mediated adhesion, as seen on biopsy.

The neoplastic cells are small, uniform, and lack tubule formation, lining the stroma individually rather than forming cohesive nests or duct-like structures.

Clinically, lobular carcinoma often presents subtly on imaging and may be multifocal or bilateral, making histologic recognition of its characteristic infiltration pattern essential.

They also have distinctive patterns of metastatic spread, often involving the peritoneum and retroperitoneum, the leptomeninges (carcinomatous meningitis), the gastrointestinal tract, and the ovaries and uterus.

Males and females with heterozygous germline mutations in CDH1 are at increased risk for developing lobular carcinoma and have a greatly increased risk for signet ring carcinoma of the stomach


Invasive ductal carcinoma (Option A): Forms cohesive, angulated glands with a desmoplastic stromal reaction, not the single-file infiltration of lobular carcinoma.

Medullary carcinoma (Option C): Composed of syncytial sheets of high-grade cells with a dense lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate and pushing borders, lacking single-cell cords.

Tubular carcinoma (Option D): Consists almost entirely of well-formed tubules with open lumens and bland cytology, without dyscohesive single-file cells.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man with Alzheimer's disease is brought to the emergency department with abdominal cramps, diarrhea, diaphoresis, and muscle weakness followed by muscle spasms. On evaluation, he is found to have bradycardia (HR 51/min), laboured breathing, hypotension (BP 88/56 mm Hg) and temperature of 38.4°C (101.1°F). His family reports he accidentally ingested multiple doses of his medications in a suicide attempt. He is immediately started on supportive treatment. Most symptoms resolve except for persistent muscle spasms. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
The patient is presenting with a cholinergic toxidrome: salivation, diarrhoea, sweating, bradycardia, muscle spasms, and weakness. These symptoms do not align with anticholinergic poisoning, but instead suggest cholinesterase inhibition, likely due to organophosphate (OP) poisoning, possibly from overdose of Alzheimer's medications like rivastigmine or donepezil (both AChE inhibitors).

  • He had diarrhoea, diaphoresis, muscle fasciculations, bradycardia, which are hallmark muscarinic and nicotinic excess symptoms.
  • Pralidoximereactivates acetylcholinesterase and is used to reverse organophosphate toxicity, which includes excessive cholinergic activity.
  • Muscle spasmsthat persist after initial stabilisation indicate persistent nicotinic stimulation, where pralidoxime is especially effective.
  • This patient has signs of cholinergic excess, not anticholinergic poisoning.
  • Pralidoximeis the correct antidote to relieve nicotinic symptoms (like muscle spasms) in organophosphate or AChE inhibitor overdose.
  • Misidentifying the toxidrome can be fatal; careful clinical evaluation is key.


Carbachol (Option A) is a direct-acting muscarinic agonist, which would worsen the cholinergic toxicity by further stimulating muscarinic receptors.

Physostigmine (Option B) is a reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used in anticholinergic poisoning (e.g., atropine overdose), not in cholinergic crisis. Giving this would worsen symptoms of a cholinergic overdose.

Benztropine (Option C) is an anticholinergic agent used to treat extrapyramidal symptoms (e.g., Parkinsonism or drug-induced dystonia). Giving benztropine in this case would have no therapeutic benefit nd may worsen delirium or cause anticholinergic toxicity.

choices.text: Referral services for sick or undernourished children
Non-formal early childhood care and education
Health education and nutrition counselling for women
Structured classroom-based formal education with assessments

questions.text: A 3½-year-old child regularly visits the Anganwadi centre. Which of the following services is not included under the ICDS scheme?
questions.solution:
• ICDS provides non-formal preschool education for children aged 3-6 years through play-based learning, but it does not include formal classroom teaching or standardized academic assessments.
  • Formal education is under the domain of the Ministry of Education and begins in primary schools, not in Anganwadi centres.
  • Thus, structured formal education is not part of the ICDS service package.

ICDS is implemented by the Ministry of Women and Child Development and focuses on early childhood care and development, but it does not deliver formal school curricula or assessments.

Referral services for malnourished children (Option A): Anganwadi workers refer children with growth faltering or illness to higher-level health facilities. This is an essential ICDS function.

Non-formal preschool education (Option B): ICDS provides non-formal education to 3-6-year-olds through activity-based learning, not academic instruction.

Nutrition counselling and health education for women (Option C): This is a key service provided to mothers, adolescent girls, and women of reproductive age under ICDS.

Reference: https://darpg.gov.in/sites/default/files/ICDS.pdf

choices.text: Most commonly occurs through the superior lumbar triangle
Lumbar hernias can be congenital or acquired
Less commonly occurs through the Grynfelt triangle
Lumbar hernias can be approached by open or laparoscopic surgeries

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a reducible swelling in the left lumbar region, increasing on coughing and straining. Examination reveals a defect in the posterior abdominal wall above the iliac crest. Imaging confirms a lumbar hernia. Which of the following statements about lumbar hernia is NOT true?
questions.solution:
• Lumbar hernias are rare hernias of the posterior abdominal wall, more common on the left side, and usually acquired, though congenital forms exist.
  • They most commonly occur through the superior lumbar triangle (Grynfelt's triangle) and less commonly through the inferior lumbar triangle (Petit's triangle).
  • Surgical repair may be performed via either open or laparoscopic approach, and Dowd's operation is a traditional open repair method.

Features of Lumbar Hernia:

  • More common on the left side.
  • More often acquired than congenital.
  • Most commonly occurs through the superior lumbar triangle (Grynfelt).
  • Less commonly occurs through the inferior lumbar triangle (Petit).
  • Can be repaired with open or laparoscopic techniques.
  • Boundaries of superior lumbar triangle (Grynfelt):
    • 12th rib
    • Paraspinal (erector spinae) muscles
    • Internal oblique muscle
  • Boundaries of inferior lumbar triangle (Petit):
    • Iliac crest
    • Latissimus dorsi muscle
    • External oblique muscle

Most commonly occurs through the superior lumbar triangle (Option A): Superior lumbar triangle (Grynfelt) is the most common site of lumbar hernia. Therefore, correct.

Lumbar hernias can be congenital or acquired (Option B): Both forms are seen, though acquired is more common. Therefore, correct.

Lumbar hernias can be approached by open or laparoscopic surgeries (Option D): Both surgical approaches are valid and routinely used. Therefore, correct.

questions.text: In a case of direct occipitoposterior position (face to pubis delivery) most commonly encountered problem is:
questions.solution:
• In direct occipitoposterior (OP) position, the fetal head delivers with the face toward the pubic symphysis(face-to-pubis), requiring maximum perineal distension
  • This leads to a high risk of complete perineal tearsinvolving the vaginal wall, perineal body, and anal sphincter complex.
  • Intracranial injuryis rare and not specific to OP deliveries (Option A eliminated)
  • Cephalhematomaoccurs due to pressure over parietal bones, more common in instrumental or prolonged labours, not specific to OP (Option B eliminated)
  • Paraurethral tearsmay occur, but they are less severe and not the most common complication in face-to-pubis delivery (Option C eliminated)

Key Takeaways:

  • Face-to-pubis deliverystretches the perineum maximally
  • Complete perineal tearsare the most common and serious complication
  • Careful perineal support and episiotomy may help reduce tear severity

questions.text:
A 22-year-old woman with poorly controlled type 1 diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department with a fever, severe dehydration, and altered sensorium. She has been feeling unwell for 2 days and has missed insulin doses. On examination, she is drowsy, hypotensive, and tachypnoeic with Kussmaul breathing. Her laboratory values are:

What is the most important initial treatment?
questions.solution:
This is a classic case of Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA), supported by:

  • High anion gap metabolic acidosis(HCO- = 6 mmol/L, H+ = 80 nmol/L → pH ≈ 7.1)
  • Hyperglycaemia, dehydration, and altered mental status
  • Typical history of insulin omission and infection (fever)

  • DKA causes severe volume depletion(deficit of 6-9L)
  • Rehydration improves tissue perfusion, lowers counter-regulatory hormones(e.g., glucagon, catecholamines)
  • Helps initiate renal clearance of ketones
  • Improves insulin sensitivity

Intravenous antibiotics (Option A): Although infection may be a trigger, it is not the first step in DKA management. Fluid resuscitation and stabilisation take priority.

Intravenous bicarbonate (Option B): Bicarbonate is not routinely indicated unless the pH is <6.9. It may worsen hypokalaemia and cerebral oedema if given unnecessarily.

Intravenous insulin (Option D): Insulin is essential, but not the immediate first step. Administering insulin before fluids can cause rapid osmotic shifts, hypotension, and risk of cerebral oedema.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with several enlarged lymph nodes in his left supraclavicular region. Physical examination reveals painless lymphadenopathy in this region. No other abnormalities are found. A biopsy from one of these enlarged lymph nodes, which is shown in the associated picture, reveals effacement of the normal lymph-node architecture by numerous nodules of uniform size that are found crowded within the cortex and medulla of the lymph node. Tingible body macrophages are not seen in these nodules. Which one of the listed chromosomal translocations is most closely associated with this type of lymphoma?
questions.solution:
• The patient has painless supraclavicular lymphadenopathy, typical of non-Hodgkin lymphoma
  • Histology reveals nodular architecture, monotonous B cells, and absence of tingible body macrophages, consistent with follicular lymphoma
  • Follicular lymphoma is a nodular B-cell neoplasm derived from germinal center B cells, often involving both cortex and medulla
  • The hallmark genetic abnormality is t(14;18) translocation → leads to overexpression of BCL2, an anti-apoptotic protein
  • BCL2 overexpression prevents apoptosis of germinal center B cells, contributing to lymphoma pathogenesis

t(2;8) (Option A): Associated with Burkitt lymphoma, not follicular lymphoma

t(8;22) (Option B): Also, a translocation seen in Burkitt lymphoma

t(9;14) (Option C): Seen in lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma, not follicular subtype

Key Takeaways:

  • Follicular lymphoma= nodular, B-cell, painless lymphadenopathy
  • t(14;18)→ BCL2 overexpression → inhibits apoptosis
  • Histology lacks tingible body macrophages, and shows uniform nodules

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a history of heroin abuse is enrolled in a de-addiction programme. He complains of severe opioid withdrawal symptoms including muscle aches, anxiety, insomnia, and intense cravings. To manage his condition, a long-acting opioid agonist is prescribed to reduce cravings and prevent relapse. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Methadone is the correct answer because:

  • It is a long-acting, full mu-opioid receptor agonistused in the maintenance treatment of opioid use disorder (OUD).
  • Methadone prevents withdrawal symptoms, reduces cravings, and blocks euphoric effectsof shorter-acting opioids like heroin.
  • Unlike other opioids, methadone's long half-life (24-36 hrs)allows once-daily dosing, making it effective for substitution therapy.
  • It does not produce euphoriaat maintenance doses, enabling patients to stabilise and engage in rehabilitation.

Methadone in Opioid Abuse and Poisoning:

Pharmacology:

  • Mechanism:Full agonist at mu-opioid receptor; NMDA antagonist; serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor.
  • Clinical Utility:Used for both chronic pain and opioid use disorder.

Use in Opioid Dependence:

  • Used as opioid substitution therapyin medically supervised programmes.
  • Prevents illicit drug use by:
    • Reducing withdrawal symptoms
    • Decreasing cravings
    • Blocking reinforcementfrom other opioids

Dosing and Monitoring:

  • Oral bioavailability: 60-70%
  • Metabolism: Hepatic (CYP2B6, CYP3A4)
  • Requires careful titrationto avoid overdose.

Methadone Overdose:

  • Causes prolonged respiratory depressiondue to long half-life.
  • Treated with naloxone, but repeat dosing may be needed due to re-narcotisation.

MAO Inhibitors (Option A) are antidepressants used in atypical depression. They have no role in opioid abuse treatment, and combining them with opioids may lead to serotonin syndrome.

Corticosteroids (Option C): are anti-inflammatory drugs used in autoimmune, allergic, and inflammatory conditions - they do not alleviate withdrawal or reduce cravings in opioid use disorder.

Loperamide (Option D): Although it is an opioid, it acts only on peripheral mu-receptors in the gut and is used as an anti-diarrhoeal. It does not cross the blood-brain barrier, and cannot treat central opioid withdrawal symptoms.

Key Takeaways:

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida in her second trimester is counseled during an antenatal clinic visit regarding her nutritional requirements. She has been compliant with iron and folic acid but has doubts regarding iodine intake. What is the recommended daily allowance (RDA) of iodine during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• The iodine requirement increases during pregnancy due to:
    • Increased renal clearance
    • Increased maternal thyroid hormone production
    • Transfer to the developing fetus
  • According to the ICMR 2020 guidelines and NIN data:
    • RDA for iodine during pregnancy is 250 mcg/day
  • This amount supports both maternal and fetal thyroid function and neurodevelopment.

100 mcg (Option A): Incorrect. This is below the minimum daily requirement even for non-pregnant adults. It is inadequate for fetal neurological development.

150 mcg (Option B): Incorrect. This is the requirement for non-pregnant women. Pregnancy requires an increased intake due to higher metabolic demand and fetal needs.

200 mcg (Option C):Incorrect. Although closer to the requirement, it still falls short of the recommended 250 mcg/day needed during pregnancy.

Reference: ICMR-National Institute of Nutrition (NIN), 2020: Recommended Dietary Allowances for Indians- https://www.nin.res.in/downloads/DietaryGuidelinesforNINwebsite.pdf

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents with a painless, slow-growing mass over the angle of her mandible. On examination, she has a firm, non-tender parotid swelling. Fine-needle aspiration cytology reveals a malignant salivary gland neoplasm with low-grade histologic features. Which of the following is classified as a low-grade malignant tumour of the salivary gland?
questions.solution:
Grading of Salivary Gland Tumours:

  • Malignant salivary gland tumours are classified into low-grade, intermediate-grade, and high-grade based on their histologic features, biological behaviour, and prognosis.
  • Low-grade tumours grow slowly, show minimal invasion, and have a favourable prognosis.
  • Intermediate-grade tumours have moderate aggressiveness.
  • High-grade tumours are rapidly growing, invasive, and carry a poor prognosis.
  • Among these, acinic cell carcinoma is a low-grade malignancy, most commonly found in the parotid gland, and is associated with a good long-term survival rate.


Pleomorphic adenoma (Option B): The most common benign neoplasm of the salivary gland; not malignant and not graded. Therefore, incorrect.

Warthin's tumour (Option C): A benign tumour that appears as a hot spot on Tc-99m scan; not malignant. Therefore, incorrect.

Squamous cell carcinoma (Option D): A high-grade, aggressive, poorly prognostic malignant tumour of salivary glands. Therefore, incorrect.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida delivers a healthy newborn via spontaneous vaginal delivery. Within minutes after placental delivery, she begins to bleed heavily per vaginam. On examination, the uterus is enlarged, soft, and poorly contracted. What is the most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient develops heavy vaginal bleeding immediately after placental delivery, and the uterus is described as enlarged, soft, and poorly contracted-this triad is characteristic of an atonic uterus. Under normal conditions, uterine contraction compresses the bleeding vessels; when this does not occur, hemorrhage continues unchecked.

Uterine atony is the most common cause of primary postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), accounting for nearly 70-80%of cases. It refers to the failure of the uterus to contract adequately after delivery, leading to continued bleeding from the uterine vessels at the placental site.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

APH (Option B):

  • Antepartum hemorrhagerefers to bleeding before delivery, not after.
  • It includes conditions like placenta previaand placental abruption, not relevant to postpartum

Injury to birth canal (Option C):

  • Trauma (e.g., lacerations of the cervix, vagina, or perineum) can cause PPH, especially when the uterus is firm.
  • However, in this case, the uterus is soft and boggy, pointing away from trauma.

DIC (Option D):

  • Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation is a rare causeof PPH.
  • It usually follows obstetric complications like abruption, amniotic fluid embolism, or severe preeclampsia.
  • It would typically present with bleeding from multiple sites and abnormal coagulation profile, not just uterine bleeding.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with nasal crusting, haematuria, and dyspnoea. On examination, he has sinus tenderness and bilateral lung infiltrates on chest X-ray. Urinalysis reveals RBC casts and proteinuria. Serum studies show positive c-ANCA (PR3-ANCA). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis is a necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis affecting:

  • Upper respiratory tract(sinusitis, nasal ulcers)
  • Lower respiratory tract(nodules, infiltrates, haemoptysis)
  • Kidneys(rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis)

It is strongly associated with PR3-ANCA (c-ANCA) positivity.




Goodpasture syndrome (Option A): Although it presents with pulmonary-renal syndrome, it is associated with anti-GBM antibodies, not ANCA. Also, it lacks upper respiratory involvement or granulomas.

Microscopic polyangiitis (Option B): While it causes RPGN and pulmonary symptoms, it lacks granulomatous inflammation and upper airway disease. It is associated with p-ANCA (MPO-ANCA), not c-ANCA.

Churg-Strauss syndrome (Option D): It also features granulomatous vasculitis, but is associated with asthma, peripheral eosinophilia, and p-ANCA, not c-ANCA. The patient does not report asthma or eosinophilia.

questions.text: Match the following components of the immune system with their corresponding class of MHC molecule:
questions.solution:
• MHC I → CD8+ → Intracellular
  • MHC II → CD4+ → Extracellular
  • MHC III → Complement + Cytokines, not antigen presentation

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4426292

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman delivers a healthy baby vaginally at a district hospital. The labor room is cleaned post-delivery, and waste materials such as the placenta, blood-soaked gauze and cotton, and a used blood bag are generated. According to the Biomedical Waste Management Rules, 2016 (Amended 2018), which of the following color-coded bags should be used to discard this waste?
questions.solution:
• The placenta is categorized as human anatomical waste, the blood-soaked gauze and cotton as soiled waste, and the used blood bag as microbiology/laboratory waste.
  • All three types are listed under yellow bag waste as per the Biomedical Waste Management (BMWM).
  • These rules mandate segregation of biomedical waste into specific color-coded categories for safe disposal and environmental protection.

References:

  1. Biomedical Waste Management Rules, 2016 (amended 2018) - https://cpcb.nic.in/uploads/projects/bio-medical-waste/guidelines_healthcare_june_2018.pdf

choices.text: Fasciotomy can be performed after 24 hours of entrapment
Prolonged muscle compression results in a reperfusion injury after rescue
Myoglobinuria contributes to renal failure through tubular obstruction
High-volume mannitol-alkaline diuresis up to 8 liters/day is recommended

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is rescued after being trapped under rubble for 7 hours following an earthquake. Examination reveals a cold, swollen, blistered, and pulseless right leg. His urine is dark brown, and serum creatinine is elevated. Which of the following statements about his condition is incorrect?
questions.solution:
• This patient has developed crush syndrome, which occurs after prolonged compression of skeletal muscle, leading to ischemia, necrosis, and systemic release of intracellular contents.
  • When the compression is released, reperfusion exacerbates injury by releasing accumulated toxins into circulation.
  • Myoglobin released from damaged muscle precipitates in renal tubules, causing acute tubular necrosis and renal failure.
  • Fasciotomy is beneficial in acute compartment syndrome (ACS) if done early. However, after 24 hours, in crush syndrome, muscle is already necrotic and fasciotomy becomes harmful due to infection risk.

Crush Syndrome:

  • Definition: Systemic effects of extensive muscle necrosis from prolonged compression.
  • Etiology: Earthquake injuries, vehicle entrapment, industrial accidents.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Ischemia and myonecrosis → release of potassium, phosphate, myoglobin → reperfusion injury upon rescue.
    • Myoglobin precipitates in renal tubules → acute kidney injury (AKI).
  • Clinical Features:
    • Pulseless, swollen, cold, blistered limb.
    • Dark (tea-colored) urine due to myoglobinuria.
    • Hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, elevated creatinine.
  • Management:
    • Early, aggressive hydration with mannitol-alkaline diuresis (up to 8 L/day).
    • Early correction of hyperkalemia and acidosis.
    • Dialysis if required.
    • Fasciotomy contraindicated after 24 hours.

Prolonged muscle compression results in a reperfusion injury after rescue (Option B): Ischemic tissue releases toxic metabolites into circulation when blood flow is restored, worsening systemic injury. Therefore, correct.

Myoglobinuria contributes to renal failure through tubular obstruction (Option C): Myoglobin precipitates in renal tubules, leading to acute tubular necrosis and AKI. Therefore, correct.

High-volume mannitol-alkaline diuresis up to 8 liters/day is recommended (Option D): Aggressive hydration with alkaline diuresis helps flush myoglobin and prevent renal damage. Therefore, correct.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman delivers a term baby after a prolonged labor requiring oxytocin augmentation. Following delivery, she develops heavy vaginal bleeding. On examination, the uterus is soft, enlarged, and poorly contracted. Which of the following is a risk factor for development of an atonic uterus?
questions.solution:
Uterine atony is the most common cause of primary postpartum hemorrhage, resulting from the uterus's failure to contract adequately after delivery. Multiple factors can predispose to uterine atony, including maternal, fetal, and labor-related conditions.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Age < 20 years (Option A):

Young maternal age is not a recognized risk factor for uterine atony. In fact, advanced maternal age (>35 years) is more commonly associated with PPH risk.

Postdate pregnancy (Option B):

Post-term pregnancy can be associated with larger babies and induction of labor, but it is not an independent risk factor for uterine atony.

All of the above (Option D):

Incorrect because only Option C (BMI > 35) is a well-established risk factor. The other options do not independently contribute to the risk of uterine atony.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida with a known cardiac murmur is evaluated during her second trimester of pregnancy. On auscultation, the intensity of the murmur is noted to have decreased compared to pre-pregnancy examinations. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cardiac lesion?
questions.solution:
• Pregnancy with known murmur: Suggests a chronic valvular lesion.
  • Diminished murmur intensity during pregnancy: This is characteristic of regurgitant lesions, particularly aortic or mitral regurgitation, due to pregnancy-induced ↓ systemic vascular resistance (afterload).
  • Among all the given choices, only AR typically shows a decrease in murmur intensity during pregnancy.

Aortic Regurgitation (AR):

Definition:

Aortic regurgitation is the backflow of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle during diastole, due to incompetence of the aortic valve.

Causes:

  • Primary valvular:
    • Rheumatic fever
    • Bicuspid aortic valve
    • Infective endocarditis
    • Degenerative disease
  • Aortic root pathology:
    • Aortic dissection
    • Marfan syndrome
    • Hypertension
    • Syphilitic aortitis

Pathophysiology:

  • The left ventricle undergoes eccentric hypertrophy and dilatation to accommodate the regurgitant volume.
  • Over time, this leads to systolic dysfunction and heart failure if untreated.

Clinical Features:

  • Often asymptomatic for years in chronic AR
  • Later symptoms: exertional dyspnoea, fatigue, orthopnoea, palpitations
  • Physical signs:
    • Early diastolic decrescendo murmur at the left sternal border
    • Wide pulse pressure, bounding pulses (Corrigan's pulse)
    • Head bobbing (de Musset sign), water hammer pulse (Collapsing pulse)

Effect of Pregnancy:

  • ↓ Systemic vascular resistance during pregnancy → ↓ regurgitant volume → softer murmur
  • AR is usually well-tolerated in pregnancy unless already decompensated

Diagnosis:

  • Echocardiography (gold standard): Confirms valve morphology, regurgitant volume, and LV function

Management:

  • Chronic compensated AR: Medical management with vasodilators (if hypertensive), regular monitoring
  • Severe symptomatic AR or LV dysfunction: Requires valve replacement

Key Takeaways:

  • Regurgitant murmurs (AR, MR) may decrease in intensity during pregnancy due to reduced peripheral vascular resistance.
  • Stenotic lesions (AS, MS) tend to worsen during pregnancy due to increased blood volume and cardiac output.
  • Cardiovascular adaptation in pregnancy can alter the presentation of pre-existing heart conditions.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with progressive bilateral pedal oedema. Urinalysis reveals massive proteinuria, and serum biochemistry shows hypoalbuminemia and hyperlipidemia. Renal biopsy with silver stain demonstrates subepithelial immune complex deposits with a "spike and dome" appearance on light microscopy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Membranous Nephropathy (MN) stands out due to its classical:

  • "Spike and dome" appearance: Subepithelial immune deposits alternating with projections of GBM seen on silver stains.
  • Nephrotic presentation: Massive proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, oedema, and hyperlipidaemia.
  • Common in older adults, especially males.

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) (Option B) is a nephritic syndrome, not nephrotic. It typically shows subepithelial "hump-shaped" deposits, with hypercellular glomeruli on LM, and presents with haematuria, hypertension, and mild oedema, not classical spike and dome or massive proteinuria.

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) (Option C) presents with acute nephritic features (e.g., oliguria, haematuria, rapid loss of renal function) and shows crescent formation on LM, not subepithelial deposits or nephrotic syndrome.

Goodpasture's syndrome (Option D) is a type of anti-GBM disease, presenting with pulmonary haemorrhage and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. On IF, it shows linear deposition of IgG along GBM. It is nephritic, not nephrotic, and does not show spike and dome.

choices.text: The drug will be more ionised at blood pH than at gastric pH
Urinary alkalinisation with sodium bicarbonate can enhance excretion
The drug is mostly unionised in acidic environments like the stomach
Urinary acidification with ammonium chloride accelerates drug excretion

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought to the Emergency Department after ingesting a large quantity of an unknown drug "X", which is a weak acid with a pKa of 4.0. On examination, the heart rate is 130/min, blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 30/min. Arterial blood gas shows metabolic acidosis. The drug is known to be lipid-soluble in its unionised form and is excreted renally. Which of the following statements regarding the management of this overdose is INCORRECT?
questions.solution:
Urinary acidification traps weak bases, not weak acids.

In the case of weak acids like drug "X", alkalinisation of urine increases ionisation, reduces renal tubular reabsorption, and enhances excretion.

  • Ammonium chloride (NH4Cl) acidifies urine → causes weak acids to become more unionised → they get reabsorbed, not excreted.
  • Hence, acidifying urine impairs excretion of weak acids.

Henderson-Hasselbalch equation:

Interpretation:

  • When [A-] = [HA], then log(1) = 0 → so pH = pKa
  • When [A-] > [HA], pH > pKa → solution is more basic
  • When [A-] < [HA], pH < pKa → solution is more acidic

For weak acids:

  • In alkaline pH, ratio shifts to more A- (ionised).
  • Ionised form is water soluble, trapped in urine, excreted more.

The drug will be more ionised at blood pH than at gastric pH (Option A): Because drug "X" is a weak acid with pKa 4.0:

  • In the stomach (pH ~1-2) → pH < pKa → drug remains mostly unionised (HA form).
  • In blood (pH ~7.4) → pH > pKa → drug shifts to ionised form (A-), water-soluble.
  • Thus, the drug is more ionised in blood than in the acidic gastric environment.

Urinary alkalinisation with sodium bicarbonate can enhance excretion (Option B):

Alkaline urine (from NaHCO3):

  • Increases ionisation of weak acids → reduces reabsorption in renal tubules.
  • Enhances urinary excretion (used in salicylate or phenobarbital overdose). Hence, this is a valid treatment strategy.

The drug is mostly unionised in acidic environments like the stomach (Option C): At low pH (acidic stomach):

  • Weak acid remains protonated (HA) → unionised.
  • Unionised form is lipid-soluble, readily absorbed across membranes.
  • So this pharmacokinetic behaviour is expected and correct.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a strong family history of breast and ovarian cancer. Genetic testing reveals a germline mutation in a tumor suppressor gene located on the long arm of chromosome 17. Her tumor is poorly differentiated and negative for ER, PR, and Her2 receptors (triple-negative). Which of the following genes is most likely implicated?
questions.solution:
• BRCA1 and BRCA2 are tumor suppressor genes implicated in hereditary breast cancer.
  • BRCA1 is located on chromosome 17, whereas BRCA2 is on chromosome 13.
  • BRCA1-associated breast cancers tend to be:
    • Poorly differentiated
    • Triple-negative (ER-, PR-, Her2-)
    • More likely to present at an earlier age
    • Associated with ovarian, colon, and prostate cancers.
  • BRCA2-associated cancers, in contrast, are often:
    • Well-differentiated
    • ER/PR positive
    • More strongly associated with male breast cancer, pancreas, gallbladder, stomach, and melanoma.

BRCA2 (Option B): Although also associated with breast cancer, particularly male breast cancer and ER-positive tumors, it is located on chromosome 13 and typically shows well-differentiated, hormone receptor-positive tumors - not the triple-negative, poorly differentiated profile described here.

PTEN (Option C): PTEN mutations are seen in Cowden syndrome, which increases the risk of breast, thyroid, and endometrial cancers, but the clinical picture here is specific to BRCA1.

KRAS (Option D): KRAS is an oncogene associated with pancreatic, lung, and colorectal cancers, not directly with familial breast cancer.

choices.text: Heart rate divided by Mean arterial pressure
Heart rate divided by Diastolic blood pressure
Heart rate divided by Systolic blood pressure
Heart rate divided by Pulmonary arterial pressure

questions.text: Obstetric shock Index (OSI) is calculated by:
questions.solution:
Obstetric Shock Index (OSI) is an adaptation of the traditional Shock Index (SI) used specifically in pregnant or postpartum women to assess hemodynamic status.

  • Shock Index (SI) = Heart Rate / Systolic Blood Pressure It helps detect early hypovolemia, such as from postpartum hemorrhage, even before hypotension becomes evident.

Explanation of Incorrect options:

Heart rate divided by Mean arterial pressure (Option A):

MAP is not used in the standard OSI calculation. It involves more complex measurements and is not as sensitive for early detection of shock.

Heart rate divided by Diastolic blood pressure (Option B):

Diastolic BP does not accurately reflect central perfusion status on its own and is not used in shock index assessments.

Heart rate divided by Pulmonary arterial pressure (Option D):

Pulmonary artery pressure is not routinely measured in obstetric settings and is irrelevant for shock index calculation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, 3 months postpartum, presents with tiredness, amenorrhoea, and failure to lactate. She reports a history of postpartum haemorrhage requiring blood transfusion during delivery. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Sheehan's syndrome classically presents with:

  • Postpartum amenorrhoea
  • Failure to lactate
  • History of severe PPH with hypotension
  • Occurring weeks to months postpartum

Sheehan's Syndrome:

Definition:

Sheehan's syndrome is ischemic necrosis of the pituitary gland following severe postpartum haemorrhage, leading to hypopituitarism.

Pathophysiology:

  • During pregnancy, the pituitary gland enlarges, but its blood supply does not increase proportionally.
  • Hypotension or shock due to massive haemorrhage causes pituitary infarction.
  • There may also be a secondary autoimmune process sustaining the damage.
  • Other signs: pale skin, loss of axillary/pubic hair, low BP

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical history: PPH + agalactia + amenorrhoea
  • Hormonal assays: ↓ ACTH, TSH, LH/FSH, PRL, GH
  • MRI: May show empty or partially empty sella

Management:

  • Lifelong hormone replacement therapy (thyroxine, steroids, oestrogen/progestin ± GH)
  • Early diagnosis prevents life-threatening adrenal crisis

Empty sella syndrome (Option A): It refers to a radiologic finding where the sella turcica is partially or completely filled with CSF, flattening the pituitary. It may be asymptomatic or associated with mild hypopituitarism but lacks acute postpartum onset or agalactia.

Nelson's syndrome (Option B): It occurs in patients with Cushing's disease who undergo bilateral adrenalectomy, leading to unopposed ACTH secretion and pituitary tumour enlargement. This case has no history of Cushing's or adrenal surgery.

Lymphocytic hypophysitis (Option C): It occurs mostly in late pregnancy or early postpartum, involves autoimmune inflammation, and presents with headache, visual symptoms, and pituitary mass effect. It may cause hypopituitarism, but PPH and agalactia are not classic features.

questions.text: Activation of proapoptotic proteins by BH3-only sensors, possibly direct activation of caspases. Which of the following pathological conditions correlates with this mechanism of apoptosis?
questions.solution:
Activation of proapoptotic proteins by BH3-only sensors, possibly direct activation of caspases, refers to the intrinsic (mitochondrial) pathway of apoptosis, regulated by the BCL-2 family of proteins, especially BH3-only proteins (e.g., BIM, BID, PUMA, NOXA).

These proteins sense cellular stress or damage and promote apoptosis by:

  • Activating pro-apoptotic proteins like BAX and BAK
  • Inhibiting anti-apoptotic proteins like BCL-2, BCL-XL
  • Leading to mitochondrial outer membrane permeabilization (MOMP)
  • Which releases cytochrome c, triggering the caspase cascade

DNA damage (Option A): p53 detects DNA damage and activates BH3-only proteins (like PUMA, NOXA), triggering intrinsic apoptosis via BAX/BAK.

Viral infection (Option B): Some viruses inhibit anti-apoptotic BCL-2 proteins; others activate pro-apoptotic BH3-only proteins to eliminate infected cells.

Accumulation of misfolded proteins (Option C): In ER stress (e.g., in neurodegenerative diseases), misfolded proteins activate the unfolded protein response (UPR), which can trigger BH3-only proteins (e.g., BIM) and lead to apoptosis.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents with progressive bilateral leg swelling for the past 2 months. His blood pressure is 145/95 mm Hg, and he was recently started on antihypertensive therapy 3 months ago. On examination, bilateral pitting pedal oedema (+2) is observed. He has no history of liver, heart, or renal disease. Which of the following antihypertensive medications is most likely responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
Amlodipine, a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker (CCB), is a well-known cause of dose-dependent peripheral oedema, especially involving lower limbs.

This is due to preferential arteriolar vasodilation without equivalent venodilation, resulting in:

  • Increased capillary hydrostatic pressure
  • Fluid extravasation into interstitial space
  • Bilateral pitting oedema, particularly in dependent areas

Edema typically begins within weeks to months of initiating therapy, matching this patient's timeline.

Losartan (Option A) is an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) that does not cause peripheral edema and in fact, can reduce CCB-induced edema when used in combination.

Hydrochlorothiazide (Option B) is a thiazide diuretic that typically reduces edema and lowers BP by promoting sodium and water excretion. It would not cause new-onset pedal edema.

Propranolol (Option D) is a non-selective beta blocker that works by reducing cardiac output and renin secretion, but is not commonly associated with peripheral edema as a side effect.

questions.text: During a supervisory visit to a rural immunization center, a public health officer finds repeated power failures affecting the vaccine refrigerator. He decides to prioritize protection of vaccines that are highly sensitive to heat but not damaged by freezing. Based on heat and freeze sensitivity, which vaccine is the most critical to monitor?
questions.solution:
• OPV (Oral Polio Vaccine) is classified as Group A, the most heat-sensitive vaccine.
  • Despite this, OPV is not damaged by freezing, which is a unique and important property.
  • Therefore, it is the most vulnerable to heat but safe in freezing - requiring the most strict cold chain monitoring in hot climates.

Heat Sensitivity of Vaccines

(From most to least heat-sensitive)

The heat sensitivity of vaccines determines how quickly they lose potency when exposed to elevated temperatures. This classification helps in ensuring appropriate cold chain maintenance during storage and transportation.

Freeze Sensitivity of Vaccines

Certain vaccines are highly susceptible to damage from freezing, as this can denature protein antigens or disrupt aluminum-based adjuvants, leading to loss of potency.

Order of Freeze Sensitivity

(From most to least sensitive):

  • DTaP (Diphtheria, Tetanus, acellular Pertussis)
  • Pentavalent (DPT + HepB + Hib)
  • Hepatitis B (HepB)
  • Haemophilus influenzae type b - liquid form (Hib-liquid)
  • Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV)
  • Tetanus (T)/ Diphtheria and Tetanus (DT)/ dT (adult diphtheria and tetanus)

Vaccines Not Affected by Freezing

These vaccines retain their efficacy even when accidentally frozen, as they are typically lyophilized (freeze-dried) or live-attenuated in nature.

Vaccines Stable to Freezing:

  • Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV)
  • Bacillus Calmette-Guerin (BCG)
  • Yellow Fever
  • Measles, Mumps, Rubella (MMR)
  • Rabies
  • Japanese Encephalitis (JE- Live and Inactivated)
  • Hib (Freeze-dried)
  • Rotavirus (Freeze-dried)
  • Varicella Zoster

MMR (Option A): Group C; not as heat-sensitive as OPV but also freeze-stable.

DTaP (Option B): Group D; less heat-sensitive and damaged by freezing.

Pentavalent (Option C): Group D; also freeze-sensitive, less heat-sensitive than OPV.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with recurrent, refractory peptic ulcers despite appropriate proton pump inhibitor therapy. Endoscopy shows multiple ulcers in the duodenum and jejunum. His gastric pH is found to be <2.0 and basal acid output (BAO) >15 mEq/hour. Further testing shows markedly elevated serum gastrin. What level of serum gastrin would confirm the diagnosis of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES) is a gastrin-secreting tumor (gastrinoma) that causes hypergastrinemia and gastric acid hypersecretion.
  • According to diagnostic criteria:
    • Gastric pH ≤2.5
    • Serum gastrin >1000 pg/mL (normal: <100 pg/mL) confirms ZES.
    • Basal acid output (BAO) >15 mEq/hour (or >5 mEq/hour if prior peptic ulcer surgery) further supports the diagnosis.
  • When diagnosis is uncertain (e.g., gastrin is elevated but <1000 pg/mL), provocative tests like the secretin stimulation test can be used:
    • A rise in serum gastrin >200 pg/mL above baseline after secretin administration is diagnostic.
  • Other provocative tests include:
    • Calcium stimulation test
    • Secretin + calcium test
    • Bombesin test
    • Protein meal test

100 pg/mL (Option A): This is within the upper limit of normal. Not diagnostic of ZES.

100-500 pg/mL (Option B): Mildly elevated gastrin levels, but can also be seen in conditions like atrophic gastritis or chronic PPI use; not diagnostic without provocative testing.

500-1000 pg/mL (Option C): Moderately elevated gastrin may suggest ZES but is not confirmatory; provocative tests would be required.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida at 10 weeks of gestation is incidentally found to have a 6 cm ovarian cyst with suspicious features on routine first-trimester ultrasound. She is asymptomatic and has no adnexal tenderness. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
In pregnancy, adnexal masses >5 cm with suspicious features should be monitored initially and, if persistent, surgical removal is recommended in the second trimester.

In the second trimester:

  • Lower miscarriage risk compared to the first trimester.
  • Luteal function has transitioned to placental progesterone production by 12-14 weeks, reducing the risk of pregnancy loss.

Management Of Ovarian Cyst during Pregnancy:

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4402440/

choices.text: It is a form of pericarditis occurring after myocardial infarction
It is mediated by an autoimmune process
It typically presents within 2-10 weeks post-MI
NSAIDs and corticosteroids are the first-line treatment initially

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the OPD with pleuritic chest pain, low-grade fever, and increasing fatigue. He had an acute anterior wall myocardial infarction (MI) four weeks ago, for which he was managed with percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). On examination, a pericardial friction rub is heard. Investigations reveal elevated ESR and CRP. Echocardiography shows a small pericardial effusion. Which of the following statements regarding this patient's condition is NOT TRUE?
questions.solution:
• NSAIDs are the first-line treatment.
  • Corticosteroids are NOT used initially due to risk of delayed myocardial healing and increased recurrence.
  • Steroids are reserved for:
    • Refractory cases
    • NSAID intolerance
    • Recurrence

Dressler Syndrome (Post-MI Pericarditis):

  • Definition: A delayed autoimmune-mediated pericarditis that occurs after injury to myocardial tissue (usually MI)
  • Pathophysiology: Autoimmune reaction to myocardial antigens released after infarction
  • Timing: Usually 2-10 weeks post-MI (can vary)
  • Symptoms:
    • Fever, pleuritic chest pain
    • Malaise, dyspnoea
  • Signs:
    • Pericardial rub
    • Pericardial/pleural effusion
    • Elevated ESR/CRP
  • ECG: Often nonspecific; may or may not show typical diffuse ST elevation
  • Treatment:
    • First-line: NSAIDs ± colchicine
    • Second-line (refractory): Corticosteroids

It is a form of pericarditis occurring after myocardial infarction (Option A):

  • Dressler syndrome is a type of secondary pericarditis that follows myocardial infarction (MI), often classified under post-cardiac injury syndromes (PCIS).
  • It occurs due to inflammation of the pericardium triggered by immune response to necrotic myocardial tissue.

It is mediated by an autoimmune process (Option B):.

  • The underlying mechanism of Dressler syndrome is believed to be autoimmune, triggered by myocardial antigens released during infarction.
  • The immune system attacks pericardial tissue mistakenly due to antigenic mimicry.

It typically presents within 2-10 weeks post-MI (Option C):

  • Dressler syndrome typically develops between 2-10 weeks after an MI, though the onset may vary.
  • This timing helps distinguish it from early post-infarction pericarditis, which usually occurs within the first 72 hours.

questions.text: A 59-year-old chronic smoker presents with shortness of breath associated with hemoptysis and a productive cough. He reports weight loss, and examination showed digital clubbing. Chest radiograph revealed a mass in the right lung apex, from which a biopsy was taken. The histopathology image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC):

  • The most common cancer associated with smoking (numerically).
  • The most common genetic mutation associated with SCC is p53. Also associated with P16 and FGFR1.
  • Most squamous cell carcinomas arise centrally in the lung from major or segmental bronchi.
  • Associated with cavity formation and massive necrosis.
  • It is commonly associated with Pancoast tumour manifestation.
  • The most common paraneoplastic manifestation is hypercalcemia, due to secretion of parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrP).

Morphology: Can be of three types based on keratin production:

  • Keratinising (Well-Differentiated): Shows keratin pearls (keratin in the centre with malignant squamous cells arranged around it). Indicates good differentiation.
  • Non-Keratinising: No keratin in the centre.
  • Basaloid: Arises from basal cells of the squamous epithelium, with more basic cells.

Diagnosis:

  • Electron microscopy: Shows desmosomes, which are always present.
  • IHC: The most specific marker is P40. Also positive for P63. Can be positive for CK5/6.

Adenocarcinoma (Option B): Adenocarcinoma is an invasive malignant epithelial tumour which usually arises in the peripheral part of the lung. These tumours are common in females and non-smokers. It is characterised by glandular differentiation or mucin production by the tumour cells.
