Small cell carcinoma (Option C): These are the most common malignant neuroendocrine tumours of the lung. Small cell carcinoma is composed of relatively small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin and inconspicuous nucleoli. They show the Azzopardi effect and extensive necrosis.

Non-small cell carcinoma (Option D): These are epithelial tumours of the lungs which include squamous cell carcinoma, adenocarcinoma and large cell carcinoma. These tumours always have a precursor lesion.

questions.text: An investigator is evaluating the interaction between two drugs. The dose-response curve for drug A shifts to the right in the presence of drug B, without a change in the maximum response (Emax), as shown in the graph. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of drug B?
questions.solution:
The graph shows three dose-response curves:

  • Curve A: Represents the original agonist (drug A) alone, showing a typical sigmoidal curve.
  • Curve B: Shows a rightward shift of drug A's curve when combined with drug B, with no reduction in maximal response (Emax).
  • Curve C: A lower curve (possibly depicting a scenario with a different interaction/mechanism).

This rightward shift without change in Emax is the hallmark of competitive antagonism.

Competitive Antagonism:

  • A competitive antagonist binds reversibly to the same active (orthosteric) site as the agonist.
  • The agonist and antagonist compete for binding.
  • Increased agonist concentration can overcome the inhibition, resulting in a rightward shift in the dose-response curve.
  • Emax remains unchanged, but the potency of the agonist decreases (i.e., a higher dose is required to achieve the same effect).


The Inverse agonist (Option C) acts by reducing the basal activity of receptors with constitutive activity. It would produce a downward shift in the baseline, not just a rightward shift in agonist curve. The graph does not suggest inverse agonism.

The Functional antagonist (Option D) refers to two drugs acting on different receptors or pathways producing opposing physiological effects. Functional antagonism does not produce a classical shift in a dose-response curve of a single drug like seen here.

choices.text: Pearl Index measures population-level contraceptive coverage; CPR measures failure rate of methods
Pearl Index is used for evaluating method failure; CPR is used for assessing family planning coverage
Pearl Index reflects program implementation; CPR reflects individual compliance
Both Pearl Index and CPR are indicators of method-specific contraceptive efficacy

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman visits a rural health center for contraceptive counseling. The medical officer explains two important public health indicators. Which of the following best describes the two indicators, Pearl Index and Couple Protection Rate (CPR)?
questions.solution:
• Pearl Index quantifies the number of unintended pregnancies per 100 woman-years (HWY) of contraceptive exposure and serves as a standardized measure of method-specific contraceptive failure.
  • Couple Protection Rate (CPR) denotes the percentage of eligible couples protected against childbirth through approved contraceptive methods. It is a programmatic indicator of family planning uptake in the community.

Pearl Index

  • Definition: Number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).
  • Formula:
  • Numerator: All accidental pregnancies (including those ending in abortion, miscarriage, or full-term delivery).
  • Denominator:
    • Adjusted total months of exposure
    • Exclude:
      • 10 months for every full-term delivery
      • 4 months for every abortion
  • Interpretation: A lower Pearl Index indicates higher contraceptive efficacy. It is used in clinical trials and method-specific evaluations.

Couple Protection Rate (CPR)

  • Definition: The percentage of eligible couples currently using at least one approved method of contraception.
  • Significance:
    • Reflects community-level access and use of contraceptives.
    • Higher CPR suggests better reach of family planning services.
    • A CPR of 60% or more is considered necessary to limit third and higher-order births.
  • Does not measure efficacy, but rather coverage and adoption of services.

Pearl Index measures population-level contraceptive coverage; CPR measures failure rate of methods (Option A): Incorrect- Pearl Index measures failure rate, not coverage. CPR measures coverage, not method-specific failure.

Pearl Index reflects program implementation; CPR reflects individual compliance (Option C): Incorrect- Pearl Index is for method failure, not program implementation. CPR is a community indicator, not individual-level compliance.

Both Pearl Index and CPR are indicators of method-specific contraceptive efficacy (Option D): Incorrect- CPR reflects service uptake, not efficacy. Only Pearl Index addresses method-specific efficacy.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department with migratory right iliac fossa pain, nausea and fever. On examination, he has tenderness and rebound tenderness in the right iliac fossa. You decide to calculate the Alvarado score to assess the likelihood of acute appendicitis. Which of the following is not included in the Alvarado scoring system?
questions.solution:
• The Alvarado scoring system is a clinical tool used to assess the probability of acute appendicitis.
  • It consists of 8 parameters with a total score of 10 points, based on symptoms, signs, and laboratory findings.
  • The components are:
  • A score of:
    • <4-5: Acute appendicitis unlikely (can rule out in children)
    • 4-6: Indeterminate; recommend adjunctive imaging (e.g., CT scan)
    • ≥7: High likelihood of appendicitis; surgery recommended.
  • In the question, leucopenia (low WBC count) is not part of the scoring. The score considers leukocytosis (high WBC) and left shift instead.

Migratory RIF pain (Option A): Included in the score, gets 1 point, therefore correct.

Rebound tenderness (Option B): Included in the score, gets 1 point, therefore correct.

Shift to left (Option D): Included in the score, gets 1 point, therefore correct.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man presents with fatigue, muscle weakness, and elevated blood pressure. On further questioning, he admits to taking large amounts of herbal licorice root extract for gastric ulcers over the past few weeks. Laboratory investigations reveal serum potassium of 2.8 mEq/L, low plasma renin and aldosterone levels, and metabolic alkalosis. Urinary calcium is elevated.
Which of the following best describes the metabolic and electrolyte profile associated with chronic licorice root ingestion?
questions.solution:
Licorice root contains glycyrrhizin, which inhibits 11β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase type 2 (11β-HSD2) - an enzyme that normally converts cortisol to inactive cortisone in the renal tubules. When this enzyme is inhibited:

  • Cortisol accumulates and starts stimulating mineralocorticoid (aldosterone) receptors, mimicking hyperaldosteronism (a condition called apparent mineralocorticoid excess).

Effects of Pseudo-Hyperaldosteronism:

  • Potassium loss → Hypokalemia
  • Hydrogen ion loss → Metabolic alkalosis
  • Increased sodium retention → Hypertension
  • Increased calcium excretion → Hypercalciuria

This profile mimics primary hyperaldosteronism, but without elevated aldosterone levels.

Effects of Chronic Licorice Ingestion:

  • ROME:
    • Respiratory → Opposite (pH & CO₂ go opposite)
    • Metabolic → Equal (pH & HCO₃⁻ go same direction)
  • K⁺ Trends:
    • Acidosis → Hyperkalemia (H⁺ in, K⁺ out)
    • Alkalosis → Hypokalemia (H⁺ out, K⁺ in)

Hypokalemia, hypercalciuria, and metabolic acidosis (Option B): Aldosterone-like effects cause loss of H⁺, not retention → alkalosis, not acidosis.

Hyperkalemia, hypocalciuria, and metabolic alkalosis (Option C): Aldosterone excess leads to potassium loss, not retention. Also, urinary calcium is increased, not decreased.

Hyperkalemia, hypercalciuria, and metabolic acidosis (Option D): As all three findings contradict the known effects of mineralocorticoid receptor activation (should be hypokalemia, alkalosis).

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl, presented to the hospital with chest pain and respiratory distress. On physical examination, the patient is having shortness of breath, wheezing, and gasping for air. A prominent pansystolic heart murmur heard on cardiac auscultation. An X-ray study of the chest shows marked enlargement of the heart. The patient expires despite intense supportive measures. An autopsy was performed, and an image of microscopic examination of the myocardium is shown below. Based on the above findings, what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A 12-year-old girl presenting with chest pain, respiratory distress, pansystolic murmur, cardiomegaly on X-ray, and sudden death is highly suggestive of acute carditis, likely due to acute rheumatic fever (ARF), especially in this age group.

The microscopic image shows features like:

  • Aschoff bodies (granulomatous lesions with central fibrinoid necrosis)
  • Anitschkow cells ("caterpillar" cells - activated histiocytes with centrally wavy chromatin)

These are pathognomonic histological findings of acute rheumatic carditis, confirming the diagnosis of Acute Rheumatic Fever.

Acute Rheumatic Fever is an autoimmune, nonsuppurative sequela that occurs after a Group A β-hemolytic streptococcal (GAS) pharyngeal infection, typically 2-3 weeks later.

Pathogenesis:

  • Molecular mimicry: Antibodies generated against streptococcal M proteins cross-react with cardiac tissue, joints, skin, and CNS.
  • Type II hypersensitivity reaction is central to its pathophysiology.

Clinical Features (Based on Modified Jones Criteria):

Major Criteria:

  1. Carditis (can involve endocardium, myocardium, or pericardium)
    • Tachycardia, new murmurs (e.g., mitral regurgitation), cardiomegaly, pericardial rub, heart failure.
    • Histology: Aschoff bodies, Anitschkow cells.
  2. Polyarthritis
    • Migratory, large joint involvement (knees, ankles, elbows, wrists).
  3. Sydenham's chorea
    • Involuntary, purposeless, rapid movements; emotional lability; delayed manifestation.
  4. Erythema marginatum
    • Non-pruritic, pink rings with clear centers, typically on trunk/proximal limbs.
  5. Subcutaneous nodules
    • Firm, painless nodules over extensor surfaces, often near bony prominences.

Minor Criteria:

  • Fever
  • Arthralgia (if arthritis is not counted as major)
  • Elevated ESR/CRP
  • Prolonged PR interval on ECG

Acute bacterial endocarditis (Option A):

This typically occurs in individuals with a preexisting valvular abnormality or intravenous drug use. The clinical course is fulminant, but it is more common in adults. Histology would show bacterial colonies with destruction of valve tissue, not Aschoff bodies or Anitschkow cells. It is not the typical cause of sudden death with myocarditis and cardiomegaly in a 12-year-old.

Subacute bacterial endocarditis (Option C):

Usually caused by less virulent organisms (e.g., viridans streptococci) and has a more indolent course. It often presents with constitutional symptoms like fever, malaise, and anemia over weeks. There is no association with myocarditis or sudden death in previously healthy children. Microscopy would show vegetations with granulation tissue and fibrosis, not Aschoff bodies.

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) (Option D):

Though SLE can cause Libman-Sacks endocarditis and pericarditis, it usually affects young women, not commonly children this young. Also, it has multi-systemic signs (rash, arthritis, renal involvement), which are not mentioned. Histology would not show Aschoff bodies, but rather fibrinoid necrosis and immune complex deposition.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents with complaints of fatigue, diarrhoea, unintentional weight loss, and increased anxiety. Her past medical records reveal that she is currently on amiodarone therapy for a ventricular arrhythmia. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in her evaluation?
questions.solution:
• The patient's symptoms - fatigue, weight loss, diarrhoea, and anxiety - are classical features of hyperthyroidism.
  • She is on chronic amiodarone therapy, which is well known to cause thyroid dysfunction, including both hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism.
  • Hence, the most appropriate next step in her management is to assess thyroid function.

Amiodarone-Induced Thyroid Dysfunction:

Mechanism:

  • Amiodarone contains 37% iodine by weight. Each 200 mg tablet delivers ~75 mg of iodine (much higher than the recommended daily intake of ~150 mcg).
  • This leads to:
    • Hypothyroidism (AIH): via Wolff-Chaikoff effect (inhibition of thyroid hormone synthesis)
    • Hyperthyroidism (AIT): due to two mechanisms:
      • Type I AIT: Iodine-induced synthesis in patients with pre-existing thyroid nodules or latent Graves'
      • Type II AIT: Destructive thyroiditis releasing preformed T3/T4

Monitoring Recommendations:

  • Thyroid function tests (TSH, T3, T4) should be done at baseline, then every 3-6 months during therapy.

Symptoms of Hyperthyroidism:

  • Weight loss
  • Diarrhoea
  • Anxiety, tremors
  • Palpitations
  • Heat intolerance

The serum electrolyte test (Option A): While electrolyte monitoring is important in arrhythmia patients, it is not the first or most relevant test for evaluating her current symptoms. There is no evidence of electrolyte imbalance symptoms like cramping, altered sensorium, or cardiac rhythm changes in this case.

The ECG (Option B): ECG abnormalities may result from amiodarone toxicity, but the presenting features (diarrhoea, weight loss, anxiety) point more toward a metabolic/endocrine cause, not a conduction defect. ECG might support arrhythmia monitoring but is not the priority.

The anti-histone antibody (Option D) test is used to evaluate drug-induced lupus, which typically presents with fever, arthralgia, serositis, and skin rashes - none of which are reported in this patient.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman in her second trimester presents with fever, conjunctivitis, and a maculopapular rash after returning from a Zika-endemic region. Serological testing confirms Zika virus infection. The physician notifies public health authorities and begins counseling on vector control to prevent further spread.
Which of the following arthropods is the primary vector responsible for transmission of this disease?
questions.solution:
• Aedes aegypti is the principal vector for Zika virus, along with other viral infections such as:
    • Dengue
    • Chikungunya
    • Yellow fever
    • Filariasis (some overlap with other vectors)
  • This mosquito is diurnal, breeds in clean stagnant water, and is commonly found in urban environments.
  • Zika virus is particularly important in pregnancy due to its link with microcephaly and congenital Zika syndrome.

Culex mosquito (Option A): Incorrect- Transmits Japanese encephalitis, Bancroftian filariasis, and West Nile fever, not Zika virus.

Sandfly (Option C): Incorrect- Transmits Kala-azar (Visceral leishmaniasis), Oroya fever, and Sandfly fever, not viral infections like Zika.

Louse (Option D): Incorrect- Transmits epidemic typhus, trench fever, relapsing fever, and causes pediculosis; does not transmit Zika virus.

choices.text: It is caused due to STK11 gene mutation
It is an autosomal recessive disease
Causes melanosis of the mouth and lips
Causes multiple hamartomatous polyps in the small intestine and colon

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents with hyperpigmented macules on the lips, buccal mucosa, and fingertips since childhood. She has a history of recurrent colicky abdominal pain. On endoscopy, multiple polyps are seen throughout the small intestine and colon. Which of the following statements about her condition is false?
questions.solution:
• The condition described is Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS), which is a rare, autosomal dominant inherited disorder resulting from a mutation in the STK11 (LKB1) tumor suppressor gene located on chromosome 19.
  • Option B is false because the inheritance pattern is autosomal dominant, not recessive.

Surveillance:

  • Regular endoscopic screening
  • Polypectomy to prevent complications
  • Vigilant cancer surveillance

It is caused due to STK11 gene mutation (Option A): True. The syndrome is caused by mutations in the STK11 gene located on chromosome 19, which functions as a tumor suppressor.

Causes melanosis of the mouth and lips (Option C): True. Hyperpigmentation of the mucosa, lips, and fingertips is a hallmark of PJS.

Causes multiple hamartomatous polyps in the small intestine and colon (Option D): True. PJS is characterized by the presence of hamartomatous polyps primarily in the small intestine, but also in the colon and stomach.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old non-obese male presents for a routine health check-up and is found to have a high fasting blood glucose level. He reports no history of weight loss, polyuria, or polydipsia. There are no episodes of diabetic ketoacidosis, and he is clinically stable on minimal oral therapy. Autoantibody screening for GAD is negative. Which of the following features most strongly support a diagnosis of Maturity-Onset Diabetes of the Young (MODY) over Type 1 Diabetes?
1. Low insulin requirement
2. Absence of microvascular complications
3. No episodes of Diabetes ketoacidosis
4. Absence of anti-GAD antibody positivity
questions.solution:
Features supporting MODY:

  • Non-obese adolescent (no insulin resistance-unlike Type 2 DM)
  • No DKA history (DKA is typical in T1DM due to absolute insulin deficiency)
  • Low insulin requirement (suggests residual endogenous insulin production)
  • Anti-GAD negative (rules out autoimmune Type 1 DM)

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with a 3-year history of worsening congestive heart failure presents with exertional dyspnoea and fatigue. Echocardiography shows restrictive cardiomyopathy with thickened ventricular walls but no left ventricular hypertrophy. Cardiac catheterisation shows normal coronary arteries. Right ventricular endomyocardial biopsy reveals myocardial replacement by acellular, eosinophilic material on H&E staining. Congo red stain of the specimen shows apple-green birefringence under polarised light. Which of the following is the most likely substance deposited in the myocardium?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of:

  • Long-standing congestive heart failure
  • Restrictive cardiomyopathy
  • Biopsy showing eosinophilic acellular material
  • Apple-green birefringence on Congo red stain under polarised light


This is pathognomonic for amyloid deposition, most commonly seen in cardiac amyloidosis.


Triglycerides (Option A): Lipid deposition (seen in fatty heart or metabolic disorders) does not stain with Congo red and doesn't show apple-green birefringence. Also, lipid deposition appears vacuolated, not eosinophilic and acellular.

Collagen (Option B): Collagen is associated with fibrosis and stains blue with Masson's trichrome, not apple-green under Congo red stain. It's cellular and organised, unlike amyloid.

Myocyte fibrinoid necrosis (Option D): This is seen in vascular pathology like immune-mediated vasculitis or severe hypertension, and does not show Congo red positivity or restrictive cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A patient is receiving low-dose methotrexate for rheumatoid arthritis. Which of the following anti-gout drugs, if co-administered, is most likely to increase methotrexate toxicity by reducing its renal clearance?
questions.solution:
Probenecid is a uricosuric agent that works by inhibiting the renal tubular reabsorption of uric acid via URAT1 inhibition, thereby increasing its urinary excretion. However, it also inhibits the renal tubular secretion of weak organic acids, such as methotrexate, by blocking organic anion transporters (OATs) in the proximal tubule.

This results in increased plasma concentrations and toxicity of methotrexate, especially when methotrexate is used at conventional low doses for conditions like rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old male presents to a DOTS center with complaints of chronic cough, weight loss, and evening rise of temperature. Sputum examination confirms pulmonary tuberculosis. He reports having taken anti-tubercular drugs for 3 weeks several years ago but did not complete the course or follow-up thereafter.
As per NTEP guidelines, how should this case be classified?
questions.solution:
• According to National TB Elimination Program (NTEP), a New case is defined as a patient who has:
    • Never received anti-tubercular therapy (ATT) before, or
    • Received ATT for less than 1 month (i.e., < 4 weeks) at any point in the past.
  • In this case, the patient took ATT for only 3 weeks, which falls under less than 1 month, and did not complete treatment.
  • Therefore, this individual does not meet the threshold of a previously treated case and must be registered as a New case.

Classification of Tuberculosis (TB) Cases under NTEP

  • This classification system is structured around a patient's past history of anti-tubercular therapy (ATT) and is essential for determining the correct line of management, monitoring outcomes, and ensuring accurate national-level TB reporting.

Previously treated patient (Option B): Incorrect- This classification applies to patients who received ≥1 month of ATT in the past. In this case, the patient took it for only 3 weeks, which does not meet the criteria.

Treatment after Loss to follow-up (Option C): Incorrect- This requires the patient to have received more than 1 month of treatment, been registered as lost to follow-up, and now presenting again with TB. This patient was never registered or lost formally.

Recurrent TB case (Option D): Incorrect- This applies to patients who were previously declared cured or completed treatment, and are now microbiologically confirmed again. Our patient never completed treatment, so this is not applicable.

References:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK214446/

choices.text: Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) of the adrenal mass

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents with episodic headaches, palpitations, and sweating. On examination, his blood pressure is 180/110 mmHg. MRI of the abdomen shows a 4 cm highly vascular adrenal mass with salt-and-pepper nuclei on biopsy. Which of the following is the most sensitive screening test to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The clinical scenario describes a classic presentation of pheochromocytoma, with the triad of episodic hypertension, headaches, palpitations, and diaphoresis, and an adrenal mass.
  • The most sensitive screening test for pheochromocytoma is plasma metanephrines.

24-hour urinary vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) (Option A): Previously used but less sensitive compared to plasma metanephrines.

CT abdomen with contrast (Option C): Although useful in localization, CT contrast is contraindicated due to risk of precipitating a hypertensive crisis.

Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) of the adrenal mass (Option D): Contraindicated in pheochromocytoma because it can trigger a hypertensive crisis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department with altered mental status. He is hypotensive (BP: 80/50 mmHg), has generalised hyperpigmentation, and his family mentions progressive fatigue, unintentional weight loss, and abdominal pain for the past several months. He has a history of Hashimoto's thyroiditis. On initial lab evaluation, which of the following findings is MOST LIKELY to be present?
questions.solution:
• The patient has clinical features consistent with primary adrenal insufficiency, including:
    • Hypotension
    • Hyperpigmentation
    • Chronic fatigue and weight loss
    • Autoimmune background (Hashimoto's thyroiditis)
  • This is likely an Addisonian crisis, precipitated by stress (e.g., infection or undiagnosed chronic adrenal insufficiency).

Addison's disease causes aldosterone deficiency, leading to:

  • Renal loss of sodium → hyponatraemia
  • Retention of potassium → hyperkalaemia
  • Hypovolaemia and hypotension

Also, cortisol deficiency increases ADH secretion, worsening dilutional hyponatraemia.

Values can drop to <120 mmol/L in adrenal crisis.


Laboratory glucose level of 298 mg/dL (Option A):

  • Cortisol has glucocorticoid effects that help maintain blood sugar.
  • In Addison's disease, hypoglycaemia is common due to cortisol deficiency.
  • Hyperglycaemia is characteristic of Cushing's syndrome or diabetes mellitus, not adrenal insufficiency.

Decreased eosinophil count (Option C):

  • Cortisol normally causes eosinopenia.
  • In adrenal insufficiency, the absence of cortisol results in eosinophilia, not decreased eosinophils.

Serum potassium level of 2.4 mmol/L (Option D):

  • Due to aldosterone deficiency, Addison's disease leads to impaired renal excretion of potassium.
  • Therefore, hyperkalaemia is expected (often >5.5 mmol/L), not hypokalaemia.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents with fever and painful joints for 2 weeks. On examination, he has skin pigmentation, glossitis, angular cheilitis, and generalised lymphadenopathy. The patient has lost 9 kg over the past 6 months. He reports pale and foul-smelling stools. Blood cultures are negative. He was started on antibiotic therapy and showed remarkable clinical improvement. A biopsy of the small intestine is taken, and the histopathological image is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Biopsy of the small intestine given above shows marked distortion of the intestinal villi and numerous foamy macrophages, suggestive of Whipple disease.

Whipple disease:

  • It's a rare infectious disorder of the small intestine in which malabsorption is the most prominent feature.
  • Caused by Tropheryma whipplei, a Gram-positive actinomycete.
  • Typically features infiltration of the small bowel mucosa by macrophages that are packed with small, rod-shaped bacilli (Tropheryma whipplei).
  • Infiltration of macrophages containing bacilli may be found in other organs, including regional lymph nodes and the heart.

Clinical manifestations:

Acute infection: Acute gastroenteritis, pneumonia

Chronic infection:

  • The most common joint involvement is arthritis. Worsened with steroids, but improves with antibiotics.
  • CNS:
    • Dementia is the most common manifestation
    • The most specific manifestation is conergent/divergent nystagmus with masticatory jaw muscle involvement. This is called the oculo-masticatory myorhythmia.
    • Encephalopathy
    • Supranuclear ophthalmoplegia
  • CVS - the most common feature is pericarditis
  • Eye - the most common feature is uveitis

Diagnosis:

  • Histopathology:
    • Foamy macrophages
    • PAS-positive macrophage in the lamina propria
    • Gram positive
    • Acid-fast negative
  • PCR: Whipple disease is a benign disease showing metastasis, i.e presents like a malignant disease.


Fig: Whipple disease A) Hematoxylin and eosin staining shows lamina propria with distended macrophages. B) PAS stains with macrophage lysosomes full of bacilli.

Explanation of other options:

Celiac disease (Option A): It's a gluten-induced enteropathy due to gluten intolerance. More common in children, they present with malabsorption symptoms like diarrhoea, weight loss, and abdominal distension. Celiac disease shows no systemic involvement. HPE shows villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and intraepithelial lymphocytes.

Tropical sprue (Option B): Also known as environmental enteropathy, the most common endemic organism implicated is E.coli. Symptoms of malabsorption though present, patients do not presents with any systemic features. Histopathology shows villi atrophy, crypt enlargement, and intraepithelial lymphocytes.

Crohn's disease (Option C): In most patients, the disease begins with intermittent attacks of relatively mild diarrhoea, fever, and abdominal pain. Extraintestinal manifestations of Crohn's disease include cutaneous nodules, uveitis, migratory polyarthritis, sacroileitis, ankylosing spondylitis, erythema nodosum, cutaneous granulomas, and clubbing of the fingertips. The microscopical findings include abundant neutrophils that infiltrate and damage the crypt epithelium, and non-caseating granulomas - a hallmark of Crohn's disease.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of chronic smoking presents to the emergency department with severe dyspnoea. He is tachypnoeic, refuses to lie down, and has an SpO₂ of 75% on room air. Chest auscultation reveals bilateral crepitations, and a chest X-ray shows hyperinflated lung fields consistent with emphysematous changes. After initiating oxygen therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate beta-2 agonist for immediate symptomatic relief?
questions.solution:
In Acute COPD Exacerbation:

  • Immediate bronchodilation is needed.
  • Short-acting beta-2 agonists (SABA) are the first-line drugs for rapid symptom relief.
  • Salbutamol is the prototypical SABA, with rapid onset (within 5 minutes) and action lasting 4-6 hours.
  • Salbutamol is a short-acting beta2-agonist (SABA), recommended as first-line therapy in acute dyspnoea or COPD exacerbation due to its rapid onset of action.

Indacaterol (Option A) is a long-acting beta2-agonist (LABA) used for maintenance therapy, not for acute symptom relief. It has a slower onset and is dosed once daily.

Salmeterol (Option C) is also a LABA, used in long-term control of COPD symptoms. It has delayed onset (15-20 minutes), making it unsuitable for acute attacks.

Formoterol (Option D): Although it is a LABA, it has a relatively faster onset than salmeterol (~5 minutes), but still not the first-line over SABA like salbutamol in acute scenarios.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old primigravida from a rural village undergoes an uncomplicated home delivery attended by a traditional birth attendant. She is stable post-delivery and has been registered under the National Health Mission's Home-Based Newborn Care (HBNC) program. The medical officer asks the ASHA worker to ensure postnatal follow-up as per national guidelines.
How many postnatal home visits should the ASHA conduct for this woman and her newborn?
questions.solution:
• According to the Home-Based Newborn Care (HBNC) strategy under the National Health Mission:
    • An ASHA worker is required to perform 7 scheduled home visits following a home delivery.
    • These visits are conducted on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, and 42 after birth.
    • The objective is early identification and management of complications in the neonate and to promote essential newborn care.

Therefore, for a home delivery, 7 postnatal visits are mandated.

ASHA and HBNC Guidelines

General Criteria for ASHA Recruitment:

  • Gender: Must be a woman
  • Age: Between 25-45 years
  • Marital status: Married/divorced/widow
  • Residence: Should belong to the same village
  • Education: Preferably up to 10th standard (relaxable if no suitable candidate is found)
  • Coverage Norm:
    • 1 ASHA per 1000 population
    • In tribal, desert, or hilly areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 per habitation

Responsibilities of ASHA:

  • Health awareness and education
  • Reproductive, child health, and family planning services
  • Sanitation, minor ailments management
  • DOTS provider for TB treatment
  • Distributes ORS, zinc, contraceptives, and disposable delivery kits
  • Assists in referrals and promotes institutional deliveries

Home-Based Care of Young Child (HBYC):

  • 5 visits after 42 days of birth
  • ASHA conducts quarterly visits in 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th, and 15th months

4 (Option A): Incorrect- Not aligned with any approved visit schedule under HBNC or HBYC.

5 (Option B): Incorrect- This number applies to Caesarean section deliveries under institutional delivery when the mother is discharged late.

6 (Option C): Incorrect- ASHA conducts 6 visits after a vaginal institutional delivery, not home delivery.

choices.text: Hepatocellular adenoma is considered a premalignant lesion
Small-cell change is strongly associated with cirrhosis and viral hepatitis
Hepatocellular adenoma is rarely associated with cirrhosis
Small-cell change commonly arises without underlying liver disease

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with a history of alcohol-related cirrhosis and chronic hepatitis C undergoes routine liver biopsy for surveillance. Histology reveals clusters of small hepatocytes with high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio scattered within cirrhotic nodules. The pathologist reports a premalignant change associated with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Regarding precursor lesions of HCC, which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a patient with cirrhosis and chronic hepatitis C who is found to have small-cell change, a premalignant microscopic alteration within a cirrhotic liver that can progress to HCC.

  • Both hepatocellular adenoma and small-cell change are premalignant.
  • Small-cell change is typically seen in the setting of cirrhosis and viral hepatitis.
  • Hepatocellular adenoma occurs without cirrhosis, commonly in young women and is associated with oral contraceptives, anabolic steroids, and NAFLD.
  • Small-cell change does not commonly arise without underlying liver disease, making Option D incorrect.

Hepatocellular adenoma is considered a premalignant lesion (Option A): True. It has malignant potential.

Small-cell change is strongly associated with cirrhosis and viral hepatitis (Option B): True. Hallmark of premalignant transformation in cirrhotic livers.

Hepatocellular adenoma is rarely associated with cirrhosis (Option C): True. Usually occurs in non-cirrhotic livers.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of bloody diarrhoea. She has no prior hospitalisations or major medical illnesses. On examination, her abdomen is distended and tender on the left side. Rectal examination reveals a small amount of faeces.

Blood investigations show:
1. Hb: 11.0 g/dL
2. WBC: 15.6 x 10⁹/L
3. Platelets: 450 x 10⁹/L
4. Sodium: 139 mmol/L
5. Potassium: 4.6 mmol/L
6. Urea: 43 mg/dL
7. Creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL
8. CRP: 35 mg/L

Which of the following is the most appropriate next investigation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with chronic bloody diarrhoea, systemic signs of inflammation (raised WBC, CRP, platelets), and left-sided abdominal distension and tenderness suggestive of ulcerative colitis (UC).

However, distension and tenderness raise concern for a potential complication like toxic megacolon, especially with elevated inflammatory markers.
Before any endoscopic procedure, a plain abdominal X-ray is essential to rule out colonic dilatation or perforation.

Ulcerative Colitis:

  • Chronic inflammatory disease of colon and rectum.
  • Bloody diarrhoea, abdominal cramps, and weight loss are common.
  • Continuous inflammation starting at rectum, extending proximally.
  • Complications include: Toxic megacolon, perforation, strictures, colorectal carcinoma.
  • Diagnosis: Clinical + Endoscopy + Biopsy.
  • Monitoring: Avoid full colonoscopy during acute flares.


Colonoscopy (Option A): It is contraindicated in acute severe colitis or toxic megacolon due to the risk of perforation.

Sigmoidoscopy (Option C): Although limited sigmoidoscopy is safer than full colonoscopy, it should not be done before excluding megacolon by X-ray.

CT of the abdomen (Option D): It is not the first-line investigation. X-ray is simpler, faster, and sufficient to detect megacolon. CT may be used later if complications like abscess or perforation are suspected after X-ray.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man complains of pain in his back, fatigue, and occasional confusion. He admits to polyuria and polydipsia. An X-ray examination reveals numerous lytic lesions in the lumbar vertebral bodies. Laboratory studies disclose hypoalbuminemia, mild anemia, and thrombocytopenia. A monoclonal Igk peak is demonstrated by serum electrophoresis. Urinalysis shows 4+ proteinuria. A bone marrow biopsy discloses foci of plasma cells, which account for 18% of all hematopoietic cells. What is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with bone pain, fatigue, polyuria/polydipsia, and confusion, suggestive of hypercalcemia
  • X-ray shows lytic bone lesions, a hallmark of multiple myeloma
  • Lab findings: monoclonal Igκ spike, proteinuria (Bence-Jones protein), anemia, thrombocytopenia, and hypoalbuminemia
  • Bone marrow with ≥10% plasma cells confirms the diagnosis
  • Multiple myeloma is characterized by malignant plasma cell infiltration producing monoclonal immunoglobulin and associated end-organ damage (CRAB: Calcium elevation, Renal failure, Anemia, Bone lesions)

Acute lymphoblastic lymphoma (Option A): Occurs primarily in children; not associated with plasma cells or M-protein

Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (Option B): Involves small mature lymphocytes and smudge cells; no lytic lesions or monoclonal spike

Extramedullary plasmacytoma (Option C): Localized plasma cell tumor without systemic involvement or bone marrow plasmacytosis

Key Takeaways:

  • Multiple myeloma = monoclonal protein, lytic bone lesions, ≥10% plasma cells
  • Presents with CRAB symptoms and M-spike on electrophoresis
  • Bence-Jones proteinuria is a classic finding

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man undergoes mitral valve replacement and is started on anticoagulation. On postoperative day 5, he develops non-blanching purpuric lesions over his trunk and arms.
Laboratory evaluation reveals:

1. WBC count: 11,000/mm3
2. Hemoglobin: 14 g/dL
3. Platelet count: 70,000/mm3 (baseline was 220,000/mm3 pre-op)
Which of the following is the most appropriate anticoagulant therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture is classic for Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenia (HIT):

  • Timing: Platelet drop occurs 5-10 days after heparin exposure
  • Thrombocytopenia: Platelet count dropped by >50%
  • Skin Lesions: Purpura/non-blanching rash = possible microthrombosis
  • Setting: Post-cardiac surgery → high heparin exposure risk

Argatroban is a direct thrombin inhibitor and is FDA-approved for treatment of HIT. It prevents further thrombosis and is used until platelet count recovers before transitioning to long-term therapy like warfarin.

choices.text: Administer rabies vaccine into the deltoid muscle on Days 0, 3, 7, 14, and 28
Infiltrate rabies immunoglobulin into and around the wound and inject the remaining IM at a site distant from the vaccine
Administer rabies vaccine in the gluteal region to achieve deeper immune response
Rabies immunoglobulin can be diluted to allow thorough wound infiltration when the volume is insufficient

questions.text:
A 26-year-old male reports to the emergency department with a bleeding wound on his hand after being bitten by a stray dog. He has no history of prior rabies vaccination. The exposure is classified as Category III. The medical officer initiates post-exposure prophylaxis as per the latest national recommendations.
Which of the following actions is not appropriate in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The gluteal region should never be used for rabies vaccine administration. Injections given in the gluteal area result in lower neutralizing antibody titers, leading to inadequate protection.
  • The deltoid muscle is the recommended site for intramuscular administration in adults, while the anterolateral thigh is preferred in children under one year.
  • Therefore, administering the vaccine in the gluteal region is not appropriate.

Rabies Post-Exposure and Pre-Exposure Prophylaxis

Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP)

  • Wound Care: Immediate and thorough washing with soap and running water for at least 10 minutes is the most critical first step.
  • Vaccine Administration:
    • Two WHO-recommended regimens are followed in India:
    • Each ID dose is 0.1 mL per site, using an entire vial regardless of vial size.
    • Vaccine must be injected in the deltoid (IM) or anterolateral thigh (for children under 1 year).
    • The gluteal region must be avoided as it reduces vaccine efficacy.
    • If any vaccine dose is missed, the schedule should be resumed, not restarted.

Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG)

  • Indication: Mandatory for Category III exposures in non-immunized individuals.
  • Timing: RIG should be given only once, ideally on Day 0, and not later than 7 days after the first vaccine dose.
    • HRIG (human): 20 IU/kg
    • ERIG (equine): 40 IU/kgTypes and Dosage:
  • Administration:
    • Infiltrate as much as possible into and around the wound.
    • If a wound is large or multiple wounds are present, RIG can be diluted in sterile saline to increase volume and ensure proper infiltration.
    • Any remaining RIG should be given intramuscularly at a site distant from the vaccine site.
  • RIG is not needed in patients who have previously completed post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) or pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP), and are re-exposed.
  • Monoclonal antibodies (mAb) are an alternative when RIG is unavailable. They must contain at least two rabies-neutralizing antibodies.

Priority Order for RIG Allocation

(when in limited supply):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Immunocompromised patients
  5. Confirmed or probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Exposure of mucosa/bite by a bat

Pre-Exposure Prophylaxis (PrEP)

Indicated in:

  • Lab staff, animal handlers, wildlife wardens
  • Residents of or travelers to rabies-endemic regions
  • Areas with poor access to PEP
  • Places where annual dog bite incidence >5%

Schedule:

  • 3 doses: either IM or ID on Days 0, 7, and 21 or 28

Re-Exposure in Previously Vaccinated Individuals

  • If PEP completed within 3 months: Only wound care is needed.
  • If PEP completed >3 months ago: Administer 2 doses of vaccine on Days 0 and 3 (no RIG required).
  • Treat as fresh case if:
    • Prior treatment involved neural tissue vaccines (NTV)
    • Vaccine potency is unverified
    • No documented evidence of previous PEP or PrEP

Administer rabies vaccine into the deltoid muscle on Days 0, 3, 7, 14, and 28 (Option A): Correct- This is the Essen regimen, a standard WHO-recommended IM vaccination schedule.

Infiltrate rabies immunoglobulin into and around the wound and inject the remaining IM at a site distant from the vaccine (Option B): Correct- This is the proper method of RIG administration and is emphasized in the guideline.

Rabies immunoglobulin can be diluted to allow thorough wound infiltration when the volume is insufficient (Option D): Correct- RIG may be diluted in sterile saline to increase volume and enable effective wound infiltration.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl presents with intermittent jaundice, abdominal pain, and a palpable right upper quadrant mass. Imaging reveals a cystic dilatation of the common bile duct, consistent with a choledochal cyst. Which type of choledochal cyst does she most likely have?
questions.solution:
The most common type of choledochal cyst is Type I, which represents about 80-90% of cases. It is characterized by a fusiform or cystic dilatation of the extrahepatic common bile duct. It typically presents in infancy or early childhood with the classical triad of abdominal pain, jaundice, and a palpable mass, which fits the scenario described.

Choledochal cysts

Choledochal cysts are congenital dilatations of the biliary tree, classified by Todani's classification into 5 types:



Type II (Option B): This is incorrect. Type II is a saccular diverticulum of the CBD, which is less common and does not typically present with the classical triad or large cystic dilatation.

Type III (Option C): This is incorrect. Type III, or choledochocele, is a dilatation of the intraduodenal portion of the CBD and often presents later with pancreatitis or duodenal obstruction symptoms.

Type IV (Option D): This is incorrect. Type IV involves multiple intrahepatic and/or extrahepatic cysts, not a solitary fusiform dilatation as seen here.

choices.text: Urease test on a gastric biopsy

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presents with epigastric discomfort and is suspected to have recurrent duodenal ulcer despite regular treatment with omeprazole. His physician suspects persistent Helicobacter pylori infection as the cause of relapse. The doctor wants to order the most sensitive non-invasive test to confirm ongoing H. pylori infection. Which of the following is the most sensitive test for detecting active H. pylori infection?
questions.solution:
The 13C Urea Breath Test:

  • Most sensitive and specific non-invasive test for active pylori infection.
  • Based on detection of labeled CO₂ in exhaled breath after ingestion of 13C-urea.
  • Useful in initial diagnosis and post-treatment eradication confirmation.
  • Not affected by past exposure.

Helicobacter pylori Infection in Peptic Ulcer Disease:

Pathophysiology:

  • pylori is a gram-negative spiral-shaped bacillus.
  • Produces urease, which converts urea -> ammonia, protecting it from gastric acid.
  • CagA and VacA toxins cause mucosal injury.
  • Leads to chronic gastritis, ulceration, and possibly gastric cancer/MALT lymphoma.

Duodenal Ulcer and H. pylori:

  • pylori is detected in >90% of duodenal ulcers.
  • Ulcer recurrence is common if H. pylori is not eradicated.

Diagnostic Modalities:



The urease test on a gastric biopsy (Option B): It is invasive, requires endoscopy and biopsy, and although highly specific, it is slightly less sensitive than the urea breath test, especially if the patient is on PPIs (like omeprazole).

The gastric fundal biopsy culture (Option C): Culture is not routinely done; it is technically difficult, time-consuming, and less sensitive. However, it helps in assessing antibiotic resistance, not first-line for detection.

The H. pylori serology (Option D): Serology detects antibodies, which persist after eradication, hence cannot distinguish active from past infection. Not recommended to confirm eradication or recurrence.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman with known systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) presents with facial puffiness and frothy urine for 3 weeks. Her blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg. Urinalysis reveals 2+ proteinuria and active urinary sediments. Serum creatinine is mildly elevated. A renal biopsy shows diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis with subendothelial immune complex deposits.
Which is the most common renal lesion seen in such patients?
questions.solution:
Diffuse lupus nephritis (Class IV) is the most common and most severe form of lupus nephritis, occurring in 35-60% of patients with renal involvement in SLE. It is associated with:

  • Subendothelial immune complex deposition (a hallmark feature)
  • Proliferation of endothelial and mesangial cells
  • Marked inflammatory infiltrates and necrosis
  • Nephritic features (active urinary sediments, hematuria, proteinuria)
  • Progressive renal dysfunction

Lupus Nephritis WHO/ISN-RPS Classification:


The Focal lupus nephritis (Option A) refers to Class III, which affects <50% of glomeruli and is less common than Class IV.

The Membranous lupus nephritis (Option C) is Class V, which shows subepithelial deposits, not subendothelial, and presents more like nephrotic syndrome, not active urinary sediment or proliferative changes.

The Minimal change disease (Option D): is not a typical lesion in SLE; it causes nephrotic syndrome but lacks immune complex deposition and proliferative changes. It's more common in idiopathic nephrotic syndrome of childhood.

choices.text: Immediately after exposure followed by HIV testing at the end of 3rd and 6th month
Immediately after exposure followed by HIV testing at the end of 1st and 3rd month
HIV testing at the end of completion of prophylaxis and also 2 months thereafter
Immediately after exposure followed by HIV testing at the end of completion of treatment

questions.text:
A 29-year-old resident doctor sustains a needlestick injury while managing an HIV-positive patient in the emergency department. The source patient is known to be HIV-reactive with unknown viral load. The doctor reports the incident within 2 hours and is started on a three-drug post-exposure prophylaxis regimen. The infection control officer advises a schedule for HIV testing.
What is the most appropriate testing schedule following occupational HIV exposure?
questions.solution:
• According to WHO 2018 and MOHFW 2020 guidelines, HIV testing in healthcare workers exposed to occupational risk should be performed immediately after the exposure to establish baseline serostatus.
  • Follow-up testing should be done at the end of the 3rd month and 6th month to confirm HIV seroconversion status.
  • This ensures detection of any delayed seroconversion due to window period and allows for timely identification of post-exposure HIV infection despite prophylaxis.
  • Hence, Option A represents the correct timeline for follow-up testing.
  • In both groups, DTG is now the preferred third drug, due to better tolerability and reduced toxicity.

HIV PEP and Follow-Up (Based on NCDC 2024)

Initial Steps Following Exposure

  • Wash the exposure site with soap and water immediately.
  • Report the incident without delay and document exposure details:
    • Type: skin, percutaneous, mucosal
    • Severity: depth, volume of blood/body fluid
    • Source status: HIV, HBV, or HCV positive

  • PEP must be started preferably within 2 hours, but can be initiated up to 72 hours post-exposure.
  • The full duration of therapy is 28 days, regardless of regimen.
  • Counseling is essential regarding adherence, safety, and possible side effects of drugs.

  • Longer follow-up is necessary especially in occupational exposures to HIV, due to variability in immune response and window period.

Immediately after exposure followed by HIV testing at the end of 1st and 3rd month (Option B): Incorrect- The standard schedule includes testing at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months. Testing at 1 and 3 months does not detect delayed seroconversion, which is why 6-month follow-up is essential.

HIV testing at the end of completion of prophylaxis and also 2 months thereafter (Option C): Incorrect- This schedule omits baseline testing and does not align with the 3-month and 6-month standard intervals.

Immediately after exposure followed by HIV testing at the end of completion of treatment (Option D): Incorrect- Testing only at the end of the 28-day prophylaxis period fails to detect delayed seroconversion. Longer follow-up is required.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male underwent splenectomy one year ago following trauma. He now presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset fever, chills, hypotension, and altered sensorium. Despite initiation of broad-spectrum antibiotics, he rapidly deteriorates. Which of the following organisms is least likely to be implicated in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
• Overwhelming Post-Splenectomy Infection (OPSI) is a rapidly fatal complication that may occur within 2-3 years following splenectomy, particularly in the absence of proper vaccination and prophylaxis.
  • It involves encapsulated organisms, against which the spleen normally provides immunological defense through opsonin-mediated phagocytosis.

Organisms Commonly Implicated in OPSI:

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (Most common)
  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Salmonella species
  • Capnocytophaga canimorsus (especially after dog bites)

These organisms share a common feature: encapsulation, which allows them to evade the immune system unless cleared by splenic macrophages.

Clinical Features of OPSI:

  • Prodrome: fever, chills, malaise, vomiting, diarrhea
  • Fulminant course: DIC, hypotension, ARDS, coma, and death within hours
  • Poor response to antibiotics
  • High-grade bacteremia with no identifiable focus

Vaccination and Prophylaxis:

  • Pneumococcal, Meningococcal, and Hib vaccines 2 weeks before elective splenectomy or before discharge after emergency splenectomy
  • Penicillin or Amoxicillin daily for 1 year, or longer if immunocompromised
  • Early empirical therapy: Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid or fluoroquinolones in β-lactam allergy

Streptococcus pneumoniae (Option A): Most common causative organism of OPSI. Its capsule inhibits phagocytosis unless opsonized, a process dependent on splenic function.

Haemophilus influenzae (Option B): A classic encapsulated bacterium frequently implicated in OPSI. Vaccination against type B strain is key.

Neisseria meningitidis (Option D): Another encapsulated pathogen included in routine vaccination schedules for asplenic patients.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male undergoes renal transplantation and is started on standard immunosuppressive therapy. Despite initial improvement, he develops signs of graft dysfunction within the first 3 months post-transplantation. A viral aetiology is suspected. Which of the following infections is most commonly associated with graft failure in solid organ transplant recipients?
questions.solution:
CMV is the most important infection-related cause of graft dysfunction and failure in solid organ transplant recipients. It exerts this effect via:



CMV and Transplantation:

  • High-risk serostatus (D+/R−) necessitates prophylactic valganciclovir or pre-emptive monitoring.
  • Antigenemia assays or CMV DNA PCR are used for early detection.
  • CMV syndrome includes fever, malaise, leukopenia, and organ-specific disease (e.g., pneumonitis, hepatitis).
  • Management includes antivirals (valganciclovir, ganciclovir) and modulation of immunosuppressants.

The Human Herpesvirus-6 (HHV-6) (Option B): It may cause febrile illness and encephalitis post-transplant but is a rarer cause of graft injury and not the most common infection-related factor contributing to graft loss.

The Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) (Option C): HSV commonly causes mucocutaneous lesions or encephalitis in transplant patients but is not significantly associated with graft dysfunction or rejection in solid organ recipients.

The Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) (Option D): While EBV is linked to post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD), it is not a primary cause of graft failure. PTLD is more of a neoplastic complication rather than rejection or graft damage per se.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is diagnosed with a mitochondrial myopathy confirmed by genetic testing, which revealed a pathogenic mutation in her mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA). She has three children, all of whom are also affected. Her brother, who carries the same mutation, has no affected children. Which of the following best explains the pattern of inheritance?
questions.solution:
• Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is inherited exclusively from the mother because sperm mitochondria are typically destroyed after fertilisation.
  • Hence, an affected mother transmits the mutation to all her offspring, regardless of sex.
  • However, an affected father does not transmit mtDNA mutations to any of his children.
  • This explains why the woman's children are affected, but her brother's children are not affected, a classic maternal inheritance
  • Diseases caused by mtDNA mutations include MELAS, LHON, and mitochondrial encephalomyopathies, all exhibit this maternal transmission.

X-linked recessive (Option A) traits typically affect males more than females and are transmitted through carrier mothers. Fathers can transmit X-linked recessive mutations to daughters (not sons). Affected males may have affected children, which contradicts the pattern here.

Autosomal recessive (Option B): Both parents must contribute one copy of the mutated allele for the offspring to be affected. Affected individuals can have unaffected parents, and the pattern is not sex-specific. This contradicts the exclusive maternal transmission seen here.

X-linked dominant (Option C): Affected fathers will transmit the disorder to all daughters but no sons, whereas affected mothers can transmit it to both sons and daughters. However, this pattern still allows affected fathers to pass on the disorder, which does not occur in mitochondrial inheritance.

choices.text: Prior probability of SLE, sensitivity and specificity of each test
Incidence of SLE and predictive value of each test
Relative risk of SLE in this patient

questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman presents with photosensitivity, arthralgia, and oral ulcers. You clinically suspect systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and order six serological tests. Four of these return positive, while two are negative. You now want to estimate the probability that the patient actually has SLE, given these test results.
Which of the following would provide the most appropriate statistical basis to calculate this probability?
questions.solution:
To determine the post-test probability of disease (i.e., probability that the patient has SLE given a positive test result), you must integrate:

  • The pre-test probability (prior probability) based on clinical judgment or population prevalence.
  • The sensitivity (true positive rate): Likelihood that the test is positive when the disease is present.
  • The specificity (true negative rate): Likelihood that the test is negative when the disease is absent.

These components are used in Bayes' theorem to compute Positive Predictive Value (PPV), which answers:

"If the test is positive, what is the probability that the patient actually has the disease?"

Thus, Option A is correct.


In clinical scenarios, sensitivity and specificity are test properties, while PPV and NPV are dependent on disease prevalence and the patient's pre-test probability.

Incidence of SLE and predictive value of each test (Option B): Incorrect- While predictive values are important, incidence alone doesn't allow post-test probability calculation without sensitivity, specificity, and prior probability.

Incidence and prevalence of SLE (Option C): Incorrect- These are population-level parameters. They help understand disease burden but do not help in determining individual diagnostic probability after testing.

Relative risk of SLE in this patient (Option D): Incorrect- Relative risk compares risk in exposed vs. unexposed groups in cohort studies. It does not inform diagnostic probabilities based on test results.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with severe headache, palpitations, sweating, and anxiety. Her BP is 226/120 mmHg, and heart rate is 170 bpm with runs of non-sustained ventricular tachycardia on ECG. She has no history of coronary artery disease. A 24-hour urinary assay reveals adrenaline of 720 nmol/24 hours (normal <80) and noradrenaline of 2300 nmol/24 hours (normal <780). Which of the following is the most appropriate acute management step?
questions.solution:
This patient has pheochromocytoma crisis, a life-threatening catecholamine surge causing hypertensive emergency and tachyarrhythmia. The mainstay of acute blood pressure management in pheochromocytoma is rapid-acting vasodilators that do not act via beta-blockade initially.

  • Sodium nitroprusside is a direct arterial and venous vasodilator, which reduces afterload and preload rapidly.
  • It does not exacerbate unopposed alpha stimulation, unlike beta-blockers used alone.
  • It provides precise titratable BP control, which is critical in pheochromocytoma crises.
  • It is ideal while preparing the patient for surgery once stabilized.

Intravenous labetalol (Option A): Although labetalol has both alpha- and beta-blocking properties, it is not ideal for initial BP control in pheochromocytoma because its beta-blockade predominates. Beta-blockade before alpha-blockade can precipitate hypertensive crisis due to unopposed alpha-adrenergic stimulation causing vasoconstriction.

Intravenous amiodarone (Option B): While this patient has tachycardia and ventricular ectopy, amiodarone treats arrhythmias but does not address the underlying catecholamine surge or hypertensive crisis. Treating arrhythmia without controlling BP first may be ineffective or dangerous.

Intravenous diltiazem (Option D): Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker with rate-limiting effects used in supraventricular tachycardias. It is ineffective in treating hypertensive emergencies due to catecholamine excess and can cause hypotension without improving the underlying pathology.

Key Takeaways:

  • In a pheochromocytoma crisis, first use rapid vasodilators like sodium nitroprusside.
  • Alpha-blockade (e.g., phenoxybenzamine or prazosin) should follow for chronic control.
  • Avoid beta-blockers unless alpha-blockade is already established.

choices.text: Altered mental status, high temperature, and low blood pressure

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with diabetes presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of fever and cough. He is disoriented, has a respiratory rate of 26/min, and his blood pressure is 94/60 mmHg. On evaluation, which combination of findings would fulfill the quick SOFA (qSOFA) criteria for predicting poor outcomes in suspected sepsis?
questions.solution:
• qSOFA is a bedside tool to identify patients with suspected infection who are likely to have poor outcomes.
  • It includes three criteria, all of which must be assessed without requiring lab results:

  • This patient fulfills all three: disoriented (GCS <14), RR = 26 (>22), SBP = 94 (<100).

qSOFA

(for quick bedside use outside ICU):

  • No labs required
  • Used in non-ICU settings to rapidly assess septic risk

qSOFA Criteria:


  • A score of ≥2 indicates high risk of adverse outcomes -> prompt further evaluation and possibly ICU admission.

Temperature >100°F, SBP <100 mmHg, GCS <14 (Option B): Fever is not included in qSOFA; this overlaps with SIRS criteria.

Respiratory rate >22/min, WBC count >12,000/mm³, GCS <14 (Option C): WBC count is not part of qSOFA, but is in SIRS. qSOFA avoids lab dependency.

Altered mental status, high temperature, and low blood pressure (Option D): Though 'altered mental status' and 'low BP' are correct, 'high temperature' is again not a qSOFA parameter.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with episodes of tachycardia and anxiety-like symptoms. She has no significant past medical history but has been taking multiple over-the-counter supplements, including kelp (rich in iodine). On examination, there are no eye signs and no goitre. Her thyroid function tests show a suppressed TSH (< 0.05 mU/L), with negative TSH receptor antibodies. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her thyrotoxicosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient is clinically thyrotoxic (symptoms of tachycardia, panic attacks, low TSH).
  • There are no signs of Graves' disease (e.g., no ophthalmopathy or goitre), and TSH receptor antibodies are negative, making autoimmune causes less likely.
  • There is a history of kelp (iodine) supplement use.
  • This fits the pattern of Jod-Basedow phenomenon, a form of iodine-induced thyrotoxicosis.
  • It occurs when a previously euthyroid or subtly autonomous thyroid is exposed to excess iodine, triggering unregulated hormone production.
  • Commonly seen in individuals taking iodine supplements or receiving iodinated contrast.

Graves' disease (Option A): TSH receptor antibodies are negative, and there are no eye signs or goitre, which are classical features of Graves' disease.

Toxic multinodular goitre (Option B): The examination shows no goitre or nodularity, and this condition typically presents with an enlarged, nodular thyroid, often in older individuals.

Solitary toxic nodule (Option C): There is no mention of a palpable thyroid nodule or ultrasound findings suggesting a hot nodule, which are required for this diagnosis.

choices.text: Hepatocellular carcinoma, Primary biliary cirrhosis, Alcoholic liver cirrhosis
Autoimmune hepatitis, α1-antitrypsin deficiency, Primary sclerosing cholangitis

questions.text: A liver biopsy reveals eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions composed of misfolded keratin filaments, ubiquitin, and p62 in hepatocytes. These inclusions are identified as Mallory-Denk bodies. Which of the following sets of liver conditions are classically associated with this histological finding?
questions.solution:
Mallory-Denk Bodies (MDBs):

  • MDBs are cytoplasmic eosinophilic hyaline inclusions composed of misfolded cytokeratins (K8/K18), ubiquitin, and other stress-related proteins.
  • Formed as a response to chronic hepatocyte stress (e.g., oxidative, toxic, or metabolic injury).
  • Seen prominently in conditions like:
    • Alcoholic liver disease (ALD)
    • Primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC)
    • Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)
    • Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH/MASH)
    • Wilson disease
    • Drug-induced liver injury


Hemochromatosis (Options B & C): Iron accumulation causes liver damage through oxidative stress but does not characteristically produce MDBs.

Autoimmune hepatitis (Options B & D) typically shows interface hepatitis, plasma cell infiltration, and rosetting, not MDBs.

Wilson disease (Option B): is partially correct, as MDBs may be present, but the combination overall is not most representative of classical MDB associations.

Viral hepatitis (Option C): While chronic viral hepatitis may rarely show MDBs, it is not a classical feature.

Budd-Chiari syndrome (Option C) shows centrilobular necrosis and congestion, not MDBs.

α1-antitrypsin deficiency (Option D): The hallmark is periodic acid-Schiff (PAS)-positive, diastase-resistant globules, not MDBs.

Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) (Option D) affects intra-hepatic and extra-hepatic bile ducts with periductal fibrosis, not MDB formation.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old woman presents for review three months after undergoing an extensive resection of her distal small intestine for Crohn's disease. She continues to experience persistent diarrhoea and is concerned that her Crohn's disease remains active. Her vital signs are stable (BP 105/70 mmHg, pulse 80 bpm), and physical examination reveals a soft, non-tender abdomen.

Laboratory findings:
1. Haemoglobin: 10.4 g/dL (13.5-18)
2. WBC: 4.5 x 10⁹/L (4-10)
3. Platelets: 195 x 10⁹/L (150-400)
4. Sodium: 138 mmol/L (134-143)
5. Potassium: 3.4 mmol/L (3.5-5.0)
6. Creatinine: 1.4 mg/dL
7. CRP: 9 mg/L (<10)

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient underwent extensive distal small bowel resection, which reduces the surface area available for fat absorption.
  • Persistent diarrhoea, in the absence of elevated inflammatory markers (CRP only mildly elevated), suggests a nutrient malabsorption issue rather than active inflammation.
  • The distal ileum is critical for bile acid and fat absorption. Its loss leads to steatorrhea, vitamin deficiencies, and fatty acid loss.
  • Low potassium may reflect chronic diarrhoea and nutrient losses.

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Chronic watery or greasy diarrhoea (steatorrhoea)
  • Nutritional deficiencies (especially fat-soluble vitamins: A, D, E, K)
  • Fatigue, failure to thrive (in children), or anaemia
  • May have mild electrolyte abnormalities (hypokalaemia)

Active Crohn's disease (Option A): The patient's CRP is normal, there's no leukocytosis or abdominal tenderness, and the surgical resection would have reduced inflammatory burden. Clinical signs don't indicate active inflammation.

Bacterial overgrowth syndrome (Option B): Although bacterial overgrowth can occur post bowel surgery, it usually causes bloating, flatulence, and megaloblastic anaemia (due to B12 deficiency), not isolated diarrhoea. Also, this condition often causes elevated folate levels and not low-grade inflammation.

Bile acid diarrhoea (Option C): It typically results from limited ileal resection (<100 cm). However, extensive ileal resection reduces bile acid pool so severely that steatorrhea from fat malabsorption dominates rather than the secretory diarrhoea of bile acid excess.

choices.text: Modified radical neck dissection type I

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with biopsy-confirmed squamous cell carcinoma of the lateral tongue presents for surgical evaluation. Examination reveals a persistent ulcer and a palpable level II cervical node. Based on the anatomical site and lymphatic drainage of the primary tumor, which of the following neck dissections would be inappropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
• Posterolateral neck dissection involves clearance of levels II-V and is indicated primarily for cutaneous malignancies of the posterior scalp and upper neck, not oral cavity cancers.
  • Its lymphatic basin does not include the anterior triangle nodes (levels I-III), which are commonly involved in oral cavity squamous cell carcinoma (SCC).
  • Therefore, this dissection would not provide adequate oncologic control in this case.


  • In oral cavity cancers (especially tongue), levels I-III are frequently involved.
  • Extension to level IV is considered if deep tongue or floor of mouth involvement is suspected.
  • Posterolateral dissection is not used for anterior or oral cavity cancers.

Supra-omohyoid neck dissection (Option A): Removes levels I-III, which are typically involved in cancers of the oral cavity. It is the standard selective dissection in early-stage oral SCC.

Extended supra-omohyoid dissection (Option B): Removes levels I-IV and is used for oral cavity or oropharynx tumors with deeper invasion or nodal spread beyond level III.

Modified radical neck dissection type I (Option D): Removes levels I-V while preserving CN XI. It is indicated when multiple levels are involved or for more advanced disease.

choices.text: Secondary pulmonary alveolar proteinosis due to hematologic disease
Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis associated with metal dust exposure

questions.text: A 35-year-old nonsmoking male presents with progressive shortness of breath and dry cough for the past 3 months. He denies fever, weight loss, or chest pain. High-resolution CT of the chest shows a "crazy-paving" pattern. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) yields a milky fluid positive for periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) stain. Serum testing shows anti-GM-CSF antibodies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with gradually progressive respiratory symptoms, a crazy-paving pattern on HRCT, PAS-positive milky BAL, and anti-GM-CSF antibodies, which are classic features of Autoimmune Pulmonary Alveolar Proteinosis (PAP).

Pulmonary Alveolar Proteinosis (PAP):



PAP associated with metal dust exposure (Option C) falls under secondary PAP, but the presence of anti-GM-CSF antibodies rules out this cause. Also, there's no occupational exposure history.

Key Takeaways:

questions.text: A 30-year-old man working in a postal sorting facility presents with fever, chest pain, and progressive shortness of breath. Chest X-ray reveals mediastinal widening. His history is significant for opening a suspicious powder-containing envelope two days ago. Which of the following is the most likely Category A bioterrorism agent responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Bacillus anthracis, the causative agent of anthrax, is classified under Category A bioterrorism agents due to the following reasons:

  • High priority agent with potential for massive impact
  • Easily disseminated via spores (aerosol or powder)
  • High mortality rate, especially in inhalational anthrax
  • Causes social disruption
  • Requires specialized public health resources for containment and treatment

The patient's occupational exposure and classic radiological finding (mediastinal widening) strongly support inhalational anthrax.


Q fever (Coxiella burnetii) (Option A): Incorrect. This is a Category B agent, not associated with high mortality or immediate mass disruption.

Typhus fever (Rickettsia prowazekii) (Option B): Incorrect. Also falls under Category B, causes moderate disease and lacks high bioterrorism potential.

Brucellosis (Brucella melitensis) (Option D): Incorrect. Also a Category B agent, it causes chronic febrile illness but not rapid mortality or airborne dissemination.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man, a chronic smoker, presents with exertional dyspnoea and chronic cough. Pulmonary function tests reveal a post-bronchodilator FEV₁ of 40% predicted and an FEV₁/FVC ratio <0.7. According to the GOLD 2023 classification, what is the severity grade of his airflow limitation?
questions.solution:
The patient's FEV₁ is 40% predicted and FEV₁/FVC is <0.7 post-bronchodilator, both of which meet the diagnostic and severity classification criteria for COPD as per GOLD guidelines:

Since the patient's FEV₁ is 40%, he clearly fits into the GOLD 3 (Severe) category.

This grading is based purely on spirometric airflow limitation, independent of symptom burden or exacerbation risk - those are considered separately in the ABCD/E GOLD grouping.


  • Diagnosis of COPD requires:
    • Post-bronchodilator FEV₁/FVC <0.7
    • Then severity is graded by FEV₁ % predicted
  • In this case: FEV₁ = 40%, which is GOLD 3 (Severe) airflow limitation

questions.text: A woman comes to a rural health camp with complaints of excessive soap use during household chores and roughness of hair after bathing. The public health officer suspects water hardness. After boiling the water, the lathering ability of soap improves significantly. What is the most likely chemical cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
• The scenario describes a condition that improves with boiling, which is diagnostic of temporary hardness of water.
  • Temporary hardness is caused by bicarbonates of calcium and magnesium, which precipitate out as insoluble calcium carbonate upon boiling.
  • This form of hardness is more common and can be tackled at the household level with simple interventions like boiling or lime addition.

Hardness of Water:

  • Definition: Hardness is the loss of soap's cleansing power due to calcium and magnesium salts in water.
  • Temporary hardness:
    • Caused by calcium and magnesium bicarbonates.
    • Removed by boiling (liberates CO₂ and forms insoluble CaCO₃).
  • Permanent hardness:
    • Caused by sulphates, chlorides, and nitrates of Ca and Mg.
    • Requires chemical softening using lime, sodium carbonate, or base exchange methods.
  • Unit of measurement: 1 mEq/L of ion = 50 mg CaCO₃/L.
  • Classification by hardness (mEq/L):
    • Soft water: <1
    • Moderately hard: 1-3
    • Hard: 3-6
    • Very hard: >6
  • WHO recommendation: Drinking water should be moderately hard.

Calcium and Magnesium sulphates (Option A): Incorrect- These salts are responsible for permanent hardness, not temporary. They do not decompose on boiling.

Calcium and Magnesium chlorides (Option B): Incorrect- These also cause permanent hardness and require chemical softening, not boiling.

Calcium and Magnesium nitrates (Option D): Incorrect- Like sulphates and chlorides, these contribute to permanent hardness and are not removed by boiling.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old male is referred to the endocrinology clinic for evaluation of delayed puberty. He reports absent facial, axillary, and pubic hair, as well as anosmia since childhood. On examination, he has a small testicular volume and lack of secondary sexual characteristics.

Laboratory tests reveal:
1. Testosterone: 3.5 nmol/L (Normal: 10-30)
2. LH: 1.8 IU/L (Normal: 1-10)
3. FSH: 2.2 IU/L (Normal: 1-7)
4. Prolactin: 350 mU/L (Normal: <450)

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The combination of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (low testosterone, low/inappropriately normal LH & FSH) and anosmia is classic for Kallmann syndrome, a congenital condition due to failure of migration of GnRH neurons and olfactory bulb development.
  • The patient also has absent secondary sexual characteristics, small testicles, and normal prolactin, all of which further support this diagnosis.

Testicular feminisation syndrome (Option A) presents with phenotypic female appearance in 46,XY individuals due to androgen receptor insensitivity. This patient is male by phenotype and gender identity.

Marfan syndrome (Option C): Although Marfan's presents with tall stature and features like arachnodactyly and lens dislocation, it does not cause hypogonadism or anosmia.

questions.text: An environmental health officer is asked to assess the degree of organic pollution in untreated domestic wastewater collected during a routine public health inspection. Which of the following is the standard indicator used to determine the organic content of such sewage?
questions.solution:
• Biochemical Oxygen Demand (BOD) is the standard test used to assess the organic content of sewage.
  • It measures the amount of oxygen absorbed by microorganisms over a specified time (commonly 5 days at 20°C) for the aerobic breakdown of biodegradable organic matter.
  • BOD is the most widely accepted indicator of sewage strength in terms of biodegradable pollutants.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is referred for evaluation of hypertension. On examination, his kidneys are palpable bilaterally. An abdominal ultrasound reveals multiple cysts in both kidneys. Which of the following is most likely to be associated with his condition?
questions.solution:
Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) is the most common inherited kidney disorder in adults and is characterised by:

  • Multiple bilateral renal cysts
  • Early-onset hypertension
  • Flank pain, hematuria, progressive renal failure
  • Palpable kidneys on examination

Polycythaemia is a recognised association due to increased erythropoietin production by the cyst-lining epithelial cells in ADPKD. This leads to increased red cell mass in some patients.


Nail pitting (Option B): This is associated with psoriasis, not ADPKD. Psoriatic arthritis may also feature nail pitting, but PKD has no dermatological manifestations like this.

Hypermobility (Option C): Hypermobility is a feature of connective tissue disorders such as Ehlers-Danlos syndrome or Marfan syndrome, not ADPKD. These conditions can have cysts but are genetically and clinically distinct.

Mitral stenosis (Option D): Mitral valve prolapse, not stenosis, is more commonly associated with ADPKD. MVP occurs in ~25% of patients with ADPKD due to connective tissue changes in the mitral valve.

choices.text: 200,000 IU once at 9 months of age
200,000 IU every 6 months till 5 years of age

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the community health center for a routine immunization and nutritional check-up. The mother reports no symptoms but is concerned about her child's nutrition. As per the national schedule for Vitamin A prophylaxis in India, which of the following is the correct dose and frequency of Vitamin A supplementation for this age group?
questions.solution:
• According to the National Vitamin A Prophylaxis Programme, after the first dose of 100,000 IU at 9 months, children aged 12-59 months (1-5 years) are administered 200,000 IU of Vitamin A orally every 6 months.
  • The total cumulative dose of Vitamin A given by the age of 5 years is 17 lakh IU, as part of a preventive strategy against Vitamin A deficiency.

Schedule Summary:

  • 1st dose: 100,000 IU at 9 months (with measles)
  • 2nd dose: 200,000 IU at 15-18 months (with DPT booster)
