  • 3rd to 9th dose: 200,000 IU every 6 months until 5 years of age

100,000 IU once (Option A): Incorrect. This is the dose for infants aged 6-11 months but not for a 2-year-old child.

100,000 IU every 4-6 months (Option B): Incorrect. 100,000 IU is not adequate for children >12 months. The correct prophylactic dose is 200,000 IU for this age group.

200,000 IU once at 9 months (Option C): Incorrect. At 9 months, only 100,000 IU is administered with measles vaccine, not 200,000 IU.

Reference: https://nhm.gov.in/index1.php?lang=1&level=3&sublinkid=1452&lid=801

questions.text: A 19-year-old man presents with difficulty walking that has gradually worsened over the past year. He has a history of poor vision that did not improve significantly with corrective lenses. On examination, he has dysarthria, horizontal nystagmus, and optic disc pallor. Reflexes are absent at the knees and ankles. Plantar responses are equivocal. He also has a high-arched foot (pes cavus). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Friedreich's ataxia is the most likely diagnosis in this young male with progressive ataxia, absent deep tendon reflexes, nystagmus, optic disc pallor, and pes cavus, all hallmark features of this condition. The age of onset, absence of reflexes, and optic atrophy point strongly towards a spinal cord and cerebellar degenerative disorder, which matches Friedreich's.

  • Progressive gait and limb ataxia: Due to cerebellar and spinocerebellar tract involvement.
  • Absent reflexes: Result of dorsal root ganglia degeneration.
  • Vision problems & optic disc pallor: Optic nerve involvement.
  • Dysarthria & intention tremors: Due to cerebellar atrophy.
  • Pes cavus: Orthopaedic deformity frequently seen.
  • Equivocal plantar reflexes: Common in advanced neurological disorders.
  • Age (19 years): Consistent with classical onset (10-20 years).


Spinocerebellar ataxia (Option A): It is autosomal dominant, usually has later onset (30-50 yrs), and retained reflexes are often seen in early stages.

Alcoholic cerebellar degeneration (Option C): It occurs in chronic alcoholics, with predominant truncal ataxia and preserved reflexes; vision problems and pes cavus are not characteristic.

Wilson's disease (Option D): Although it presents in young adults with neurological features, it typically includes extrapyramidal signs (e.g., dystonia, tremors), Kayser-Fleischer rings, and hepatic involvement - none of which are described here.

choices.text: Occupational health safety for female workers

questions.text:
During a national training session for newly recruited community health workers, the facilitator introduces a globally recognized strategy developed by UNICEF to reduce mortality and improve health indicators across underserved populations. This framework includes interventions like growth tracking, immunization, and promotion of essential health practices.

Within this strategy, the "O" stands for which of the following interventions?
questions.solution:
The GOBI-FFF strategy, initiated by UNICEF, is a structured global health approach for child survival. It emphasizes the following interventions:


  • The "O" stands for Oral Rehydration Therapy, a simple, cost-effective intervention for reducing deaths from childhood diarrhea, a major cause of under-five mortality.

Oral contraceptive distribution (Option A): Incorrect- While family planning is part of the strategy, it is covered under the "F" components, not "O".

Obesity prevention counseling (Option C): Incorrect- Obesity is not a primary focus of this UNICEF strategy, which prioritizes malnutrition, infections, and child survival in resource-limited settings.

Occupational health safety for female workers (Option D): Incorrect- While female literacy is a component, occupational safety is not included in the GOBI-FFF framework.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with progressive weakness. Examination reveals weakness of upper limb extensors and lower limb flexors, nasal speech, and tongue fasciculations. Deep tendon reflexes are brisk in the lower limbs. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This case is classic for Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), the most common form of Motor Neuron Disease (MND), characterised by mixed upper and lower motor neuron signs:

  • Upper Motor Neuron signs: Spasticity, brisk reflexes (lower limb reflexes are brisk).
  • Lower Motor Neuron signs: Tongue fasciculations, weakness with wasting.
  • Bulbar involvement: Nasal speech → indicates cranial nerve involvement.
  • Asymmetric limb involvement: Extensors of upper limbs, flexors of lower limbs - classic MND pattern.

MND (especially ALS) spares sensory and cognitive functions early on and shows combined UMN and LMN signs, especially in middle-aged males.

Motor Neuron Disease:


Wilson's disease (Option A): It typically presents earlier (teens to 30s), often with hepatic dysfunction, psychiatric changes, and movement disorders like dystonia or tremor-not isolated UMN + LMN signs. Tongue fasciculations and nasal speech are not typical.

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (Option B): It presents with rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus, and ataxia-not with chronic progressive motor weakness and fasciculations. It's also extremely rare and has a fulminant course.

Myasthenia gravis (Option D): It presents with fatigable weakness and often involves ocular muscles (ptosis, diplopia). Reflexes are preserved, and no fasciculations or UMN signs (e.g., brisk reflexes) are present. Also, MG does not involve tongue fasciculations.

choices.text: Use both Pentavalent & MR open vials
Discard both Pentavalent & MR open vials
Use Pentavalent vial & discard MR vial
Use MR vial & discard Pentavalent vial

questions.text: A 1-year-old child presents for immunization at an urban PHC. The health worker finds 1 open vial of Pentavalent vaccine and 2 open vials of MR vaccine, both used in the previous session. The cold chain has been maintained, aseptic technique was followed, expiry dates are valid, VVM is acceptable, and each vial is labeled with date and time of opening. What is the correct course of action as per the Open Vial Policy?
questions.solution:
• Liquid Pentavalent is covered under the Open Vial Policy (OVP) and may be used for up to 28 days if eligibility criteria are met
  • MR (Measles-Rubella) vaccine is a lyophilized preparation and is not included in OVP; it must be discarded at the end of each immunization session
  • Use of open vials is permitted only when vials are labeled with opening time/date, cold chain maintained, and no contamination suspected

Eligibility Criteria for Reuse of Open Vials

  • Multi-dose liquid vaccine
  • Expiry date valid
  • Cold chain maintained
  • Aseptic withdrawal technique used
  • Vial not submerged in water
  • Vial not contaminated
  • Vial labeled with date and time of opening
  • VVM (Vaccine Vial Monitor) in usable stage
  • Transported using zipper bag and sealed ice packs
  • In case of AEFI, retain the opened vial

Use both Pentavalent & MR open vials (Option A): Incorrect. MR is not covered under OVP and must be discarded after every session even if unopened doses remain.

Discard both Pentavalent & MR open vials (Option B): Incorrect. Pentavalent is reusable under OVP if all criteria are met. Discarding it is unnecessary and wasteful.

Use MR vial & discard Pentavalent vial (Option D): Incorrect. MR must be discarded, not reused. Pentavalent, if eligibility is fulfilled, can be reused.
